description:
Used to eat here a couple times a week when we lived in the City. Hadn't been often since we moved to Napa, but dropped in for lunch today. We discovered that the restaurant has a new owner, the Chef. His name is Hiro, and he's a super friendly guy and great chef. 

We also discovered that the options for neta (the stuff that goes on top of the rice has expanded. We luxuriated on melt-in-your-mouth toro, crunched through the great giant clam, and the uni from northern Japan was so good that I had to steam one of Julie's pieces when she wasn't looking. 

The service was also a big step up from the past. Our sake glasses were never empty! Anyone who knows me knows that that takes work to accomplish.

Can't wait to return for dinner!
author: David G.

description:
We should've looked at the menu before going in. We were totally disappointed on the menu, with the small/basic sushi roll selections, no appetizers, and prices. The rolls were tiny pieces. 

And 2 cans of coke were $5.90+tax

Worst $75 lunch

Nope, we're not coming back.
author: Chaye U.

description:
A slightly underwhelming restaurant. 

I ordered the octopus as appetizer. Paired with the sauce, it was a delicious dish. The octopus was firm and chewy. 

For my main, I got the three item combination dinner, and chose the tempura, salmon teriyaki, and pork cutlet. The dinner came with many side dishes, including an egg custard (quite yummy) and miso soup. The pork cutlet was tough and hard to chew. The salmon teriyaki was small in size and very average. Nothing special about the tempura. 

For dessert, I chose the green tea ice cream. It was okay, not nearly as creamy or milky as I prefer. 

My friend ordered the eel, and I think this dish was much better than the one I got. The eel was soft and the flavors paired well with the egg and rice sides. 

Not a bad place to eat, but not great either.
author: Karen Y.

description: Price is a bit higher (though still within normal SF price) here than surrounding restaurants but the portions are huge and the food is generally not bad. Nothing too fancy, taste like what you may have from home. I like that they served in different plates.
author: Clara Y.

description:
Came here a few times and the food hasn't disappointed me yet.

Sushi was fresh and the noodles were yum. 

Wait staff operated at a good pace each time we were here.

The Japanese porridge, which they only serve at dinner time is delicious and I have been thinking about going back for seconds.

I'll be back.
author: Sam Y.

description: Great traditional Japanese food.  Love the fried oysters!    However they now charge for chawan mushi, so I miss having the small delicious taste to start the meal.
author: Lisa M.

description: Fresh and delicious sushi! Tried their special of fatty tuna nigiri. It literally melted in my mouth =P. Tried the American Idol roll- pretty good! Tried a bite of the cold udon noodle dish with the tempura. So crisp and delicious. I'd definitely come back here to try more! I wasn't as hungry at the time, so the roll was the perfect portion for my dinner.
author: Kirby P.

description:
Ostensibly free of Asian fusion it's an unpretentious place at the "end" of Japantown next to the Kabuki Hotel. The dinners are a pretty good value. I was t a huge fan of the savory egg custard but others were. I had the sashimi and fried oyster combo. The fish was uneven. I've had better sashimi. The fried oysters were delicious. 

Friends raved about the chirashi sushi they had. Maybe I'll opt for that another time.
author: Tim P.

description: Wish I could rate this less than 1 star. THEY ARE LITERALLY FORCING THEIR CUSTOMERS TO GIVE AT LEAST %15 TIP, doesn't matter wether you liked the service or food. Their food was too salty though. Smh ‍
author: Shallia A.

description: Traveled all the way from arizona just to get to this place and try their "ramen" but what we get is not a Ramen. The presentation of the food was completely disappointing. I got the spicy miso ramen which I expect to be spicy but its not. It's like putting the noodles and a small piece of egg in a bowl full of soup. I wish they wont force their customer to tip them 15 dollars for this kind of service next time.
author: Kyra M.

description: This is probably my favorite Japanese restaurant in San Francisco.  Mostly because they serve this unique egg custard/soup appetizer, which I've never seen at any other restaurant before.  It is hard to describe, it is almost like a very thick savory semi-solid soup - my Japanese colleague was very surprised that this would be served at a restaurant in the US.  Other than that egg custard/soup, this place seems like most other Japanese restaurants in SF, albeit with slightly higher prices.
author: John P.

description:
Solid lunch options here. They have limited orders of their special lunch bento (30) for $11.95 which includes a main of your choosing, plus salad, soup, California roll and tempura. Chawanmushi are limited to 10 per day so get there early to get one.

Opted for the lunch tonkatsu since I was craving it for some reason and got the chawanmushi. Pork was nice and thick, tender, juicy (lean with not much fat) and had the thinnest crispy batter, which so hit the spot. Chawanmushi was good, but I missed having some scallops or shrimp in there.

Definitely the place to go for lunch and avoid the crazy touristy places on the other side of the mall.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
You would never know this was here unless you wandered over to the other side of jtown that no one really cares about.  It's in the same building as daiso...but upstairs to the left on the corner.  Haha.  It is Japanese owned and they definitely pride and advertise that.  Some of their fish also comes from tsukiji market in Japan. 

My favorite thing about this place?  Their lunchtime bento.  I don't come here for anything else.  For under $12, you get a huge bento box full of salad, california roll, tempura, rice, miso soup, and a protein of your choice.  I mean...it's pretty gosh darn good except for the times my chicken teriyaki is a bit burnt and overcooked.  The tempura though is always spot on and prob my favorite spot for that.  

It's always busy at lunch time.  Doesn't matter the day...it's busy.  Service can be on the slower side but they get the job done.  One of my favorite spots for lunch and definitely beats out most of the other spots in jtown.
author: Jen W.

description:
I love that this place is not pretentious! It's just your good ol Japanese Owned Restaurant....
 The sushi is fresh and is not warm... the tempura is perfect and if you're feeling adventurous get the thinly slice beef tongue

You come here with friends who actually like sushi not the fake rolls but sashimi and such! 

Coming back soooon
author: Ella W.

description: This used to be one of our favorite Japanese restaurant in town. I guess it's under new management now; most of the sushi we ordered were not available . The service were terrible ; the waitress did not even know what is Yusenabe. The minute we sat down, one of the waitress asked what do we want to drink and are we ready to order right after she gave the menu. They never came back to the table after served our food. All the food were not even tasted like the old Takara we loved. It's a shame
author: Margaret L.

description: Authentic Japanese style.. This is the place .. ordered a 2 set meal combo .... it's pretty decent Serving... Before our meal came out .. had the Custard hmmmmmmm can't recall... it's good .. the Quality of Food not bad ... Loved it..
author: Donovan L.

description:
Very reasonable prize and good quality. We ordered mini octopus for appetizer, a combo of Sashimi and 2 combo of Nigiri for main dishes. The Nigiri combo came along with a Miso soup and Chawan-Mushi. 
We waited for a little while to be seated, but the quality of the food satisfied us.
author: Lê H.

description:
This is probably the only decent place to eat in japantown. I've heard good things about the omakase spot down the hall, and the ice cream place everyone raves about downstairs is edible but nothing to write home about. Bottom line is: my pocketbook can afford to keep me coming back here and the quality of this restaurant will surely do that.

The sign outside read, "no fusion." For once, it didn't lie. The waiter was polite and prompt. Ordered the two dish combination. It comes with an assortment of small dishes.

What I enjoy about this place is that no single dish is over-the-top french fusion caviar too rich to eat. It's all just mom's cooking, and it's good. The steamed egg uses real chicken stock, not that crap out the box your lazy ass keeps buying. It's full of real chicken. I mean real chicken, not chicken breast. You know, the kind with brown meat and flavor. There's also a mini-shrimp and a mushroom. Exactly what you wanna when you order this dish.

Miso soup was standard. Seaweed (the thick kind). Pickled vegetables were there, but I've never really been a fan. And I never remember having those salads with orange thousand island while in Japan, but hey, they are serving Americans. In any case you can choose not to eat it. The rice was sweet and properly cooked. Everything you would want.

The sashimi was the appropriate temperature and cut to the correct proportion. I don't know why that's so difficult for most sushi chefs to get right in SF, but these guys nailed it. Also, the serving size was just right for a five dish combo (I think there were seven pieces). Only thing lackluster here was that fake green kind of wasabi. But at an everyday kind of restaurant, I guess I can really expect fresh wasabi. In fact, I don't think I've even seen real wasabi get used in SF, even at that overpriced one-kind-of-sushi-omakase served at akiko, the chefs only use the green paste.

Tempura was a classic finish to the meal. Light and crispy on the outside and cooked to perfection on the inside.

I think the only thing I was disappointed by during my visit to this lovely neighborhood restaurant was the lack of dobinmoshi on the menu.

To recap, this restaurant just didn't make a wrong turn, like nearly every other restaurant in SF does. And at SF prices, there better not be any oops I served you warm sushi mistakes. I'm really not sure why Yelp only gives this place 3 stars. All I can come up with is that yelp reviewers are fickle and don't judge a restaurant on its food. You guys tend to send me to fancy looking places that play house music and taste like shit, serving me $30 plates prepared by a donkey that's never tasted the frozen seafood s/he serves his/her customers. I wish you guys who don't know what real foods is, who don't cook for a living or in your spare time, would stop reviewing; you're fauxing up our restaurant culture. But this place is really the only restaurant I will return to in Japantown. I highly recommend it if you enjoy real Japanese food.
author: JWest M.

description:
The quality and assortment of the sushi combination was a bit underwhelming. I specifically ordered the special item sushi of the day (kohada) to see how well it was prepared (a decent reflection on the quality of the other fish that are likely to be served) - and it tasted a bit too fishy and not pickled as well as it should have been. The rest of the nigiri that came shortly after we received the kohada didn't feel that fresh and the didn't taste anything above average. The overall experience felt like average sushi for slightly above-average prices. 

However, the cozy atmosphere, the quick and attentive service, and friendliness of staff made the visit a bit more comfortable.
author: David Y.

description:
My wife and I just had a great dinner at Takara. Under new ownership for a little less than one year, so FORGET all the old reviews you see here on Yelp. Our experience was fantastic!
I had Black Garlic Tonkotsu spicy Ramen. Wonderful broth (takes 15 hrs. to make), and shared a Takara Roll - very fresh and flavorful.
Waitress was super-helpful and really helped us through the menu.
My advice - get in there before the secret gets out!
author: Joe B.

description: Really enjoyed the tempura udon here. I was craving udon and it hit the spot. The broth was clean (not greasy) and flavorful, the noodles were perfectly cooked, and the tempura was lightly crisp on the outside, just like it should be. Along with the shrimp tempura, they also had potato, sweet potato, and green beans. The place seemed very authentic, and our server was attentive. I would come back here!
author: April H.

description:
Takara venerably is the quintessence of authentic Japanese dining in SF Japantown!!!

It's also sadly one of the last few remaining Japanese owned and operated eateries in J-Town since much of the neighborhood has become nauseatingly gentrified with hipster ramen, poke, and chai places. 

Japantown was once filled with sushi-ya's and authentic Japanese restaurants which focused on quality over quantity. Now, it seems to be the opposite with many diners looking to grab a quick, inexpensive bite to eat before or after they see a movie down the street. My Mom grew up in SF Japantown and this area has has a long, rich, and genuine culinary history.  

When the Chef/Owner of Aka Tombo (formerly of Yamato) unfortunately passed away unexpectedly a few years ago it marked a turning point for the neighborhood and what used to be inexpensive stables in Japanese and Asian Pacific Islander cuisine, ramen and poke,  suddenly became contemporary hipster, along with the prices, sigh. 

You really can't go wrong dining at Takara! They have one section that's an awesome sushi bar and another that's a full on restaurant and, for over past decade I've had the pleasure of dining at both and have never been disappointed. I love the combination lunches and dinners at the restaurant and their tempura is truly out of this world!

Last month we decided to give the sushi bar at Takara another go and were totally stoked! The head Sushi Chef Ken really knew his fish and made brilliant recommendations. He and his staff were warm, cordial, knowledgable and gave amazing insights into Japan and it's culture, which I totally appreciated being 1/2 Japanese American. 

The Hirame was perfection personified! Fresh, delicate, and enticing. So much so that we devoured 3 whole orders!

I LOVED their Saba Sushi! It wasn't "fishy" tasting and the pieces were prepared with only the the tenderest cuts on top of the rice!

My favorite has always been the Ama Ebi. OMG, it's so sweet and delicious! What's more, Sushi Chef Ken gave me the option of them preparing the shrimp head either in a miso soup or coking it tempura. I love me my deep fried shrimp heads and I wish I ordered a few more!

What truly stood out at Takara's Sushi Bar was their Unagi. I've had eel and then I've REALLY had eel! Golly, this was the divinely buttery and fragrant! Truly outstanding!

What more can I say but Takara is now our official "GO TO" authentic Japanese Sushi Bar and Restaurant in SF Japantown! We look forward to seeing you again later this month!

All Hail Takara! Kampaii!!!
author: Richard T.

description:
My fashionable, friendly and foodie mom, 93 years young, is now in hospice. Her condition now keeps her from being able to keep food down but she is still able to enjoy the taste. 
She lived for many years in Japan and learned to speak Japanese fluently. When she moved to San Francisco a dozen years ago, she discovered Takara and enjoyed many lunches and dinners there.
Sadly, she is now so weak that she can't walk. As someone who loved Japanese cuisine, in the past couple of weeks she's asked for chawan mushi, which is quintessential Japanese comfort food. It's steamed egg custard with small amounts of mushrooms, gingko nuts, pieces of meat, etc. mixed in. A week ago I had called Takara and spoke to a waitress asking if I could get chawan mushi as a take-out. She said no, it was only available in the restaurant. (The reason is that it's made in a ceramic bowl.) Last night I walked by the restaurant. I explained the situation. Owner Hiro gave me a steaming ceramic cup with a cover and said "I'm pretty sure that I know your mom. Tell her I'm so sorry and that's it's on us. Just return the bowl and cover, when you can." I nearly started crying. When I went to show her, she was dozing. But I gently woke her and asked if she wanted to taste it now or tomorrow. She replied without hesitation, "right now!" She was so happy. Her happiness means everything to me. Thank you, Hiro and Takara. Your act of kindness will forever be remembered by our family.
author: Liana T.

description:
$9-12 for a bento box lunch? What a deal, especially when it comes with miso soup, salad, 3 california rolls, and tempura. The menu is very diverse so they have many options for sushi, and other lunch deals which I recommend. It was nice that they still offered the lunch special prices on a Saturday too!

We got the tonkatsu and beef terriyaki bento box, no complaints on anything except that maybe it took a bit for the waiter to take our order, but everything was very delicious. They are located in the Japanese Center Miyako Mall in Japantown, but more towards one of the ends, so I would suggest going through the parking lot of the Kabuki hotel to find the restaurant entrance faster.
author: Alexa T.

description:
Pretty good japanese foods with reasonable price.
Had chicken katsu dinner plate.
Including miso soup, japanese style steamed egg, bowel of rice, 2 pieces of yellow raddish ,one veggi side dish, entree with salad and one scoop of green tea ice cream for dessert.
Really enjoyed to eat with family.
Highly recommend this rest if you are in Japantown center.
Will go back to try bbq eel dinner and salmon teriyaki dinner plate in the future.
author: Jane K.

description:
This restaurant has been a long time family favorite.  Food is always hot and fresh, and extremely tasty.  We only come for lunch, and there is frequently a line with sign-up sheet, so be prepared to wait.  The special bento box is an amazing deal at $12 for soup, salad, California roll, tempura, and one main of your choosing.  Unfortunately they are limited to 30 bento boxes a day, and they were all out when we tried to order at 12:30 yesterday. 

We had tempura, steak teriyaki and pork tonkatsu.  YUMMO!  All were still a very good deal for the amount of food and quality.  Service is friendly.  We especially liked how they automatically serve hot green tea with no charge.   

Whenever we have our "Japantown day" we will come to Takara for lunch!
author: Marie B.

description: Excellent with 3 nice slices Hamachi, ika with tobiko, rock n roll= eel & avocado roll, chawan mushi, Hamachi collar, uni nigiri. Owner is sushi chef, has owned only 7 months. Very charming guy, will go back.
author: Dave Y.

description:
Takara is easily my favorite in Japantown. This is a kind of place where I just enjoy all the meals and service is consistently great. I've ordered almost everything and haven't had a bad experience yet.

On my last trip I came here on a Saturday morning around 12:30pm in a group of 4. I ordered the cold udon and it was good :)
author: Mimi T.

description: 一番好きな寿司店。Very delicious and fish is fresh... I don't know why that store opened at the corner. Difficult to find... I always go to Japantown but I never found... ( '' )
author: Eva D.

description: You are here because you want decent Japanese food, with decent service, in a decent looking space. The menu is diverse, sushi, udon noodles, standard set dinners. Try the rice balls and seaweed salad for appetizers. Volcano vegetarian roll and miso cod for entrees are good.
author: Mohini R.

description: Came here with a Japanese friend and the sushi was super fresh. Service is very efficient and friendly. I got one of the lunch sushi specials and they were very accommodating to my food allergies. Loved this restaurant and exploring Japantown. Get the sushi here!
author: Andrew D.

description:
If you want authentic old style Japanese fare, you've come to the right place as this place has been here for a long time.  There are so many places in Japantown to eat and one of our friends recommended this place but she hasn't been here in a long time so we thought we'd give it a try. 

I'd say it is a 3 and 1/2 to 4 star place.  The portions are good for the price.  Some of us ordered sushi, chicken katsu (huge portion), as well as the dinner set which includes radish, miso soup, hot savory custard that had mushrooms and fish cake, seaweed, rice and dessert as well as the entree.  The custard was ok but I wasn't expecting it to have some unusual flavors in it.  Some dinners even come with tempura.  I ordered the unajyu dinner which is eel and the portions were huge.  It came in a box with the eel on top and the rice on the bottom.  Dessert was green tea ice cream!
author: Karen W.

description: After not having been here for a long time, we decided to try it again and it was incredible. The food was back to its great quality - and portions. Service was good. The vegetable tempura was exquitely done and the miso soup was one of the best I have had anywhere. My companion ordered the regular Chirashi and he found it perfect with more than the average slices of sashimi.  We will definitely be back soon.
author: Richard p H.

description: Lunch Sushi box was ok and got to the table fast so no complaints. The fish seemed fresh and tasted good so maybe just a little pricey but overall good experience for lunch.
author: Gil S.

description: I've been to a lot of Japanese restaurants in SF Nihonmachi over the past few decades but I've never discovered Takara. My friend and I decided to stop over when we realized the restaurant I used to frequent wasn't open. We saw that the reviews on Yelp for Takara were decent. So glad we did. I ordered the Iron Pot Rice Dinner. It was delicious and very filling. Was nice to have chawanmushi too; first time in a long time. The food quality was decent and not over the top. Like others have said, their "no fusion" sign was spot on. The prices were reasonable as well. Gochisousama deshita.
author: Mayumi C.

description: Good tasty options at a slightly pricing rate.  Clean and fairly quiet restaurant within a mall setting
author: Lana C.

description: Nice place, food is decent with good portion.... (noodle soup and donburi are served hot!!!  Just the way i like it :)
author: Dan Y.

description:
Of all of the restaurants that I've tried in and around Japantown, Takara is one of the most divisive among my friends (New Korea House would be another).  The two times we've been here, the same issue has popped up - decent food, but why are some items so expensive?  And this isn't even counting the first time we tried coming here, when my friends walked up, saw the prices, and walked away.

Cost aside, Takara's menu is actually one of the more interesting ones Japantown has to offer.  Beyond the usual slate of bento boxes, udon/soba, donbouri, and sashimi/nigiri/rolls (which is what we had the first time, about four years ago), there are more authentic and unique items, like onigiri, ochazuke (rice in soup), and zousui (rice porridges).  

-- SPIDER ROLL - Deep Fried Soft Shell Crab...$9.50
-- ROCK & ROLL - Unagi and Avocado...$6.00
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/takara-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=spIuS38sLgZJwfHhO92E4A)
Neither were bad, but they weren't very notable either.  Both were pretty standard for the most part, though the unagi in the Rock & Roll was pretty decent.  The Spider Roll also had a shiso leaf in it, but I thought that actually was more distracting than anything else.

-- OYAKO ZOUSUI - Salmon and Salmon Roe Porridge...$13.95
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/takara-japanese-restaurant-san-francisco?select=HcemjcGTz_JaVlc87-pKlQ)
Not only was this the whole point of coming back (and to write this review), but this is the only reason why I'd come back.  On such a cold, foggy night, this was perfect - hot, filling, and subtly flavorful.  What's more, it had a fairly generous amount of salmon and roe.  Yum.

As for what I had the first time I came here, it was a few years back.  For the most part, we stuck with sushi and sahimi - Negitoro, Spicy Hotate, Hamachi Sashimi, Aoyagi (Surf Clam) Sashimi, and Mentai Onigiri (Spicy Cod Roe).  The exact details of everything we had escape me, but from what I recall, while the sashimi was fresh, everything else wasn't very memorable.

While the food falls somewhere between three and four stars, the prices really are a buzzkill.  Some things are priced pretty typically (like our rolls), but $16.75 for a Rainbow Roll?  $18.75 for a spicy Dragon Roll?  As much as I appreciate how authentic some of the food is, these aren't exactly budget friendly prices!  Since they aren't easy to find though, I'll be back for the zousui and perhaps the ochazuke.  Otherwise, I don't think I'd come back for anything else.
author: Mike L.

description:
Highway robbery.

I only went there for a karrage and gyoza app while I waited for another restaurant. Came out to 14.21.

The kaarage has 5 dinky pieces and the gyoza is the standard 6 piece. I should have known better for the gyoza but was heavily disappointed. Did not eat a full dinner so can't comment on the rest.
author: Edward K.

description:
I came here with my parents when they were visiting me in the Bay Area, and we all loved it.  

We all agreed that the food here tasted as if we were actually eating in Japan.  I'm not a fan of people saying that certain ethnic foods taste "authentic" vs. "not authentic," but I felt like I understood what that meant when I ate here.  It's not necessarily my favorite Japanese restaurant in the Bay Area, but it certainly is very good.
author: Richard S.

description: The food is really good and the service too my kids love it . i recomend this place .plus  good prices.
author: LA China A.

description:
We come here often with the kids 
The food good 
The price fair 
Fish very fresh 
Only thing the wait staff is pretty awful 
If it want for the location and food and kid friendly I doubt we go there  again 
They just pretend you don't exists 
They nearly notice you 
It's almost feels like we are annoying them by coming to eat
author: Paula O.

description: I just love this place. Old school Japanese restaurant. Good portions, well prepared. Don't come here for designer sushi, or crazy priced sushi sittings. Very satisfying, can't wait to come again. (I come every couple of weeks)
author: Tony R.

description:
I've eaten here many times over the past 15 or more years that I can recall.  I've never had a bad experience.  The food is more traditional Japanese rather than the newer Americanized style noodle and sushi dishes you will find in the more recent J-Town eateries.  My favorite dishes at Takara are the Chawan-Mushi, Miso Cod, Tempura, Teriyaki Bento, and Yosenabe. The food is fresh, well prepared and presented attractively.  The staff is attentive and unobtrusive.

Takara is my Japanese boyfriend's favorite restaurant in Japantown.  He is very picky when it comes to Japanese food and wouldn't return if the food wasn't good.
author: Donna P.

description:
The food here is actually pretty good but they were very rude. The guy who seated us was not happy that we needed an extra spot for our 7 month old baby and expressed that he was not happy to seat us. Not a big deal, we got over that but they messed up my order and charged us extra on our bill. That whole mess took about 10-15 minutes to solve while the staff was arguing about how to fix the bill. 

If you have the patience to deal with bad service this place will work out for you. I mean I'll be honest and won't bash their food since it's pretty good if they can get your order correct.
author: Tony L.

description: We had an amazing time in Takara this weekend in the sushi bar area, the fatty tuna and all sushimi were fresh and delicious.  The new owner Hiro was super friendly and we enjoyed chatting with him while he himself prepared dishes for us.  I highly recommend this place for tasty Japanese dining at very reasonable prices!!!
author: Irina E.

description: Old school Japanese home cooking. Favorite place in J-town. Want grilled saba teshoku? This is your place.
author: K T.

description:
I enjoyed Takara Japanese restaurant. It was standard Japanese cuisine, not anything over the top but very solid, wholesome and good portion sizes. 

It also looked very dependable by the amount of what seemed to be regulars filling the restaurant. 

We needed a quick meal on the go, and really ended up enjoying our meal here. I ordered the Sashimi dinner combo and got a whole lot of food! Chuwanmushi, miso soup, rice, sashimi (of course) seaweed salad and pickled radish along with complimentary green tea. All solidly good fare.The Dude got the Chicken Katsu dinner combo and was a very happy camper. 

Overall, this is a solid Japanese joint kind of a neighborhood affair and not too hard on the wallet.
author: Sara F.

description:
I really wish Japantown SF was more akin to Little Tokyo LA which has more innovative, fresh, and just better tasting restaurants overall. 

Instead we continue to have old, dated restaurants like Takara that somehow manage to live on by the willpower of tourists not knowing any better. Takara pretty much serves the whole spectrum of a Japanese restaurant, from your typical terikiyaki dinner combination, sushi, ramen to donburis and traditional porridge. To sum it up, my $17 pork katsu dinner paired with some nigiri, overcooked chawan mushi, and udon wasn't quite worth the $50 price tag for a painfully average tasting meal. 

Service was okay, although the interior of the restaurant felt pretty sad and empty. Maybe our city's rent is too damn high after all for new concepts to give birth or true ramen masters to make it.
author: Steven C.

description: we went to eat here during my sister visit from Idaho. The server and the owner were so nice to accommodate us with everything we need especially when we have 2 little children and 2 teenager with us. the food was amazing and my sister family was thrilled. we all loved it! thanks so much.
author: Olivia L.

description: It is really nice place to eat a dinner with friends. I visit this restaurant 1-2 times per year. The miso soup is pretty authentic. I felt that the sashimi is a bit overpriced.
author: Shirchin B.

description:
The food was ok, I had some soba soup and an onigiri.  The soup was a little too oily but otherwise was good, good to share between two people.  I went there with my partner, who ordered a roll and some chicken tonkatsu.

Our experience with the waitress (the taller, younger one) was one of the worst I've ever had.

As we were looking around for our server to order, a family sat at a table nearby. She eventually came to their table and took their orders then coming to ours. After we ordered, she never came to our table again. She kept walking by and going to other tables, going out of her way not to make eye contact with us, even as I tried to get her attention. The family next to us completed their meals, and she went to their table and offered them some complementary ice cream, before disappearing. She brought them the ice cream and the check, and continued to ignore us. 

We contemplated leaving without paying, as it had been half an hour since we finished our food. Eventually, after the other family left, I decided to go get another server (an older lady), who took care of us from that point on.  This second server was extremely courteous and quickly brought us the check.  The first server kept going by, refusing to make eye contact.  I didn't tip.

The restaurant should consider at least some extra training for that server, by her actions alone we'll never return.  Everyone else we interacted with were pleasant and friendly, however.
author: Eric F.

description:
Waiting time to get seated isn't that bad with a full house. Came in, and waited for about 10-15min or so to get seated...

Overall. Upon getting seated. Its nice. The venue is nice.. Its missing music though. It would be lovely if they played Japanese music in the background. 

And food wise, I've had better Japanese cousin over this.. and it's just ugh! I got nothing more to say, but this place needs a new management. Just saying. Namm sayinn..
author: Joey B.

description:
If you come to Japan town wondering where all the Japanese people are, they are eating here.  

Real Japanese food.  Japanese waiters/waitresses and I guess Japanese cooks. The lunch special was cheap and authentic. 

Probably the best in Japan town

The environment is old style and very relaxing.  

The customers tend to be older people.  So if you are looking for a party atmosphere, this isn't it.
author: Emma C.

description:
Went to JTown for dinner @ Mifune, since my honey had a hankering (maybe addiction) for Modenyaki. We had forgotten that they are closed on Tuesday's .... oooh, so disappointing. 

http://www.yelp.com/biz/mifune-don-restaurant-san-francisco

Foraging for food near by, Takara drew us in. The lights were on, but no one was home. 

Food: "mediocure and boring" is a description by another reviewer, and it is TRUE. Nothing BAD, nothing really GOOD. Shawanmushi is for me a nice & -not- common dish, however it has devolved @ Takara.... thin on the ingredients ( where was the ginko nut?, the shrimp ?... ). It has been a valued Takara tradition, it now is a disappointing "going through the motions" dish. Not expecting culinary revelations, I had hoped for a glimmer of "that was good". Shawanmushi @ Takara is a disappointment. 

Service: While IMa very very FAR from a "new-age" - "energy" "sensitive", Takara pulled my mood down to "HO HUM", mainly due to the sad faces & demeanor of the servers. While certain that it is no fault of theirs, it affected me. Its the same faces you might see in communist countries where "workers" are conscripted.

JTown (this "mall") which includes the Mifune outlet that was mentioned above was sold a couple of a years ago, and I'm wondering if the businesses are just: "maximizing profit...hanging on..get what we can" kinda feel. The light at end of their business tunnel in clear sight ... the headlights of a massive bullet train.
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Takara is the Japanese restaurant that time forgot. Hell, it's the Japanese restaurant that the Japan Center forgot, and it's slipping from my memory as I write this review. Next to the neck massage place, it's in that semi-hidden hallway in the Miyako Mall which provides a shortcut for guests of the Hotel Kabuki. That means locals like me barely notice it in the distance unless they have a hankering for standard-issue Japanese food or need a neck massage. I'll write about the former, but somebody else can tell me how the massage place is. Jamie W. and I came here simply because it's probably the only place I had not eaten at in the entire complex. Gee, that's a lousy reason to patronize a place, but they had teriyaki on the menu and Jamie was game.

It was surprisingly popular the evening we went though not so much by my people if you know what I'm saying. Let's just say the chicken teriyaki was a popular item that night. The robust menu is eight pages long, so it's not like it was the only thing they served. This didn't stop Jamie who ordered the $16.95 Chicken Teriyaki Dinner, which came with an appetizer, miso soup, rice, savory egg custard, pickles and dessert (photo: http://bit.ly/1MODkdh). As far as I could tell, I think the accompanying salad was acting as the appetizer, and the custard was like a naked chawan-mushi bereft of any shrimp, mushrooms or any other ingredient you would expect to find in it (photo: http://bit.ly/1GC1U1L). Jamie immediately pushed it to me since he didn't like the texture. Finger-burning, yes, but blandly comforting as well.

The chicken teriyaki itself was a generous serving but rather overwhelmed by the sweet sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/1TgvQE8). I think I fared better with the $23 Two-Item Takara Dinner Set since I went for the Salmon Teriyaki and the Grilled Mackerel. Same accessories for me even, more custard for me and for some reason, the salmon didn't seem quite as overrun with the sauce much to my benefit. It was a pretty decent-size cut as well (photo: http://bit.ly/1GC1OqX). Even so, the mackerel, an unadorned as it was, turned out to be the highlight of my meal (photo: http://bit.ly/1FYcFVB). Meanwhile, Jamie was downing a mini-bottle of the Sho Chiku Bai Nigori Unfiltered Sake to counteract the sweetness of the sauce. Also he likes sake. I don't know when that started happening. Anyway, the obligatory scoop of Green Tea Ice Cream ended our meal (photo: http://bit.ly/1cQ2GKJ). What was the name of this place again?

FOOD - 3 stars....like I said, standard-issue Japanese doesn't really make this destination dining....may I suggest the mackerel?
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...speaking of standard issue though roomier than most in the Japan Center
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...a little too rushed at the beginning followed by long pauses at the end
TOTAL - 3 stars...if the Japan Center was a theatrical movie, then Takara would be the 6th sneak preview before the main feature
author: Ed U.

description:
The sushi was delicious, I ordered the Spider roll, Dragon roll and their soy sauce based Ramen. The ramen really filled me up, which was good because two rolls is usually a lot for me and it didn't fill me up at all! 

Service was the worse - of course I can understand that there weren't many staff on the floor, but  to have a party of 3 wait for 10 minutes without asking if we signed up on the waiting list is a bit absurd. I would have seen it if it was on the hostess's table or if there even was a hostess but it was on a little board scattered on the wall where they had many other papers.

After that, it took another 40 minutes, so I'll rate it 2 out of 5 because I have experienced better.
author: Marina S.

description:
Tamara has good variety but I was not blown away.

My boyfriend and I each got a dinner plate, one with grilled mackerel and one with eel. The dinner plates were $18-25 each, and with good reason considering how full I was after eating a third of my portion. Each dinner plate comes with soup, chawan mushi (steamed egg), and two other pickled side dishes. Oh and did I mention? The meal ends with complimentary ice cream :)
author: Vivian W.

description:
This is my favorite sushi place! I came here on a Thursday night and sat at the sushi bar with two of my friends. The new owner of Takara, Hiro San was very friendly and introduced us to the sushi chef, Ken. They chatted with us and were very knowledgable, giving us great recommendations. 
we started with appetizers: karaage, fried calamari, hamachi Kama, and fresh oysters. For sushi, we ordered salmon, aji, toro, red snapper, saltwater eel, yellowtail, ikura, sea urchin, sweet shrimp and scallop nigiri. We also ordered a bowl of the shoyu ramen to share. For dessert, there were 3 flavors of ice cream: chocolate, vanilla and salted caramel. (The chocolate was our favorite!) 
Everything we ordered was delicious and served beautifully, the service was fantastic and the prices are more than fair. 
My high expectations of authentic Japanese food were exceeded; I would highly recommend this place to everyone and I promise you won't be disappointed.
author: Miki A.

description: Dude sushi here is amazing! And the service is pretty good too, everyone there is super nice and the recomendations are great, love this place!!
author: Daniela Q.

description:
Not sure why there are so many haters of this place. Maybe SF has too many good sushi joints. But to me, this place is definitely a very decent sushi and ramen place to frequent. 

My Japanese hair stylist recommended it to me and my dad. She said it is one of the more authentic sushi restaurants in the area. We trusted her opinion b/c she is a Japan native not some Americanized Asian. So we went and certainly weren't disappointed at all! 

The restaurant is located inside the Japanese mall in Japan town. So you can stop to browse some interesting stores on your way there which is a plus. I love the fact that they serve both authentic ramen and sushi, two of my favorites. 

We ordered two shoyu (soy based) ramen specials that came with onigiri (rice ball) and also ordered some sushi rolls. The food was super tasty and the price was very reasonable. My dad was visiting from overseas and it was his first time having real Japanese food. He loved it! We couldn't stop talking about the food afterwards.

The following month I was in SF again, I went right back to Takara to get my ramen and sushi fix. It has now become a regular stop for me whenever I am in the city.
author: Angela F. W.

description:
If you like...

...unappetizingly fishy egg custard
...salmon teriyaki potential hindered by excessive sauce
...side salads with nice dressing but mostly just lettuce
...red bean or green tea ice cream

Then Takara is the place for you.
author: Amy C.

description:
Probably one of the worst Japanese restaurants I've been to in the city. Aaaaaaaaaaaaaandddd let the roasting commence:

As we get seated we are all given green tea without us asking, and as the bad Japanese person that I am, I don't drink hot green tea, THUS I asked for a glass of water. The waitress gladly gave me water however once my whole party asked for water as well, the SAME waitress tells us they are not allowed to give water to the whole party since everyone has green tea. 1. WE DID NOT ORDER YOUR FUQ ASS TEA. 2. WHAT RESTAURANT IS NOT ALLOWED TO GIVE WATER?!?! (I guess you have to be dying to be qualified to drink your pretentious-ass water).

The next issue I had was with the food. I ordered the lunch bento box that comes with tonkatsu (breaded pork cutlet), and tempura. The best description I can give is... OVERCOOKED OILY CRAP. The tonkatsu was so overcooked that the breading was hard and broke off in one whole piece and the meat itself was rock hard. Now addressing the tempura, order this if you love food covered and soaked in oil.

The last issue regards the fact that we got kicked out. YES, KICKED OUT. We hadn't exceeded a total of 1 hour and 15 minutes sitting there and they had the nerve to kick us out because we were taking too long.

Thank you Takara, for this wonderfully bullshit experience. The only thing you were good for was validating our parking ticket. Enjoy the rest of your time open because with service like this, y'all ain't gon be open for long

However, because this is a Japanese restaurant and I'm Japanese I'll give y'all two stars...
author: Brandon F.

description:
Japantown is where Yelp reeeally comes in handy. So many sushi spots with almost identical storefronts & menus, and nearly all of them have a 3.5 star average. What's a Yelper to do?! Welp, sometimes you just need to put down the phone and step inside.

Takara is a perfectly good option, above average actually. While the sushi was 3-stars in my book (too much rice vs. fish, too heavy on the mayo with the crab, pretty pricey), the service and ambiance were both solid 4s. I got really excited about the cubby hole/ ledge next to our table where I could stash my purse and coat. The tables are spaced out nicely and feel private, with leafy plants separating them. And our server was so polite and attentive, we felt like royalty. 

I had the Rainbow roll and Spider roll, both fine, not extraordinary. Dude man had the miso ramen with extra pork and said it was 'not the best, and not the worst he's ever had'. But, he slurped up the entire bowl, so it must have been more than OK.

Complimentary green tea comes standard, but a big bottle of Asahi is recommended :)
author: Nique F.

description:
My go-to Japanese place in jtown. They have a great selection of menu from Izakaya style dishes to sushi and udon. Generally everything is done well and the price is reasonable. 

I love their tempura. Always fried to perfection and not overly greasy. Their rolls are excellent as well.
author: Nancy Z.

description: I was wandering around Japantown, caught in a downpour with no internet service...so I found a place to eat old school style:  by walking around and following my stomach.  Takara had exactly what I was craving- saba and sashimi lunch combo.  It's a nice restaurant and I was seated quickly.  Fair prices.  I was tempted to add on fried oysters to my combo but I knew I wasn't that hungry.  The service was very friendly, food presentation was nice:  not bento box style but all on separate plates, and the food hit the spot.  Great find!
author: Lyn C.

description:
This is an authentic & reasonably priced Japanese restaurant in Japan Center.  
Their sushi, sashimi, and chirashi are fresh & yummy.

I also like their beef teriyaki, pork cutlet, salmon shioyaki, and chawanmushi (steamed egg) which comes with the combo dinner.
If you like rice, try their iron pot rice dinner.  I especially like the one with crab meat.

The servers are nice and friendly.  Five stars all the way!!
author: Miriam W.

description:
Ooh, I didn't notice the health score - 68 out of 100.  No matter, my two sisters and I had lunch here today.

Very affordable at lunch.  Lunch box $8.95. Their lunch box is a bento box elsewhere.  Choice of pork cutlet, beef teriyaki, chicken teriyaki, fried white fish, or albacore sashimi.  Shrimp and  veggie tempura, three pieces of California roll, green salad, and miso soup. A sure bargain bite. The best tempura I've had in a long time.  Fresh and the right amount of tempura flour.

Dinner menu is much more expensive. 

Given an option, come for lunch.
author: Shirley N.

description: This place is tucked away in the Japanese Mall and is an absolute gem. I had the fatty Toro, which comes slight torched on one side and it was delicious.
author: Matt T.

description:
Loved this place since my first visit to SF with the family in 2010. I moved here this year and their menu is exactly the same- along with the quality.
It doesn't taste like your typical Japanese restaurant, meaning it is not in any way american/westernized. So Some may find this place bland or boring. But it is only because it is authentic! For some reason their dishes always have this -home-made sort of taste- thumbs up! 
Everything tastes fresh. Good portions (not too small) at reasonable prices (IMO). 
Yellowtail all the way, btw.
author: Grace C.

description: Since Hiro-san took over, this place is amazing! Delicious food and awesome conversation at the sushi bar. The service is great. Chefs choice is the best choice. They have a great variety of fish. 10/10 would come again .
author: Timothy T.

description:
We were disappointed with the quality of food during our visit. Different management, perhaps. Sushi and chirashi weren't so fresh. But their tonkatsu was good. But then again, you can fry shoes and i may like it.  

Service was very, very slow.
author: Bayarea K.

description: Came here for lunch on a weekday. Super delicious chawan mushi, limited to 10 people served only. Delicious mini kitsune udon and katsu don lunch set. Very nice, attentive waitresses, too. My only issues were: 1. No A/C - I got sweaty and the fans they had were not enough for relief, even though I sat relatively close to them. 2. No parking validation under $40. I dunno, do a lot of the J-town restaurants do this? I usually forget to ask about validation...
author: Sheri G.

description:
Went here on New Years 2016 (late review, I know, and I am sorry).

The customer service was alright, but it was late at night so everyone's tired. I especially like the Amaebi and feels great drowning it down with some hot tea. Quite surprised to see they're opened that night, saving me from starvation.
author: Vincent V.

description:
I don't know the name of my waitress as she never introduced herself. The facility looked and felt dirty. The table felt like it wasn't even wiped down after the last diner. The water glass had soap grime all over it, I didn't want to drink the water. I can only guess how bad the kitchen is...

The miso soup tasted like a block of salt, for $1.95. The small bowl wasn't even filled halfway. Ordered salmon roll, salmon skin, and eel. All tasted like salty cardboard. Zero to no presentation for an order of sushi.

Come here at your own risk.
author: Steve A.

description: This place is awesome! Coming from someone who is new to seafood, their sushi was amazing! I can't stand when sushi is super fishy and this place didn't have that at all. Very authentic and quiet restaurant on the top floor of  the Japantown mall, above Daiso! The service was quick, the food was delicious, and the prices were low, so nothing but good things to say! If you go I recommend you try to fried oyster appetizer, it is small but worth every penny!
author: Halle O.

description:
This place lives up to the Yelp reviews as we both had the chicken Teriyaki lunch special which was delish! 
Traditional Japanese without the hipster attitude and mediocre food. 
Generous portions and great service as well as rock star Japanese food. Remember it starts with the food.. good food!
author: Matthew M.

description:
Ignore the high maintenance haters on this thread.  I love this place.  I've been to Japan and I feel that this is authentic Japanese comfort food. In fact, I try to eat here a few times a month! I particularly love the small sides that accompany the dinner entrees, such as chawanmushi, seaweed appetizer, takuan pickles (yellow pickled radish), etc. IMO, this place beats most of those restaurants in the "main" mall.  I've been coming to J-Town for years and tried almost all the restaurants. 

Service is professional and servers speak Japanese, which adds to the authenticity.  The restaurant itself is clean and cozy.

Items I Love:
- Chawanmushi - savory egg custard appetizer (comes with dinner entree)
- Fried oysters entree or as part of bento
- Tempura entree or as part of bento
- Various Udon Soups/Nabes
- Shoyu Ramen
author: Ana Marie L.

description:
I hate to do this but in all good conscience, I felt the need to forewarn fellow yelpers about my experience in Takara on the evening of Sept 22.

I love sukiyaki and is always looking for a good rendition. Sadly, sukiyaki has over the years lost its popularity. Recently, we tried some of Takara's nabemono (yosenabe, kamameshi) which weren't great but were at least satisfying and acceptable. We thought we do sukiyaki for a change. 

We were their first customers and a few others trickled in. Although the menu said table side cooking, we were ok when all the ingredients were already cooked in the pot. I tasted one spoonful of the broth and spitted it out. IT WAS WAAAAAAAY SALTY!!! It was so salty that even the beef and the other ingredients were like soaked in salt. I immediately flagged down my server and she took it back to the kitchen apparently to fix it. Oh yes, the redone version was sweeter but just as salty. Just by adding sugar would not take care of this. Here then was the kicker. She brought me a tall cup of hot water so I could dilute the broth. WTF? It didn't help or make any noticeable difference to the salty taste. My hunch was they were scraping the bottom of the barrel where the undissolved salt was deposited.The server insisted that that was Takara's recipe and she couldn't do anything about it...so no exchanges for another entree, no discounts, no apologies, no remorse..no nothing. She weaseled her way out by saying the owner wasn't around, there were no manager and she wasn't authorized to do sh*t. $23.50 down the toilet!

Never again TAKARA!
author: Geoff G.

description: Great spot for lunch. Took my grandma out to lunch here today. We ordered the lunch box and 3 item combo bento. It was the best chicken teriyaki and tempura I've ever tasted but beef teriyaki was a bit salty. Saba was small but I enjoyed it. A lot of options I'd like to try next time, especially the donburi and noodle combo.
author: Joyce C.

description:
This is the perfect place to come warm up on a cold SF foggy night. We were greeted at the door and seated quickly into a booth. It took a while for a waiter to come over to us, but that's fine since the menu is so long. They have a lot of sushi options, a couple of ramen choices, and a variety of udon. Two of us got the udon with beef in the miso broth (vs the seafood broth) and the other got ramen and seaweed salad. 
The portions are huge! They add a little salad to the udon dinners which was delicious. They serve it in huge iron bowls that kept everything extremely hot. Two of us could have easily shared our dinner, but hey leftovers are good too. Only complaint was that the broth still tasted very fishy. I ended up adding a lot of soy sauce to the broth which made it a lot better. The noodles were amazing and very filling. I wish there was a little more beef and vegetables in there as well. Needless to say, successful spot to get a big bowl of udon.
author: Alisha K.

description:
I didn't really expect much from here, since it's inside Japan Peace Plaza which ironically has pretty mediocre and overpriced Japanese food. But Takara actually seems pretty authentic (read: there are a significant number of Japanese people who eat there), rather than an overpriced tourist trap.

My friend and I split a grilled mackerel dinner set and a salmon avocado roll, which turned out to be the perfect amount of food at a decent price. The grilled mackerel was fatty, greasy, and delicious, yet still seemed fairly healthy in the way that only fish can be. The dinner set also comes with some fun side dishes and appetizers, which were pretty tasty. The salmon avocado roll was fresh and well-made, and paired well with our set.

Service is friendly and fast, and it seems like the staff is mostly Japanese. There's a quiet and casual vibe so it's a nice place to hang out or chat. It sounds obvious, but this is a good place to get some authentic and affordable Japanese food in Japantown.
author: Brittany C.

description: A solid 3 stars. Nothing fancy, not expensive. Just decent food when you arrive at the kabuki. The food is tasty but not incredible. Just good food at a good price. Can't complain when the cost is less than $10. Fast service, good tea, and a nice family style place.
author: Aron N.

description: So incredibly disappointing: the sushi and sashimi were not good. Tasted not so fresh. The sukiyaki was too sweet and lacked variety and vegetables. The service was mediocre. Shouldn't Japantown center restaurants have great food and great service?
author: Eric W.

description:
Solid Japanese restaurant, and it's much tastier than the places near Benihana.

Takara is located a bit off the beaten path as it's not in the main restaurant row area of Japantown. It's actually really close to the Hotel Kabuki and Daiso. My boyfriend and I decided to give this place a try for lunch on Saturday, and we weren't the only ones who were out and about! The entire front area of the restaurant was filled up when we arrived at noon, but there were still some tables in the rear area. They seated is the corner which was a bit concerning because I thought they would forget about us, but it ended up being fine.

I ordered the vegetable udon set with a mini chirashi (sashimi on top of rice), and my boyfriend had the lunch set with the fried oysters and tonkatsu. An older lady brought us both miso soup and tsukemono (pickles), and gave my boyfriend his rice. You rarely see Japanese pickles so I was super excited!! Two minutes later my chirashi arrived which was ridiculously quick, but I think it was because the sushi chefs were ready to go =) The fish was quite good and tasted fresh; I loved how they added a substantial pile of ginger, but the tamago (egg) wasn't too good. The rice underneath was vinegared which was surprising but tasty. The aforementioned miso soup had great flavor, and we also each received a cup of hot green tea without even having to ask!

My mini vegetable udon arrived before my boyfriend's food. I was still working on my chirashi and miso soup when it was placed in front of me lol. The veggies were tasty: spinach, mushrooms, various greens, and the noodles were delicious and perfectly chewy. The broth had a subtle fishy undertone which was weird when I first took a sip but it wasn't bad after awhile. My BF's tonkatsu arrived and it was perfect! The cutlet was uniformly cut and the breading was light and delicious. The fried oysters were delicious as well, but be careful when you bite into them because they are extremely hot in temperature! The side salad was a refresher after all the fried food.

The cuisine here is a lot closer to legit Japanese food than the other restaurants in the restaurant row area. I'd come back here for lunch for sure! The waiters/waitresses are quick to bring you your food, but they can take a bit longer to bring you your check. Just be patient and enjoy your tea =)
author: Sam F.

description:
Hard to find authentic Japanese food cooked by authentic Japanese nowadays. 
Takara doesn't disappoint. 

I had lunch on Saturday, barrel eating the lunch crowd mixed with locals and hotel guests (Hotel Kabuki next door). 

Miso ramen was perfectly seasoned, rich and flavorful without being overly done. Ramen, pork, egg, seaweed all good. 

I had the combo, Zaru (cold) Sobs and Katsudon which also came with miso soup and a small plate of homemade tsukemono. 

Service was great, and the green tea was oh so good. 


The reason for subtracting a star? The sauce  on my katsudon was too salty. I mostly find this too salty most places I go. But it's not how I like it. 
Sooooo... I will return and try something else. It was good, and there are more menu items I want to try.
author: brian k.

description:
Good, fast service, nice setting, good prices, great food. Very nice wait staff who work very hard to please. They do get busy. Great menu of authentic traditional Japanese comfort foods. I eat here every chance I get when I'm in town. My friends, locals, have been coming for years and still rave about it. Tempura is light and crisp. The grilled mackerel is moist and flavorful, albeit bony. The salmon is consistently cooked perfectly. Sushi is fresh, chirashi is a good value and you can't beat the special bento combinations at lunch. 
The last time I had my parking validated (for a purchase over $30) I got $2 off parking.
author: K K.

description:
Good place for sashimi/nigiri/maki -- fresh and tasty. The other japanese dishes are authentic and tasty as well, but not a whole lot of "special rolls" offered here. Regardless, the place is really good and a little more expensive than most places, but well justified.

It's a little hard to find -- it is tucked away INSIDE the shopping mall, in the heart of Japantown SF.
author: Stephanie B.

description: I have dined here at least five times and the food had always been very good---my best description would be home style Japanese cuisine.  They have an extensive menu. The restaurant is very clean and quiet and the service has always been excellent.
author: James M.

description: Freshest sashimi in San Francisco for reasonable prices! Highly recommend.
author: Kirill E.

description:
Our go-to restaurant Mifune in Japantown moved downstairs so decided to try Takara.  Everyone in the restaurant is Japanese so we knew it was authentic.  Went for the lunch bento box special $9.95.  Had the Tonkatsu which came with 3 pieces of California rolls, lots of tempura, salad, rice and miso soup.  Thought the food was tasty and plentiful.  Our new Japantown restaurant.
Mifune is now on the first floor, with a really weird menu, and completely empty for lunch.  So sad.
author: Helen H.

description: This place is old school style eat. They had fantastic choice of food according to me. Service here is awesome. Prices here are good. I was on seat very quickly. overall friendly environment.
author: Paige C.

description: This is a favorite of mine in J-Town. Their lunch specials are a great value, with most lunch sets coming in around $9.95 or $11.95. Lunch bento box sets, or donburi (Tanin don, katsu don, oyako don) with a mini noodle dish (kitsune udon, tanuki udon, zaru soba) are my goto. Great miso soup, even just the texture of the rice is especially good.
author: Kenny W.

description:
Fresh fish, plenty of UNI, many others run out of uni early in the evening.  Ramen was great too.  One of the few that have the spinach salad. 

Best of all, easy access, and on the quiet end of the Japan Center.  

This is now our family favorite for a full menu sit down option.

It is a little more expensive than our previous choice, but the food is a few steps up and the quite are so worth it.

This is the place to take out of town guests.  Skip the sword and griddle show.
author: Patrick H.

description:
Went here on a recommendation from an elderly Japanese friend.  Restaurant was average - no frills, minimal ambiance, average quality food, that is a little pricey.  Captive clientele from nearby hotel.  Where else would a traveler go if you don't have a car, don't speak the language, and want something that reminds you of home?

The restaurant fulfills the demands of clientele expecting the full gamut of Japanese cuisine:  Grilled Items, Steamed Items, Raw Items, Rolls, etc.  Although each item we ordered fell short of expectations.  

We had the Grilled Ika / Squid Appetizer which could have benefitted from more grilling to add more flavor.  The squid was fully cooked of course but lacked that grilled taste.  We also had the Miso Cod Appetizer - a properly cooked fish but overly miso'ed.  The Agadashi Tofu Appetizer was very disappointing - sauce was thick and cornstarchy with only 4 small pieces.

The 30 piece Sashimi platter was fresh with a good variety of fish...although slices could be a little bigger.  Dragon Roll was nothing special....

We ordered approximately $70 worth of food for three people - multiple appetizers, sashimi platter, sushi roll....and did not receive any complimentary soup or salad.  Definitely no frills.  Won't be going back as there are plenty of Japanese restaurants in the city that offer better quality food at comparable prices.
author: Scott L.

description: This is it, D' BEST in SAN FRANCISCO for SUSHI AND SASHIMI. It is so Fresh and delicious. The Masterchef Hiro San done a very good job on presenting the Sashimi and Sushi, and you know what, it is so delicious. It is been my 3 weeks in SF and I have been searching all over Bay Area for a good Sushi and Sashimi. I'm a foodies that like to travel and eat, so far my travelling experience in San Francisco has been satisfied by TAKARA with a Great Value. I just found out that he has flown the Fish etc from Tsukiji Japan 2 times a week. That's why it is different from those conveyer Sushi. Thank You for a such good Sashimi and Sushi.
author: Michael H.

description:
3 stars...Mainly because I love the sashimi there. Food came out consistently so it's a plus right there. Extremely filling (dinner menu). 

Now the subtraction of two stars:
1. Service is slow when it is not related to food (seating, asking for drinks, and getting our orders took at least 10 minutes). 
2. Servers that weren't in charge of certain sections were extremely helpful (kinda annoyed when you asked for them and don't help unless you call them over).

Mainly the idea is, not a bad place, but not a good place. Just don't expect the service to be good. Food is okay with exception to the sashimi.
author: Juli H.

description:
I ordered the chef's special and while the sushi itself was OK at best, the service was far from OK. My plate came half an hour after the rest of the plates at my table because they "forgot" to put in the order.

Very displeased with how they handled the mishap as well. Not only did they not offer to make up for the mistake in any way until I asked about it (at which point they only offered a 10% discount whereas most restaurants would just take it off the bill), but they also ended up including 20% gratuity on the bill which I also had to ask about.

There's plenty of places to get sushi right around the corner from here, I'd recommend trying them out first.
author: Jake C.

description:
Seated right away. Came in for the lunch special . They actually serve large portions. 
Veggie tempura was nice & lightly battered, rice nice and sticky .

Place was clean host  male , was friendly but server female , seemed annoyed and rushed.
Food was all right came out really quick.

Asahi to Sapporo biru shimasu demo Kirin shimasen.
They have Asahi & Sapporo but not Kirin beer.

I would go here again. For their other veggie rolls.
author: Lost B.

description:
Very slow to get seated, but the sushi rolls tasted great.  I got the rainbow roll which was excellent.  The Rock 'n' roll was a bit sour but still good.

Once I was seated, service was fast.
author: Niniane W.

description: Authentic Japanese restaurant. Run by the Japanese.  Simple, Pure, quality and great Value! The "egg custard" (Chawanmushi) is the best and I haven't found another Japanese with a better Chawanmushi
author: Antoine N.

description: Four of us had a superb lunch together.  The piece to resistance was the arctic char sashimi.  Incredibly good.  Between us, we had Japanese style steak (very very good, no sauces used since there was no need to hide the great flavor), Takara Chiarashi (excellent assortment of sashimi, though the rice was too vinegary), Takara Nigiri (very well presented and tasty), and an assortment of rolls, also excellent.  The prices were noticeably less that expected, but maybe that is because they can have more tables given that the only restroom is in the common area outside the restaurant.  The lineup was reasonable at noon (two parties), and service was mostly excellent.  Only missed refilling the tea.  Definitely the place to come to see how Ken can deliver sushi on par with Ginza district sushi in Tokyo.
author: Bob b.

description:
We wanted some good sushi while we were in SF and it was a Sunday. After looking through Yelp, this place was one of the highest rated that was open. We arrived around 1:30PM, they close for lunch at 2:00PM, and were promptly seated and given tea. We have a service dog and there were NO issues and they seated us with everyone else as opposed to over in a corner, which happens.

The waiter took our order and the turn around time was very quick. The food was top notch. The wait staff were attentive and made sure we had tea and made sure we were happy.  We ordered the regular chirashi, nabeyaki udon, a spicy tuna roll, an unagi roll, and a fire dragon roll.  Everything was fresh and absolutely wonderful. 

If you park in the parking garage, they will validate, but only one hour.  They are located in the 'mall' and there are plenty of great stores to explore either before or after you eat.
author: Kimberly M.

description: Nice, average, restaurant .  Good service, clean, food is fairly good; not outstanding.  If there's a long wait at one of the other better places in Japantown this is solid second choice option.
author: Naomi Y.

description: Great place for family and young kids. We are a noisy bunch and nobody seem to mind. We had a nice time and the kids and they like the standard issue Chicken Tonkasu. California rolls and Dragon rolls were pretty good so we ordered another round.  $16.95 for a dragon roll seems a bit excessive tho. Had a nice warm sake and some great green tea.  The Agadashi Tofu was a bit soggy and salty but good flavor hiding under the texture miss.
author: Mitch F.

description:
I really like this place.

Come here once in awhile and it is always great.  I often order the Unagi and some sashimi as a side.  I have tried the Ramen as well, and it's solid.  I think in comparison, the price is about the same as many of the Sushi spots around the area. so it's not a huge sticker shock.  The folks that work here are amazingly nice and friendly.  It is by far my go to place in the area.
author: Bernie C.

description: My sister and I are half- Japanese and going to Takara for dinner was like a small step back in time and into Japan. The wait staff was efficient and friendly, present but not overbearing. My sister got the saba (mackerel) dinner meal and I got the tonkatsu bento box. Both of us were really happy with our meal choices. The bento box comes with rice, miso soup, tempura (ask for all veggies if you have a shellfish allergy), and very sufficient portions inside the box. The green tea is delicious and we also had the matcha (green tea) ice cream to top the meal off. Also delicious.
author: Anna C.

description:
It is what it is

With a bunch of places to choose from in Japantown this is probably your standard, cheap Japanese food place. The food was just so-so. The servers were nice though. I wouldn't go back but when you have a hankering for Japanese food and you can't get into another place in town you can get it fulfilled here.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
I have always been apprehensive about dining in Japantown's malls as I have had two pretty traumatic experiences at Benihana and On the Bridge. Glad we stopped at Takara, I was pleasantly surprised~

In sum: super nice and accommodating  server; rainbow roll was good, tempura chicken roll was great. Draft sake was available which was also delicious and good value!
author: Button L.

description:
I'm pretty impressed. I don't usually like eating sushi at the Plaza (ironic huh) since I've had so much better sushi elsewhere. 

I ordered a bento lunch box. It came with rice, miso soup (which was a bit too salty) and the bento box. The bento box had salad, 3 california rolls, a variety of tempera and sashimi. I was really impress! The sashimi was fresh & delicious and the tempera was actually good!! It was light and airy, not overly coated and over fried. For once I actually ATE the tempera that came with the bento box! I also tried the  Teriyaki chicken that my mom got with her bento box. It was average. 

The only con was that the miso soup was a bit too salty & my cup of green tea was empty quiet often and when it got filled it was only filled 3/4 of the way. AND the waitress kept staring at one of my family members for no reason. Kinda weird/ rude. 

None the less, I'm definitely coming back again to give it a try. The place gets pretty busy so try to come right when the place opens! My family didn't have to wait in line for a seat!
author: Ruhjeenuh Z.

description:
We ate at Takara Japanese Restaurant because my first choice didn't have a table for 2 at 6pm.  

We got a table for 2 after only waiting about 3 minutes.  Menu is huge here.

I got: Yakizakana Dinner - grilled salted mackerel it comes with appetizer, rice, miso soup, savory cup of custard, pickles, & dessert $16.25.  Everything was pretty good.  Dessert was a choice of dessert - I picked green tea ice cream & it was a small scoop - he brought 2 spoons so we could share.

B. go Fried Soft Shelled Crab - he liked it.

Something else Fried - he thought was too rubbery.

Cold Tofu appetizer - 4 small cubes of cold tofu & some bonito flakes on the side.  Tasted ok.

Scallop nigiri - we liked it fine.

Ikura nigiri - we liked it fine.

Yelpers seemed to like the Lunch deals, maybe next time I'll go for that.
author: Ann L.

description: I was in J-town and wanted a sushi dinner and chose this spot.  I was seated promptly and ordered the $18.95 Nigiri Combo which comes with Miso Soup, Chawanmushi (Steamed Savory Egg Custard), and 11 piece plate (8 Nigiri pieces, 3 Maguro roll pieces).  I was very satisfied with the meal.  The Chawanmushi was really a welcome addition to my meal.  The food is solid.  Looked like there were many locals there too.  The servers were attentive and friendly as well.  I certainly wouldn't mind eating here again when I'm in the area to try more of their menu.
author: Alvin J.

description:
I guess if I could use half stars I'd go for 4.5, but since I can't I guess I'll use my elementary math skills and round up to 5 and here's why:

My grandmother is Japanese, which makes my mom 1/2 and me 1/4. That said, I'd like to think that as a family we know our Japanese food. My grandmother has been to Takara twice with me and she says they have the best udon noodles in Japan Town.   

As for me I've dined here three times. The first time I ordered nabeyaki udon which was phenomenal. I took the extra step and asked how they cook it. Apparently they actually cook it inside the cast iron bowl, which is rare these days. Most places will cook the udon in a regular stainless steel pot, then serve it in the iron bowl. I appreciate the more traditional touch and I could definitely taste the difference. This was by far the best nabeyaki udon I've had outside of visiting Japan. I've also had their sashimi, teriyaki salmon, teriyaki chicken, salmon shioyaki, tempura, and fried oysters. 

Two of the main reasons I like this place are location and culture. It's located on the other side of Japan Town and more away from the tourists and also a little more secluded.  As for culture, the servers are mostly (if not all) Japanese, and the clientele is consistently at least 1/2 Japanese. There's something to be said for an ethnic restaurant with these two characteristics because, and I'm making assumptions here, the food is more likely to be "authentic." 

I'll end with saying that this place has been busy all three times I've been so be prepared to wait. I don't think you'll be disappointed because I haven't been and I've been there three times.
author: Leo S.

description:
When it comes to sushi, I tend to separate places into two categories: casual and special. The "casual" is a place with good quality sushi at a reasonable price. That's really all it takes, and I'll be back on a fairly regular basis as long as things are kept consistent. The "special" places are much more expensive - usually in the $50 per person range, at least - but you're very much paying for quality. If I find these places, I typically won't go often, but I will make it a point to go occasionally.
Locally, I have my "casual" place already marked, though I do continually seek out new ones, both in other cities and locally. This may be my new SF casual sushi spot.
I stumbled upon it after finding other places inside this little shopping center closed on Monday. Admittedly, I came for lunch and only had two sushi items. They have a "lunch box" on their menu, which includes a choice of one entree item, miso, rice, a half California roll, salad and tempura. All this is $8.50. They have a variety of lunch specials though, including several with much more fish, for just a couple of dollars more. The entree items included teriyaki, katsu and - what I found to be the best option - albacore sashimi.
The place is set up like any other Japanese restaurant. I believe there's a sushi bar at the back, and the rooms are decorated with the typical lanterns and screens. There is a row of tables that faces the window out to the mall, which itself faces a nice garden area outside. The restroom is behind the restaurant, in another hallway.
I found it somewhat reassuring to hear the servers speaking Japanese to one another, and many of the patrons coming in speaking Japanese with the staff. It may be a bit judgmental, but I do this a lot with any sort of ethnic food, and I don't think I'm the only one who does. It's quite popular. I got there at about 11:40, and there was a wait for a table within 30 minutes.
The service was excellent. The food came out relatively quickly, and the staff were attentive. My soup and rice came out first, very quickly. I appreciated that, even though I'm white, they didn't give me a spoon for the miso, which I think is silly.
Though I know it's not "authentic sushi," I'm a sucker for a good California roll, and this was a good one. Not only that, but the sashimi was also quite good. Much better than I expected for a lunch under $10. The tempura featured a shrimp, a carrot, a zucchini, a sweet potato, and (IIRC) a mushroom, and was served with tempura sauce.
I left very satisfied. More satisfied than I'd been with a lunch in a long time. It was almost too much food, it was very cheap compared to most of San Francisco's restaurants, and the service was quick and friendly.
And that leads me to the five stars: I just can't find anything for which to knock off. It was all so good. Though it's a bit off the typical track, I would make it a point to come here next time.
author: Colin G.

description:
Avoid this place. Apparently the waitress does not have a manner. Very disappointing finding fellow Japanese with manner like ruffian. My wife was trying to have lunch and this stupid waitress scolded her for asking to be serviced. Hey, you are a waitress, so please service your customer...
Know your place!

Apparently this business does not want a business.

Good thing, she did not eat there, she might be poisoned and died...
author: Kevin C.

description:
If your going to Japan town in San Francisco and craving some great bento boxes without spending an outrageous amount of money of Japanese food then Takara might be the place for you. 

Pros:

Pricing- Definitely cheaper compared to the other larger Japanese restaurants in Japan town.  

Food Selection- They have everything from sushi rolls to bento boxes to udons to any mixture of Japanese cuisine. Definitely the Chirashi (Rice with sashimi) is one of my favorites here, because it was filled with several large fresh decadent sashimi. 

Cons:

Seating- They have limited spaces for seating and it does get packed easily on a weekend or during dinners (Like any other Japanese restaurants in Japan town) so there might be a wait getting inside the restaurant. 

Udon- Was plain and not as great as the Chirashi overall. 


Overall if you love sushi rolls than Takara might not be the restaurant for you, however if you love Japanese bento boxes then definitely give Takara a try and you won't be disappointed.
author: Lucy D.

description:
13.01.02      First Visit

Food      3 1/2 - 4 
Decor     3
Service   4
Price       $10 - $20

Nice clean and spacious environment

Basic mainstream Japanese food with some exceptions
     - Seems to be run  by real Japanese staff ...I think
     - Have some unique dishes that cannot be found in
                Chinese run Japanese restaurants
                 You will be surprised how many are out there ... no offense
                 I have tried many Japanese restaurants ... 
                          I can safely say more than 150 Japanese restaurants in the Bay Area
                                   they are either run by the following groups:
                                            Japanese, Chinese, and Korean
                 Sadly most Chinese run one are below average when compared to 
                           the run by true Japanese
                 I can understand some of the two languages except Korean
                 There is a distinction in the way Korean sounds.
        - The food is above average and cooked well
        - Salmon teriyaki was cooked perfectly ... I so hate overcooked fish


ROUGH DRAFT and will update
Will try again and try some of unique dishes
author: S.K. Y.
