description: If you want quality sushi and sashimi, this is the place. The sushi chefs are experts and knowledgeable. The restaurant has a large menu, and the entrees come with a complimentary chawan mushi. This is the real deal.
author: Debbie N.

description: Expensive mediocre place.  Nothing special really.  They supposedly serve hamachi kama, but only had one (it was taken already) when we got there this past Saturday.  Unsual agedashi tofu with a heavy sauce.  Tempura seemed to have been on a diet with those so small shrimps.  One and done here.
author: Joel M.

description:
belatedly found out via paper clippings in window that they sell japanese comfort food. had stopped reading menu when i found "lunch specials" 

eats: miso ramen + (salmon) rice ball (9.95)lunch special
-didn't get any miso soup, but didn't care
-rice ball not a rice ball but a clump of rice with salmon inside and a seaseed covering
tasting in a bland way
-miso broth very sweet and miso tasting, definitely msg enhanced.
-toppings of half of a boiled egg, bamboo, 1 chashu, seaweed
-noodle chewy, slippery texture.(probably not instant).
3 stars for good value, satisfying eats

temaki:
-many combos available for lunch, even chirashi
-service friendly, quick., checkins, tea refills.
author: Victor G.

description:
Hidden gem in J-Town. I say "hidden" because it is at the very end of the mall thing-y. The end where the old Miyako Hotel (now called something else) is. 

Their set bento box lunch is oh so oishii http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=oishi. For $7.50 you get to choose one item like your standard terriyaki chicken for instance. I got the fried fish, but if you are really hungry go for the chicken. It also comes with the standard little goodies like California roll, salad, miso soup, rice and tempura. 

The decor is pretty typical for the Japanese restaurants around here. Little cozy rectangular booths. The tea was hot and refilled quickly and the tempura was crispy, light and no oily aftertaste. 

If you spend $30 on your tab (excluding tip & tax), you get one hour of validated parking in the garage. So, lessay there are four of you, then at least you can get one hour of free parking. 

Good food and you can practice your Japanese here too!
author: Tiffany K.

description: My family has been coming here for years. I'd say this is a pretty authentic Japanese restaurant. Food is made correctly and always presented beautifully. I must commend the perfectly battered tempura!! It's the best in Japantown. I usually get the two item lunch special. Make sure you get here in time, since they close early! I always see people trying to eat here after they close for lunch. I enjoy seeing actual Japanese people eat here!, not just tourists. It just shows how authentic of a place this is.
author: Andrew V.

description:
Talk about a difference in experience from lunch and dinner! I reviewed Takara just last week and gave them a pretty decent review and rating for their lunch, but after tonight's dinner experience, I just had to update and let everyone know that Takara, in a nutshell, isn't really as great as people make it out to be.

I had a dinner planning meeting with a couple of fellow Board members this evening at Takara, and the service was just, simply put, bad. As slow as it was in the restaurant, there isn't any rationale for the unfriendly or uninviting service that we received. Our server checked in on us once for the whole night. And when she did, I almost turned to stone when she scowled at me for asking for another side of ginger for my sashimi platter. Who knew Madusa was Japanese?

The food, however, was was still good. I had the sashimi dinner platter, which comes with miso, rice, a couple of other side dishes, and dessert. it filled me up, and is definitely worth the $20.95. 

OH! I almost forgot! When we got our check, tip percentages were hand written on the bottom of the receipt... I mean, I get it. I'm a server/bartender myself, and tipping is important. but when you hand write what 15% and what 18% of my total bill on the bottom of the receipt for me... that's just tacky.

1) It's indirectly undermining my ability to do simple arithmetic, and
2) You're assuming i WOULDN'T tip you the 15-18% to begin with.

Kudos to the kitchen and sushi chefs. Kudos to the lunch staff.

BOO ON YOU dinner staff.
author: Mike N.

description:
OVERALL: the food is average, but you go here for the atmosphere and culture. 

ATMOSPHERE: This is a quiet family style restaurant with a strong traditional japanese clientele. It was a simple reminder of my days living in East Asia. The staff is very friendly and "hello-kitty" cute, meaning that they may go over and above at times but it's never boring or offensive. The only problem that I saw was that it seemed understaffed and overworked. Perhaps that was because I went at lunch time. 

MENU: full menu with a large variety of options. I got the "don katsu" bowl which was nice and simple. Not my favorite item but it is authentic E Asian cuisine, which is why I chose this restaurant. The preparation was professional and clean.
author: Gavin P.

description: Excellent food with very nice variety! We had ramen, sushi, salads, and grilled chicken. Everything was fresh and delicious. The service was prompt and cheerful. Overall, a great meal.
author: Masha B.

description: Takara's food was tasty and the choices of sake was very good!  To be amidst so many other sushi restaurants in Japantown, they have and know there is a competition to attract the customer in.  In my mind, where they have not earned my other 2 stars have to do with service.  They were short-handed last night, I thought.  2 servers served all the tables and bussed them, too.  A smile and a willingness to accommodate requests were what I needed but didn't quite get that.  It may possibly have been a not-so-good day for them.  Otherwise, food was outstanding!!
author: Chary P.

description:
Good lunch special - comfortable, nice food and actual Japanese staff - not a bad combo.

Have only been once, so far, so I can't comment too fully on the menu but Mrs G and I liked it
author: Chris G.

description:
SF conundrum: why is there only fair to middling Japanese food in SF's Japantown?

It just seems like in a foodie city like San Francisco, Japantown would have more authentic and fabulous food than is found on offer here.  After years living in San Francisco, I could never make sense of it.

Yet, there is something about traveling to Japantown with its easy underground parking, its quirky shops including great bookstore, incense and teapot shop, Hello Kitty store, Cherry Blossom festival and Japanese paper goods store, that keeps us inexplicably coming back over and over again.

So if you find yourself vering to Japantown's Kintetsu Mall, then Takara with its bento boxes, tasty food and access to Japantown is a very solid lunch choice.  Its one of only a handful of good restaurants in Japantown (Maki, Ino Sushi and Sophie's Crepes are your best choices.) At lunch, Takara is particularly affordable (not so much at dinner) and worth a visit, although service is often spotty  --sometimes brisk, always overwhelmed and plates are typically not cleared until after you pay your bill.

Takara lunch boxes and bento boxes are pretty darn tasty, fun for kids, and an incredible deal, considering maybe you may want to save your pennies for some other great momentos, artwork or anime.
author: Rachel H.

description:
Come for the food, not so much for the service (from the kitchen).

I've been a customer for years and two things have been consistent, even under new management/ownership - the food has been consistently good but the service (from the kitchen) needs some work.

I come here because the menu offers a variety of dishes I don't often see, as it goes beyond your typical bento boxes and sushi found at many Japanese restaurants these days.  Yes, Takara does offer those items, but also has rice, noodle, nabe (hot pot) and soup dishes along with grilled and fried items.  Most of the dishes come with miso soup, pickles, appetizer, rice, dessert and my favorite, chawanmushi, a steamed egg custard with bits of vegetables and chicken or fishcake.  I do enjoy the quality of the food and find the portion sizes to be more than generous.  This establishment is Japanese owned and reminds me of some of the meals I experienced in Japan.  

The service (not the wait staff) has always been an issue for me here.  Dishes are not always ready at the same time.  On this latest visit my dish, the Yosenabe (seafood, meat and vegetables cooked in a broth), arrived about 10 minutes after all the other main course arrived.  On prior visits the dishes either took a long time to arrive or they arrived at separate times. The waitstaff does a great job of checking in and letting us know that the missing dish(es) are coming, which I very much appreciate.  In most cases, this really isn't much of an issue but I have noticed that this happens fairly often.  I guess I'm willing to overlook this as I keep coming back to enjoy their food.  

The restaurant does fill up, but mostly after 7 pm.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Excellent sushi and sashimi, best gyoza I've had outside of Boston's Chinatown. My friend liked her soup, hated her plum wine. 

We had a short wait as a walk-in. 15 minutes. The waiter was also really great about charging our phones for us as we ate.
author: Ana R.

description: This is one of few Japanese restaurant that is a traditional Japanese restaurant that is left in Japantown.  The food was delicious and they validate parking which is a plus.
author: Raymond L.

description:
There are so many restaurants in Japantown; it can be overwhelming to choose the one that is going to satisfy your taste buds.  Anyway, we came here during the Annual Cherry Blossom Festival and found this place as a recommendation from a shop owner.  

   The food is typical of any Japanese establishment; nothing surprising or unique.  We found the ambiance somewhat boring and not engaging at all.  I ordered their lunchbox and their spicy tuna roll.  My sister ordered their sashimi meal.  Their servings were small; something that we were not used to compared to 
Vancouver, BC.  The fish was tender but the flavors were boring.  Overall, we were satisfied with the food but were not taken away by the food like at other places.  A little more creativity would go a long way for this place given that it is located in the neat Japan Centre of Peace Plaza.

I would only recommend this place if you were not looking for any surprises and had a happily unadventurous taste palate.
author: Nancy S.

description: We usually go there for lunch. Great service. Food comes quickly as a Japanese restaurant. Also everything is pretty descent, tasty, and authentic. Real Japanese food restaurant, owned and run by Japanese. NOT fake. Have to say rice is very good comparing other Japanese restaurants. Pricing is reasonable if you go for lunch.
author: Masako M.

description: Came here for lunch on a weekend and only had to wait for a few minutes.  The food was just average, but it was a pretty good value for quantity and price.
author: Simon L.

description: Delicious Japanese food! Authentic Japanese food and the service was fast! Our server Rieko was great and friendly. Overall I would highly recommend this Japanese restaurant.
author: Product S.

description: every type of nigiri sushi i requested they were out of. with no one inside their empty restaurant. the korean waitress just kept saying they were out.
author: Dean N.

description: Ventured out in Japan Town and stumbled upon this place for lunch. We ordered teriyaki chicken bento box and a beef teriyaki bento box. Big portion for a measly $8ish dollars. The tempura was light and crisp. My criticism is the teriyaki sauce is a little salty but its not so bad once you eat it with a lot of rice. The rice itself was not up to par with Japanese rice but over all good meal for a good price. For those of you on a budget but want good food, check this place out.
author: Julie C.

description: One of my favorite Japanese places in the city. The food is always spot on, prices are decent, and it's in a quiet corner of the less frequented Japantown building. I love having lunch here, then browsing the shops nearby. Their dinner prices are a bit higher, but their chawanmushi is the best (only served during dinner). I'm giving only 4 stars because service is not the best - they are not very attentive or friendly. You may have to ask several times for items and flag down your waiter.
author: Susan T.

description:
It was before 11:30am and already, there were at least 10 elderly Japanese couples waiting outside to eat. We stopped by to ask what was so special about this place and one of the ladies mentioned "chirashi", which is essentially a bowl of sushi rice with sashimi and other delicious things, served in a box.

Incredible! I ordered a regular chirashi and the sashimi was very fresh. The rest of the table ordered combination lunches and thought it was decent, just average. Will definitely come back for the chirashi, but nothing else.
author: Kevin L.

description:
First time at Takara. To make it short: inattentive waiters who don't smile, average food. We had the lunch box and I would not order that one again. Looking at the menu I find the prices above average. Not a good value they deliver.
I would not recommend Takara to a friend.
author: Guido W.

description:
Tried the salmon teriyaki for lunch. Fish was small portion and undercooked.  Service was so-so.--Very non chalant and  indifferent. 
Too many choices in Nihonmachi. Will not go back.
author: Swami L.

description: Good selection of fish from Japan. The new owner is dedicated to good Japanese food. Rice is a bit too loose but overall quality is good. I have been there a few times, this time I feel it is comparable to Japan. Recommend to try.
author: GL1687 S.

description: Looking for good, authentic Japanese food in Japantown?  Look no further.  You know it's the real deal when you see menu items like chawan mushi, sake chazuke & ume onigiri.  Eating those items takes me back to the time I spent in Japan as a child.  This is one of just a couple of Japanese-owned eateries in the area.  I hope this place stays in business forever.  I don't see how it doesn't have a 4.5+ Yelp rating!
author: D N.

description:
During our trip to San Francisco, my husband and I ventured over to Japantown to do some touristy things. We eventually needed to recharge and refuel with some food and beverages so we wandered around the Peace Plaza in search for a good Japanese restaurant.

In the Peace Plaza, we noticed that our Japanese restaurant selections were very limited for lunch as the majority of them did not open until dinner service. We came across Takara as being the only one opened in the East Mall of Japan Center.

I remember the restaurant having typical diner decor, nothing really stood out in terms of style or decoration. The place was fairly small and very busy. The atmosphere was very casual - a mix of tourists and residents. We were greeted and seated immediately by staff and the waitress took our orders right away. The food came quickly and the waitress was very attentive to our table, refilling our drinks and taking away our courses as we finished them. The food was average. I had the Katsu Don lunch and there wasn't anything spectacular about it. It was good but not the best I ever had. The portion size was also very good and filled me up right up until dinner.

Overall, my experience at this restaurant was ok. if you are in the neighbourhood and are looking for a place to eat (particularly a Japanese restaurant) during lunch I would recommend this place. The food is okay and you get a decent amount of food for the price you pay... plus I think it is one of the few restaurants open nearby during lunch.
author: Kat M.

description:
So I was fully prepared for the standard J-Center disappointed and expensive review.

But gotta say they hit it on the nose here at Takara. 

The menu was impressive and that old newspaper article on the window hits it on the nose. Authentic japanese food here without hype without fads. My review might be a little biast just because I finally found a place that does actual shio yakitori and the waiter understood what that meant 3 star dish! They also rock out a decent +1 point maguro yamakake - yea its small, but its under appetizer so anyone who expects more needs to get real. Got a nice quail egg in addiiton to some nice pieces of ahi in there. only thing they didn't have was a shiso...3.5 star dish. Had the Wafu steak ( aka daikon steak) 3.5 stars, was not impressed, but the dish was in line with my expectations and ordered mostly to make sure that I was full. They have some nice Jazz playing and a very nice sushi bar. Atmosphere is comfortably casual and you can have a decent conversation there. 

Honestly a 3.5 denotes bad food or something was wrong, but nothing was wrong and the food was decent, so I'll say 4 stars just because they didn't do anything worth degrading the restaurant. Will I come back? Yes. This week, month? No, maybe.
author: Garrett N.

description:
Unfortunately, most of the Japanese restaurants in Japantown are mediocre. Somewhat contradictory considering it is Japantown...

After a lot of debate between the other 3.5 rated restaurants in the area, we finally decided to head over here since they had a lot of combo options for dinner. 

We got the nigiri sushi combo and the tonkatsu dinner. The sushi wasn't bad -- better than kaiten-zushi but nothing to write home about. The tonkatsu was crispy but the meat was pretty tough. It did come with A LOT of tonkatsu so I guess that's a plus. 

The meal comes with egg custard which I thought was a nice addition to the meal. I just wish the meal had come with ice cream. 

Overall, not bad but not great. At least I know this place is decent enough to eat at again if I find myself stuck in Japantown with a hungry belly.
author: Chantelle T.

description:
I am glad that there is a lot of support and love towards J-Town, but let's face it, with a few exceptions, most of the Japanese restaurants in the malls are mediocre and boring.  Mifune (http://www.yelp.com/biz/KlpSebgoBXJ1PXJ6P9hyew), Kushi Tsuru (http://www.yelp.com/biz/gn5poUrTw5grzKhwNy_3pg), Osakaya (http://www.yelp.com/biz/LPbxqvHlctFiYsfZTx3YrQ), and on and on.  Many places depend on packaged/frozen food and use lots of chemicals (MSG).  I leave these places thinking dishes could be made better at home (Koremoka, Aremoka, Aremademo!).

I understand that Takara has had its glory days, but the condition in 2007 is much like most of the restaurants in J-Town - very average.  Don't get me wrong, I am not saying this place is bad.  Yes, food is authentic.  Yes, Japanese people work there.  Yes, dishes are done right.  BUT, I just don't get the vibe to want to go back here again and again.   

PRICES:  They have a really nice $7 lunch deal!

SEATS:  Fairly spacious.  

HOW TO FIND:  Located in Miyako Mall near Miyako Hotel of Japantown.
author: トモ T.

description: I'm in Japantown all the time, and also in the mall there all the time, but I usually never go to this building. And now I have a reason to go. Takara is tucked away next to the Kabuki Hotel and is a really good place for a good meal. My husband and I both had the Chirashi Lunch which came with a good portion of fish, as well as miso. It also came out in about 5min. The staff are efficient and friendly. I have a feeling I'll be returning to this place often.
author: Mariko F.

description:
I was planning to go to Sophie's Crepes after eating here because I've been craving for green tea ice cream for weeks. Little did I know that they will serve green tea Ice cream after the dinner combo and that was all I was craving for, so I had to pass Sophie's.

Service crew were very nice, although it seemed like there were only 3 wait staff at 6pm on a Sunday. That sort of slowed them down.

Sashimi- Very good! Awesome! I'm speechless.
Everything else that we ordered- beef teriyaki, pork tonkatsu, etc. were all good! Everything was fresh and tasted the way they should.

Next time, I promise to try out their rolls! The food of the couple beside us looked really yummy.
author: Christian R.

description: Love this place. Always a destination when I am in SF and looking for a great Japanese Lunch.
author: Maureen S.

description:
Food was ok. But...

A waitress stopped my friends and I outside the restaurant after we ate and demanded a bigger tip because we had tipped about 10%. She explained the California law of tipping 15% for dinner as if we were clueless, and we simply obliged to give her the extra $2 she was demanding. I'm sorry we undertipped because we're broke teenagers, but I'm not sorry for the one star review. It was rude and unpleasent, and that waittress lost the business of myself and my friends, who happened to be regular customers.
author: Christopher G.

description:
Their rolls tend to be on the smaller side compared to god-knows-how-many Japanese restaurants I've been to. Japantown is one of my favorite spots to hang out whenever I'm in SF, especially when it comes to food. But, come on, for the price you're paying, you'd expect a bit more. Luckily, my friend didn't want his miso soup that went along with his veggie tempura plate, so I took it. Delish.

Two words: tourist trap.

Went to Belly Good creperie close by and my tummy was happy again.
author: Erin H.

description: Walked into this place holding my girlfriends hand (I am also a girl). Put my name down for the wait list, waited ten minutes, and then the the male host came up to me after seating another straight couple, and said "we are busy and there aren't any seats for you. I don't think we can serve you." Seriously? Homophobes in San Francisco in 2014?!!
author: Bernadette D.

description:
The 3 top sushi restaurants in Japantown I mentioned are dinner only and unfortunately the best sushi bars are usually dinner only.  If you want a sushi restaurant that also serves sushi during lunch hours with a Japanese staff with good service and decent sushi in Japantown then I would recommend Takara.

OPEN AT 11:30AM 7 DAYS A WEEK .  I remember the sushi being good enough (did not smell fishy, taste defrosted, or hurt my stomach).  Their health score being 90 out of 100 is good in general however for handling raw fish that sounds more borderline.  Not the best sushi in Japantown, but reasonable ESPECIALLY COMPARED TO MOST OTHER PHONY SUSHI RESTAURANTS IN SF J-TOWN, but not including the 3 other good sushi restaurants I mentioned in J-Town.

IF YOUR LOOKING FOR A DECENT SUSHI RESTAURANT IN JAPANTOWN SAN FRANCISCO OPEN 7 DAYS A WEEK SERVING LUNCH AND DINNER THEN TAKARA IS THE PLACE.
author: Rudi A.

description: Wow the rudeness. Never happened anywhere else but on a 138 post tax bill, we left 21$ tip with coins then had an ice cream for 2.7$ so the in the end we were exactly at 15% of the pretax bill. Yes, we didn't use a calculator, yes we didn't leave a 50% tip like they might have wished. Multiple waiters took turns to come back after leaving the money to see if we left the right amount and the last one made a huge "oh WOW" to make sure we were thoroughly disgusted when we're leaving.
author: Xiao Y.

description: This sushi place is decent. Nothing special--just normal sushi you would expect anywhere else. Price isn't cheap either. Nothing wrong with the place, but probably won't go back again since there are so many other Japanese restaurants to choose from in the area.
author: Henry L.

description:
This review update is for the miso ramen I had here for lunch this past week. I understand ramen is not supposed to be their specialty still. Still I say the soup base is the worst I ever experienced for Japanese miso ramen. It was so thin to the point where I felt it was almost disgusting. Never again will I order that. I admit it wasn't my choice but the lunch menu didn't have the ochazuke that I enjoy here and wanted, and therefore had to opt for the ramen.

On top of that, customer service is spotty with inconsistent attitudes (more often poor than not in my opinion). However, since from time to time I'll crave for their ochazuke I will return, just not at lunchtime anymore.
author: H K.

description:
I came here again about three weeks ago and ordered the regular chirashi at lunchtime, which I've had before. I was really pleased with Takara on my previous visits, and it had become my favorite sashimi restaurant.  I came in from Sacramento to eat here.

I have to downgrade my rating because the sashimi was SO disappointing this visit. The presentation and quality of the fish was just awful compared to what it was before.  The fish was cut sloppily and seemed thrown in the chirashi box. All of the elements (fish, shiso garnish, etc) were there, but there was no care for how it looked - it was just hunks of meat in a box. Takara, did you get a new sushi chef?  What happened?  I'm so sad.

The quality of the tuna (maguro) was the most disappointing.  The texture was mealy and crumbly - marginally better quality than what you would get with sushi at an American supermarket or an all you can eat pan-Asian buffet.  Ick. The other fish were just ok, but what I would expect from a $10 chirashi instead of the $17 we paid.  None of the fish, except for the salmon (sake), which is super fatty anyway, had that "melt in your mouth" quality that I looked forward to with the sashimi at Takara.

To be fair, the ebi and the tamago were pretty good still, and the tako was cooked nicely as usual (tender, not horrible and rubbery like at most places).

My aunt said that sashimi is out of season, so maybe I should cut Takara some slack, but it doesn't explain the crappy presentation of the food. Also, if the food continues to be this mediocre, then the so-so service needs to improve to make up for it (waitress from Japan with blond hair - I'm talking about you).  I should saved some money and gotten sashimi at Nijiya Market this time. :(
author: Lisa M.

description: Food was reasonable.  Interior felt a little "tired" from lots of traffic.  4 different sushi rolls were all nicely prepared and tasted fresh.  Teriyaki chicken was average.  Tempura and gyoza were both pretty good.  Udon was also good.  I would put this in the "good/relaible" category.  Not likely to disappont, but also not anything to gush over.  I would definitely eat here again, however.
author: Lewis C.

description:
For years Takara has been my go-to place for Japanese food in J-Town. It's not high concept, style de jour, or artsy Japanese food, but rather sort of home-style, one level above okazu Japanese comfort food, with nice little flourishes like the little bowl of chawanmushi (the savory egg custard that Venerable Mom used to make you when you were sick which showed you how much Venerable Mom loved you) served at the start of the meal.

And the entrees at tonight's meal were all competently prepared from quality ingredients with Venerable Mom's tempura being crisp and grease free with a generous quantity of shrimp, Shorty's unajyu having a generous portion of first-rate unagi, and my taramiso having the requisite scorching and not being excessively salty.

What cost the place a star and actually makes us wonder whether we need to start looking for a new "old reliable" is the indifferent chaotic service.
- Venerable Mom's Tempura was dumped on the table at the same time we received our chawanmushi and before the misoshiru or salad were served. 
- The waiter dropped a spoon into tempura dipping sauce, disappeared for an extended period before returning with another spoon and never getting around to wiping up the splashed sauce.
- The waiter dropped the check off at the table and disappeared before returning and asking if we wanted the included-in-the-meal ice cream or anything else.

There were plenty of empty tables so it wasn't like they were overworked or stretched too thin. Perhaps we missed the memo regarding finding somewhere else to eat.
author: Ed T.

description:
When I asked my Japanese hair stylist for AUTHENTIC Japanese restaurant, Takara was the only one he recommended in Japantown, and also in SF too. 

The server showed us to our seat with warm towels to wipe our hands. Authentic, check! 

I got Yakizakana dinner - grilled salted salmon. The salmon was well seasoned. Not too salty. Good taste. The rice covered with a lid to keep it warm. The miso soup, salad and dressing were all good. But what really made me happy were the small bowl of chawamushi  (savory cup of custard) and takuan (the yellow pickle). Can't remember when was the last time I saw these two guys in a dinner set in SF, probably never. Overall everything was well-balanced seasoned and well prepared. I'll definitely go back again and try something else. 5 stars for the food. Authentic, check! 

The service was OK. The servers were very polite but they were too busy. We have to wait several minutes to get my server. So I minus 1 star here. I saw two customers waiting at the door at around 6:30p in Monday evening. One waited for about 5 minutes, no one came to take her to the seat, and she left. The other one waited for 10 minutes, the same result. Then I started to see people lining up. So you'd better come early, or prepare to wait in the line.
author: V L.

description:
I've experienced a LOT better. I instantly knew the sushi wasn't going to taste good when I saw the ginger was fluorescent pink (not the "true" cream color it should be). The lunch was relatively expensive and the options were quite obtuse. Like, I couldn't order any lunchtime combinations with maki rolls. I found that a bit weird. My meal was miso soup, 5 pieces of nigiri, and a side order of spider roll. 

The nigiri was decent; it wasn't horrible by any standards but again, the ginger was poor. The spider roll was the worst excuse for a sushi roll I have ever seen and tasted. The individual parts of the roll were so large I literally could not fit each piece into my mouth in one bite. The roll had two layers of rice. TWO LAYERS! Nothing of substance was stuffed in the middle either.

 I liked how the restaurant brought around green tea constantly; that was nice.

In short, there are much better sushi restaurants in Japan Town; I wouldn't come back again. $50 for shitty lunchtime sushi just doesn't make sense to me.
author: Tommy C.

description:
ANOTHER JAPANESE DISAPPOINTMNET

My GF and I had lunch here 10 January 2014.  She picked it out.  I wish she had picked another.

Lately the Japanese restaurants here in SF have dropped with a THUD......UGGGGG

Talk about slow and unconcerned wait service, they have it here.  It seems they are on
slow mo and uncaring about patrons.

While ordering I asked about the Chirashi, he assured me it was substantial.  What arrived was in a box that was about 4x6, NOT SUBSTANTIAL and totally overpriced.
I ordered the dinner size and it was 5x7!!!!  I told him not to have the ebi, "desiccated", shrimp on it (it is supposed to be FRESH).  It is the most overrated item in sushi joints.

The Chirashi was mediocre and the finger and wasbi portions were miniscule.  Edible and Could fulfill hunger but NOT SATISFY with FLAVOR and QUALITY.......
Another meal disappointment.

My GF ordered a rice noodle bowl with beef and she was NOT HAPPY. The beef looked diizzzgustung as it looked like dark, mangy mystery meat.  You could see the
connective tissue and fat, gross.  She complained to me about it and wouldn't tell the waiter.  It was not a pretty picture but she wouldn't complain.  I DO NOT SUFFER
H O R R I B L E   FOOD GLADLY.  She had an unhappy experience.

We left disappointed, later she ate some really bad French fries at a hipster joint.

OBVIOUSLY she put TAKAHARA on the DON'T EAT LIST!  

TAKAHARA will NEVER be on MY LIST!!!!!!

Why oh why is Japanese food so bad in SD?
author: ELINOR H.

description: Not sure why some people are so critical about this place.  I've been going to this place for 10+ years and they have been consistently good.  Its reasonably priced....for San Francisco.  I like their combo bentos and their shabu shabu is good too. While its not the best Japanese restaurant in San Francisco, it's a good place to go after shopping in J-town. I've never been disappointed here.
author: Ryan Y.

description: Pretty good food. I LOVE udon. My boyfriend took me here when we visited Japantown. That was my first time ever trying udon so I got something basic with meat. The restaurant itself is quiet and not too loud. Would come here again.
author: Eliana D.

description: I was introduced to this gem a few years ago by my cousin. I'm obsessed with their salmon and salmon roe porridge. It is a huge portion that comes in a mini cauldron, but I never share because I want the leftovers for myself   The only downside is that they don't serve the porridge during lunch hours. But I will make specific trips into SF from the Peninsula just to eat there. I haven't tried everything else on the menu, but what I have tried is delicious!
author: Heather C.

description: That is exactly what it is..Meh. I've had it better. The food was pretty good. I ordered rice bowl dish with hot noodle set and it was very filling for $10, and that's a very reasonable deal in Japantown, I thought.. The sushi rolls was good too. However the waitress with long dark hair needs some improvements in her service. She has tried to take away my friends' dish while she was still working on it!! and when we stopped her, she made some kind of a rude facial expression!! whoa.. be professional. We might come back though for the food only to hope we get a better service next time.
author: Melinda H.

description:
Found muh way here one weekend afternoon of the big snazzy Cherry Blossom Festival... so there were quite a few peeps in this place... but nothing super jammed packed... but I guess jammed packed up enough that they ran out of water glasses and told us that they couldn't provide us with water because they ran out of water glasses and couldn't even you know, use a different type of glass/cup in their restaurant to give us water.... we were just a small party of 3, too.

Meh.  Food was good though.
author: Ravo Y.

description:
Good sashimi slices (nice and thick)- fresh! 
AND offers chawamushi (steamed egg) with my meals. Delish! 
Kinda pricey for what it is but still tasty compared to the other Japanese restaurants there. 
Pretty good portions!

Grilled mackerel was delish also!
author: Helen Y.

description: Went here for a take out lunch after I had been craving donburi and happened to be in Japantown after an eye appointment.  Ordered the shrimp tempura donburi which came with miso soup and cost about $9.  The tempura was a little soggy, but I blame that on the 20 minute drive home, but the flavors were there and the veggie selection was good.  Can't wait to get this again!
author: Sara R.

description:
All 3 of us had the katsu curry.
Good- not oily or too fatty.

Service was pretty quick. They have good lunch specials.
Lots of food.

Funny conversation at the table to the left of us. Some geeks speaking clingon or something.
author: Ash R.

description: Its the truth that many Japanese restaurant in J town are opened by Chinese and it is hard  to find the one that is truly owned by Japanese and that is the reason why I have been coming here for many years. The price is high to be honest but you do get what you pay for and that is real, quality Japanese food. I think many people in SF are used to the "fake" Japanese food, how about try it once and then decide whether you want to stick with the Chinese Japanese style or the real one.... I really like the lunch set menu as well as the sushi, the spider roll and dragon are great and for dinner I always liked the sukiyaki. Like i said try it once and you will see.
author: William C.

description:
Had the most horrible waitress experience in my life and that's saying a lot! In fact it prompted me to write my first review!!! I've eaten at many restaurants from hole in the walls to the French Laundry and consider myself a foodie in what I hope is the best sense of the word. 

My 5 year old daughter started playing with the soy sauce and immediately upon my noticing I told her to stop. Not more than a second later the waitress, her name is Yuki, ran over and literally took the soy sauce bottle right out of her hand looking upset and not saying anything and put it at the next table. Needless to say we were very upset and left as soon as we signed the check.  How dare they treat us that way.  Such rude, awful service!!!  The waitress should be fired.  Too bad because the food was above average. I will never return!!!!
author: Justeen A.

description:
Attracted by the bento box compliments, I tried Takara for lunch.  The place was pretty full, a good sign.  I ordered a two-item bento box which came with a bowl of miso soup and two sushi rolls to share.   The soup was really tasty!  When I got the box, the food was hot and plentiful.  However...I didn't really taste a huge difference with the other Japanese places around.  It was just OK.  Good but not outstanding.  The rolls were the same.  Not bad but not outstanding.  
Parking is easy in the pay lot.
author: Pablo R.

description:
Came here yesterday with Monica Y. for our post-finals stress relief. We ordered the lunch nigiri (which came miso soup), salmon and avocado roll, spicy scallop roll, and yellowtail and green onion roll. Everything tasted really good and fresh. My only gripe - and it's enough to make me not really want to come back - is that the portions are so tiny. I wish we could have ordered MOARR without breaking the bank. But I suppose all sushi restaurants in SF are more or less like that. 

The service was great. They came to pour more tea for us multiple times. The waitress wore a lot of perfume, though.
author: Jamie C.

description: This place has really good Japanese food. It appears and tasted authentic enough. My friend and I arrived on a Friday night and fortunately there was a spot for 2. The service was okay. It took a while for them to refill our tea and water. We both ordered a dinner set. It came out nice with side dishes. Everything tasted good. I will come back again to try other dishes.
author: Allan W.

description:
Not even give me water.

It takes forever take a ordrr and food coming afyer 40m 

Wasting time
author: Vincent K.

description:
To find a good sushi in Japan is checking the sushi chef's fingers.
If his fingers are all pink fingers, it's clean and his sushi is good.

Would you eat sushi if sushi-chef has dirty fingers? 
It doesn't matter, because they just ware plastic gloves to make jiveassrolls. 
I don't eat it if I see plastic gloves to make jiveassrolls. 
Well, I don't order jiveassrolls to begin with. So why bother?

I always check fingers 1st. It's easy to see because all "Good" Sushi-Chef has clean Pink fingers. Yes, they do have "Pink" fingers. Pink finger sounds Pig but I am talking about good sushi chef. They don't have black finger nails.

85. 
The score from SF Health Dept.
That's too low for Sushi Bar. 85 is like a dirty fingers Sushi-Chef.

I came here this after noon.
It was not bad at all. The new lunch menu was pretty good actually.
10 bucks Mini Donburi + Mini Noodle combo is a good idea.
It says Mini but it was ... medium size bowl, to me, it wasn't too small that I was expecting.
I had the combo with Kitsune Udon + Chirashi Don.
I like the Kitsune Udon because the noodle was good al dente and the broth was also good, and the Chirashi, 1 large slice each of Aka-Maguro, Hirame and fresh salmon plus 2 slices of Tamago-Yaki plus one Shiso leaf (Perilla) with a little bit of Kaiware-daikon (sprouts of daikon-radish)
It was $10.50 that I think it was good deal for lunch.

Do you still have to eat Bento-Box? I hate Bento-Box. I absolutely hate it because one reason. That is very disgusting that they keep left overs and use them for next orders, items like cal-roll, especially for non-Japanese customer include Black, White, Latino and other Asians.
Let me be honest, how many Black, Latino and other Asian people go for sushi? Still pretty rare, isn't it?
I think they still prefer going Chinese in stead of going Japanese because it's cooked.  
I have seen a sushi-chef who totally dis liked a Black man sitting front of him. It was very very uncomfortable situation I was in because the black man was with me. 
I have to tell you that some Japanese are still very racist like some whites.
Some Asian called me resist only because I wrote 1 star reviews for Chinese own Sushi bars. That's pathetic because bad sushi is bad, no matter who is making. It just happened to be most Chinese sushi bars, and in general, they were not really good as they think.
And most of all, they just don't like to get called as "Chinese Sushi". 
I don't get it. What's wrong with "Chinese sushi"? Nothing!
What's up with that? I just found it's no good. That's all.
I think they should be proud of been called Chinese Sushi if it's good as The Jiro. Ha! 
I know that's never ever going to happen.
Well, I think they can be good as Nobu in NY. But I don't think the Nobu is good as The Jiro.

Btw, Just wondering, even though I am tired watching Iron Chef America, but why there is No Chinese Iron Chef yet? They should have.
 
Btw, about Takara.
The 10 bucks Donburi-Lunch combo, 4 star
The decor, table, chairs, carpet, 2.5 star
The service was not bad may be because I spoke them Japanese, 3.5 star
85 is still low for sushi, 2 star

Total 3.4 star.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I can't speak for anyone else but there is nothing not too like about our visit.  We are pretty picky sushi eaters and the quality here is exquisite.  Extremely fresh sushi.  Even the other dishes were extremely good.  The Salmon teriyaki which is forgettable at most Japanese restaurants was very well prepared and not overcooked like so many places do.

The only reason for not giving 5 stars is that the ambience is not that of a 5 star restaurant.  So if you are looking for a place to impress your fiance to pop the question, this is not the place.  To take your girlfriend or wife who enjoys succulent Sushi without breaking the bank, this is the place to go.
author: Mak C.

description: We've eaten at the sushi bar a few times and we've never been disappointed (it probably helped that we always went with our Japanese friend who is a regular at this place).    What they lack in ambiance they make up for in food.  Not a bad trade off if you'll ask me.
author: Janice T.

description:
I had the Katsudon Lunch and my boyfriend had the one that had grilled salmon. He thought the salmon was good, and I thought my breaded cutlet was fine too. Lots of salad to accompany them, and good rice (unlike gross and mushy rice from May's Cafe). He also ordered a spicy tuna roll to share, and was quite interesting to taste. I would have wanted to try a different roll, so I will probably go back to try them!

The patrons were a mix of elderly Japanese couples, middle-aged Chinese moms, and younger Caucasian couples. Basically, it looked like a place for smaller groups but I would prefer to come with a larger group next time.
author: Jessica F.

description:
I don't go to J-Town as much as when i lived 5 blocks away, now I am 35 miles away, so I had never been to this place before, but had been to many others in the area. 

The nice thing about this place is that all the people working were Japanese, although most of the patrons were not. So there is always some comfort for me to know there is real Japanese influence, rather than so many Korean and Chinese owned Japanese restaurants in the city. I was afraid that it was Korean owned, because I saw the long list of sushi rolls in the front of the menu, usually a dead give-away. But nowadays, many middle of the road Japanese restaurants have to  offer a lot of rolls because most Americans or younger American born Asian customers expect it. If they travelled to Japan, they would be disappointed. It is so much easier to mask old fish in a roll with Jack-in-the-Box secret sauce dripping all over it's tempura fried ingredients than to serve fresh sashimi or nigiri to Americans.  

We came and just got a bento dinner combo. The food was decent. I had Sashimi, Tempura, and Saba Shioyaki (mackerel) combo ($26.50, and the Favorite Relative had a double barreled Teriyaki, beef and chicken ($22.50). They were not served in a big bento tray, but in separate dishes, which I prefer, but is not as easy for the restaurant to serve and clean up.  It was a Friday night, so the service was a little slow from the kitchen and a bit hectic out front.

The combo dinner came with the 2 pickled tsukemono dishes, a covered bowl of rice, miso soup, and ice cream for dessert. The nice extra was the Chawan Mushi, which is unusual for most places to serve, and gives you another idea this is more Japanese than your average Japanese restaurant, which isn't necessarily Japanese anymore. Chawan Mushi is a light, hot, egg custard served here in a large tea cup (often with a hat on it). This one had sliced pieces of kamaboko (fish cake) and shiitake mushrooms and other goodies. This was nice comfort food, tasty and satisfying. 

The restaurant is on the eastern hotel end, near the Daiso end of the mall. So what you didn't save on dinner, you could save on Japanese Tchotchkes made in China at Daiso.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
The Sashimi's are amazing! Im a sashimi fan and definitely very particular especially on the freshness of my sashimi's. The price is reasonable, the staff are personable...I love it. The food is amazing especially the chawanmushi. 

I wished I had more friends who loves japanese food as much as me. Im gonna come back for sure!
author: Rachel L.

description: Came here for lunch recommended by local person.  Had the tempura hot udon : nice good and simple. Very popular place .
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
I have often bemoaned the lack of a real, authentic Japanese place in JTOWN. Don't get me wrong, all you JTOWN lovers out there, but let's keep it real..most of the places to eat inside the mall are run by Chinese folk. they are about as japanese as my blow up doll collection, and just as fake. but lo and behold...one day I decide to go into the "other' mall...and found this very charming place right near the entrance to the Hotel Kabuki. The banner on the front of the place says" authentic" so I went inside and was immediately greeted by cute Japanese waitresses with bad english. I knew i was home. 

Hey, being honest, in Japan, my homies there are nice and all, but man, does their english suck. I get it, they don't need to know it, but wow..i got old ass grandmothers in Taiwan that spit better english than my lovely Tokyo-ites. 

tried their lunch combo..the small donburi plus small udon. it was fantastic, and at 10 bucks, it was a steal. I will def/. be back and try all the other wonderful things on their menu. I am still thinking about the zaru soba and the chirashi i had..so good. Portions are not too big though in general, from what I see..but that's authentic for ya. japanese portions are normally much smaller than what we fat ass americans like to devour.
author: Jerry C.

description: I really liked the Udon. My husband got the Tempura lunch, which had a lot of fun veggies in it. The price was very reasonable too.
author: Cate H.

description: I've eaten at the majority of the restaurants in J-town and I found the interesting food dish here is the Takara chirashi.  I liked how it came out in a stackable tower.  Good food.
author: Brent T.

description:
Foods ????? 
 Waiters do terrible job. Especially the waiter who dyed hair to the long blond. She doesn't  do smile and very rude!!
author: W W.

description: Food was ok. Service is bad. The walls of the restaurant are dirty with stains. The waitress and the host were not very helpful. I don't know why she served the steamed white rice that was supposed to come with my teriyaki salmon 15 minutes before my salmon arrived.
author: Liyin Y.

description: My experience here was sub par. When I first came here, the service was already off to a bad start because the host was not very kind or even helpful. He seemed detached and it seemed as though he did not want to be there. We couldn't even get a smile the entire time. Also, when our food was served (we had a party of seven) the waitresses were really confused on what side dishes went with which entrees. It was just really unorganized and messy. When it came to actually eating, the ramen I had (I believe it was miso based) was pretty bland. It wasn't anything special. One thing that was good was the rock and roll roll. But, overall I probably wouldn't be coming back due to the mediocre service and food.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
This place has great lunch options for pretty reasonable prices. We got here around 12:30 for lunch and had to wait 15 minutes (there was a line and you need to sign your name in by the door), but the guy in the front said the food here was really fresh and authentic so it's worth the wait. Busy restaurants are always a good sign!

We were seated and right away they set 2 cups of hot tea in front of us which is complimentary. That was really nice! 

Got the 3 Item Takara Combo Lunch Set for $16.50 with tuna and salmon sashimi, chicken teriyaki, and grilled mackerel. Comes with a bowl of rice and miso soup, both of which were made well and acted as good fillers. 

*Sashimi - 5 stars! Very fresh and juicy. I just wish the portions would have been larger.
*Chicken Teriyaki - Pretty good, but not great. I'm generally not a fan of this dish anyway though. Comes in a large portion with salad on the side that has a yummy dressing on it.
*Grilled mackerel - this was ok. No wow factor here. Doused it with lemon. 

Also got the Maguro (Tuna) and Avocado Roll for $6.25. This was ok, I wouldn't order it again though. I've decided that next time I will pick the rolls instead of letting my friend order them... aiya! Horrible choices. 

Came out to $30 total with tip. Not bad at all!
author: Kriti R.

description: Pretty standard jp town resturant.  Large menu.
author: Michael E.

description:
YUMMY!
We actually heard about this restaurant but never been.  And the fact that  I saw an old friend (who is Japanese) eating here with his family assured me I was at one of the best in J-town.  It was very authentic, crowded for a Saturday evening, and service was adequate.  Seems like each dinner came with salad, soup, and chawan mushi (unheard of right?), and a choice of ice cream.  I had the combination dinner with sashimi and tempura.  Sashimi was good average and the tempura was super good.  We agreed we'd be back, perhaps our new fave!  :)
author: Meredith K.

description: Awesome place for some authentic Japanese food!   Chawamisu is delicious and you've got to try the Ogashi Tofu!
author: Jeffy C.

description:
So I can't vouch for the ramen, but their agadashi tofu, spider roll, and shrimp tempura roll were horrible.

Their agadashi tofu was in a very cornstarchy glutinous sauce which I found odd.  No bonito flakes either.  Just lacking in any flavor at all.

Their rolls contained a bitter leafy sprout (maybe watercress or something like that) that  literally tasted like you were eating grass. I've had similar looking sprouts in my rolls but it never tasted so nasty. It completely overpowered the roll that I had to take it out.  The crab in the spider roll was also tough and tasteless.  Plus, there was only 4 pieces in each roll, yet it cost $8.  I'm used to getting 6-8 pieces per roll.

Honestly, the supermarket rolls taste better than this place.
author: C A.

description:
First off, they are very strict on closing up at 2pm.  My friends and I came here at 1:30-1:45 and after they seated us, they rushed us to order as they were closing the kitchen in 5 minutes.  It would have been helpful had they told us before they seated us that we were going to be so rushed but since we had already settled down, we just stayed. Plus the waitress was still really nice and apologetic about rushing us.

After looking at the menu for 10 seconds, I ordered their Miso Ramen. It was decent, not terrible but nothing spectacular.  Being in J-town and with so much competition, you'd hope that the ramen would blow your mind but it was just good enough.  The only plus is that they do offer combinations that came with ramen and a rice cake for pretty cheap.
author: Krystal C.

description: Went for lunch yesterday, ambiance acceptable, service good, just dont eat the food. My lunch combination chicken teriyaki was barely warm and tasted funny, my tempura was soggy and just warm. I left most of it, just not enough as my stomach still hasn't settled down.
author: Ken V.

description:
i've been coming here for a few years now and i can't believe i haven't written a review for this place yet! takara is one of my fave japanese restaurants in san francisco. it's not fancy and doesn't have drinks or crazy rolls, but it's some down-home real-talk japanese food.

if you like the rolls and sauces, this ain't the place for you. but the sushi is always really really good! super fresh and delicious. the prices are also very fair for the quality you are getting. family faves include the takara chirashi and the toro platter (with all assorted toro).

they also have some pretty unique things i haven't seen at other places in SF. they have rice cooked in an iron pot and also zosui, which is a rice porridge similar to chinese jook. it is SO freaking delicious! they have something with tea and rice too but i have yet to try that.

since its a more traditional place, of course they have bento boxes, teriyaki, tempura... they even have some pretty decent sukiyaki cooked at the table. another one of my faves here is the miso black cod... mmmmmmmm!!!

overall everything i've tried here is pretty good. for lunch today i had the ramen lunch special, which was a bowl of ramen plus one giant onigiri... all for $9.95!! what a steal! the ramen was nothing crazy or special but it was good and hit the spot. if you are ever in the area, please definitely try this place out!

just a tip, if you sit in the "sushi bar" room, sometimes they only allow you to order sushi... so just ask ahead for table vs. sushi bar.
author: Bobbie L.

description:
We go to Japantown every so often and always walk by, well this time we decided to have dinner here. We have a Takara at home that we love so much and know this is going to be different which is a good thing.

We weren't disappointed.
It was a Friday night after driving up for the weekend, not too busy; but they close at 9:30 and we had a good hour to eat.
I can't remember everything we ordered but everything tasted fresh and good. The seaweed salad was great, the couple rolls were good; but maybe on the smallish side. The sashimi was very good too.
I would probably come back here; but we usually try to go to different places, so we'll see. Nothing outstanding; but just good food.
I didn't thing there was anything wrong with the service either.

Why only 3 stars? Because it was just average good food - what you would expect.
author: Sandra R.

description:
There are many Japanese restaurants in Japan town. But this is the place I usually go to when I visit SF. Today, I had lunch, and the food was good as usual. The price is also reasonable. 

It may not be the best food you can findt, but I found it overall quite good. The service can be improved - I think. The place can get crowded... The servers do not make you feel at home.
author: J L.

description: Had a great lunch at Takara today - Toro, Hamachi, Sake and Uni were all awesome. Tried a bunch of other great fresh fish as well. Will definitely be going back.
author: Chris H.

description:
Only tasted a couple things here, but what the hey... I'll review anyway.

Maguro sashimi - pretty good but I'm guessing not the very best pieces of the fish, as they had lines or connective tissue or whatever that is.  Maybe am I too picky?

Strangely enough, the plain rice that comes with.. was not so Japanese or sticky!  Bummer.

California (or ur most basic) vegetarian roll with spinach, egg, mushroom etc. looked great and tasted fine.  Then again, it would be so so wrong if a place like Takara cannot execute that perfectly.

Very attentive service, nice lengthy menu.  I didn't really care for the windowless room but we might have been sent there because we were too numerous.

Great value for the most part.  Everyone except for me had lots of food in their order.  A huge tonkatsu looked yummy, and I was told it was.

Good green tea ice cream but then, when have I ever NOT enjoyed that dessert?

Disclaimer:  I must not have gotten enough 2eat, hence my current underwhelm-ment.  I'll re-review at some point and likely bump this to a five, after sampling more.

Bring your parking stub.  They validate for one hour at J-town garage.

This place is BUSY.  Get there early if u don't like waiting.
author: Jade T.

description:
3.5 stars?  C'mon.  This place is top-notch.  Authentic.  Run by Japanese.  Nice decor.  Quiet.  Clean.  Oh, and the food is fantastic.  My wife ordered the $8 "Lunch Box" and everything was great and plentiful.  I had $9 oyakodon and $4.50 salmon nigiri, and they were divine.  The miso soup was tasty.  The only thing it is missing are the hot towels beforehand.  

I will make it a point to come here the next time I am in SF.
author: Tony C.

description: Great place, very accommodating. I had the salmon avocado, which they did really well. Staff even brought my gf a bag of ice for her injury! Food is excellent. Enjoy!
author: nathan p.

description:
I WOULDN'T GIVE THIS PLACE A STAR IF I COULD.

I went here for a birthday dinner with a party of 4, service was ok. Food was ok. The disappointing part was after the bill was paid, I just stepped out the restaurant, they came after me asking for at least 18% tip. I can't believe they wanted to get 18% tip from me, I already gave a tip that I thought was reasonable. The service wasn't out of this world neither was the food. Nothing was spectacular to make the place stand out.

There is nothing that says 18% tip is required for a party less than 6. I know that if my dinner party was at least 6 people, then minimum tip is 15% but the fact they asked me for an 18% tip, I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS PLACE FOR ANYONE.
author: Althea D.

description:
This place is on the 2nd floor inside the "Peace Plaza". We ordered the seaweed salad, spinach, and gyoza for the appetizers. The gyoza presentation was great, the seaweed salad was quite large, lots of "value". The spinach was ok, nothing special.

My friend got a dish that ended up being a bowl of calms, crab, tofu, and other asian veggies. Looked great. I had normal rolls: rock'n'roll, spicy yellowtail. It was decent but not super mega awesome. I wouldn't go out of my way to come back...  

The servers were very nice and attentive. Much appreciated. The menus weren't very clean and the atmosphere was kind of mall-like. For the money I think the interior could have been better.
author: Michael S.

description:
If you want average Japanese food with sub-par service, go to Takara. The food is fine, but I was pretty surprised at how unaccommodating the waitresses were. 

When we asked for the rice balls to come first so the kids could eat, the waitress gave us a forced smile, saying that the restaurant was very busy and could not guarantee anything. Nobody came to fill our water during the meal. When I asked to take home one of the dishes, she handed me a plastic box for me to do myself. 

And then she had the nerve to write exactly how much I should tip on the bill.
author: Linda W.

description: My go-to Japanese food place.  They have authentic Japanese food like my Mom makes.  Chawan mushi, nasu with miso, spinach with miso, tonkatsu, various nabes.  Service is awesome and the food is great.
author: Jimmy S.

description:
David at Two told me that he thinks Takara is one of the best Sushi restaurant in the city, so I had to give it a try.   I'll give 3.4 points for Takara.  Their food was decent but was not that special too me...

I liked Takara because:

1.  It reminds me of  restaurants in department stores in Japan. 
2.  Their fish is fresh.  They uses honmaguro (deep red colored tuna. "hon" means real.  I only eat this kind of tuna)
3.  Both tonkatsu (panko bread crumb fried pork) and fried oysters were juicy and not too oily.  They were accompanied by traditional condiments of finely julienned raw cabbage and tomato (for color)
4.  Their dinner comes with chyawanmushi (egg custard with fish broth) and Ice cream (vanilla, red bean, or green tea).  They tasted good for a combination dinner at Japanese restaurant in the US. 

I didn't think Takara was special enough for me to go back because:
1.  It reminds me of Japanese restaurant in Japanese department store.  
2.  Even though I liked the way they were cooked, pork and oysters were not great quality.  
3.  They close at 9:30.-  I usually start eating my dinner at 9PM. -  I usually have a few drinks with my meal. - It takes me over 1 hr - 1:30 hr for me to finish a dinner and drinks.  - the restaurant need to close at 9:30...
3.  Their dishes taste like home cooked meal.  I cook at home.  So there is no need to go to Takara for cooked dishes.  For sushi, I prefer other restaurants in the city.
 
I may go back if I was hungry at 8PM...
author: Chie J.

description:
OK, I've been here several times and still wonder how it has gotten all of the hype it has. It is just an average to below average Japanese run restaurant. The staff are polite and prompt, the menu items standard but not outstanding. You can get the same kind of food at a number of other places in the city, you just have to know where to look and know what to look for.

I guess some people just follow what ever local food critic Michael Bauer dictates.

Seriously, check out my other reviews of Japanese restaurants for comparison. As for my qualifications, you could say I was weaned on my grandmother's Japanese food made the way it was supposed to be made.
author: 和子

description:
First went here years ago seeing the advertisements on Japanese television. While it was okay it was really cafeteria food, felt like cattle in a feed lot. It wasn't cheap either. I know it then closed for a time, but then opened with new management and chef. What a difference!
It's the sort of place that gets the details correct, something a lot of places don't bother with. Recently had lunch there and it was rather hot outside. So when they served us tea, it was iced tea, how thoughtful and unexpected!  They also give oshibori with dinner. With the dinner combination they give you a great selection of items, including chawan mushi, done very well.
Probably my favorite dish is the tekka don, slices of excellent sashimi over sushi rice with all of the trimmings. Not cheap, but so satisfying!
Also had the sukiyaki here, which you cook on a table top unit. When you first look at all of the stuff packed into the sukiyaki pan you don't see how it could taste like much. But it cooks quickly, and thanks to their delicious sauce it was an amazing meal, probably one of the best I've ever had.
So if you get a chance visit Takara, they have a large menu, good variety, and delicious food. Some may find it a little more pricey than some of it's neighbors, but it's worth every cent.
author: Kevin T.

description:
Came for: lunch
Will come back for: pondering that point...

I was excited to try a new place and hopeful of finding a go-to in the area. Well, I'm still looking.
My katsu donburi was dry. Both the donkatsu itself and the donburi. From what I've experienced, a good donburi is one in which the egg and sauce well-coat the rice bowl. This was far from it.
My friend's bento box was really meh. Chicken was rather dry, the tempura was ok, and none of the other pieces anything to write home about.

Take-Away: their booth seats have seat-warmers, which is pretty cool; questionable whether that's enough to lure me back for another try.
author: Carol K.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars.  What I like best about Takara is it has an extensive menu - udon, sushi, bento boxes, appetizers...something for everyone, all reasonably priced.  Reliable, standard food that I can count on when I'm craving basic Japanese fare.  It's nothing mind blowing, but this comes into regular rotation on my casual dinner list.  It's usually a full house for dinner.  Love the nabeyaki udon on a cold evening.  Oh, their lunch specials are a good deal, if you're ever in J-town for lunch.

The ambiance is casual, mellow and unpretentious.  For dinner on Friday, seems to be a mix of locals, groups of friends and casual date-nights.
author: Caroline I.

description: This place has always been my favorite spot for Japanese food. Everything is freshly prepared and delicious. . The owner and waiters are all Japanese, so you know this place is authentic. My favorite here is their ramen. It sounds lame, but their broth is deeeelicious! Their bento choices are wide and yummy as well; beef teriyaki is bombbb. :)
author: Selina S.

description:
They were understaffed but we still got prompt service. The restaurant was full and busy the whole time we were there which is always a good sign. Much of the clientele were Japanese, another good sign. I'm so relieved that Takara was a decent choice. I had originally had my sights set on Kui Shin Bo but they're closed on Mondays!! My mom and I had to quickly find an alternative, which I feel like can be hit or miss in Japantown. 

Can't really rate my review on its sushi but I heard the Japanese couple next to us exclaim "oishiii."  I wanted me some Japanese comfort food and got the oyako don. It came piping hot in a HUGE bowl (see my pic!) with a ton of chicken and egg (no duh). They did not skimp out on the veggies either--tons of shitake mushrooms, thinly sliced yellow onions, and green onions topped with a smattering of seawood. The sauce the donburi was simmered in was delicious. Sweet and flavorful, just like it's supposed to be. 

My mom ordered the special lunch obento where for $6.95 it came with soup, rice, salad, 3 California rolls, nicely battered and fried tempura, and a choice of entree; my mom got the white tuna sashimi.  Honestly, for the price and the quality, this was an extremely worthwhile deal. Food prices just don't go this low these days!

The restaurant itself has a worn and faded look.
author: Annie W.

description:
I went here for a friend's birthday.  Upon entering I noticed that the table was very sticky.  When I inquired about the Nigiri dinner I was told that it was chef's choice 8 pieces nigiri sushi and 3 pieces tuna roll for $15.  The waitress brought out soup for each of us, which was some type of chicken broth with a custard topping and a hard boiled quail egg inside.  My yelp journal reads: "odd chicken custard soup had disgusting egg in it."  Someone at the table ordered pickled cabbage (which i usually like) and it tasted old like they had left it out.  

By this point i was very disappointed.  The waitress brought out miso soup which was good, but I guess you can't fuck up miso soup...  

But when she brought out my sushi plate the meal started to take a turn for the better.  The sushi was amazingly fresh and yummy.  When I had been told it was chef's choice I assumed it would be all tuna or something, but it included fresh salmon, white tuna, 3 regular tuna, eel, as well as octopus and more.  The sushi was really great and totally worth the $15 I spent.  

My friend Jeff's main course was really good as well.  I took a bite of his tempura and it was great.  And I hate tempura.  

All in all I was pleasantly surprised by how good this little gem in japantown was for the price.
author: Matt N.

description: I'm Asian and I know what a good Asian restaurant should taste like. The Sashimi is not fresh at all, and please don't order fried oyster because you will regret for sure...
author: Elsa C.

description:
Dear Yelp:  your search algorithm is a little wonky.  I was shocked that no one had Yelp'ed this place yet...but in fact a Google search pulled this page up while a site search could not.

Anyway - after the not-so-great sushi experience at Sushi Groove, I wanted to take my friend somewhere not so trendy and open on Christmas Day.  After many phone calls out - we found this place & I had my first Japanese porridge.  YUM.  Super flavorful broth with a good amount of seafood.  I'm definitely a porridge girl so this hit the spot.  The menu is pretty expansive - lots of different types of Japanese food to try including shabu shabu.  

They did take reservations and we were seated right away.  Friendly service, but it did seem like they were under-staffed that day.  I will definitely be back.
author: Helen F.

description:
Hmmm...

Quiet lunchtime food
Box of bento and miso
Tummy is happy

Thus concludes my haiku for Takara Japanese Restaurant.

Overall, the service was right on key. From the host stand, to the server to the exit, everything was kept at a minimal noise level, and the miso was GREAT. Finding a good miso soup is so hard these days. 

I had the chef make me a 6 piece lunch set and I wasn't disappointed. I love sushi but I love Nigiri more! Mmmm...I'll definitely be coming back for more and I'll get dessert next time.
author: Jessica K.

description: Must come here for lunch. The lunch combo filled me up so much. I had a soba and rice bowl combo. The place is a bit stuffy, but who cares when the food is good. One of the best Japanese restaurants in Japantown.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Not a place to see and be seen.  This is a place to go eat great Japanese comfort food.

At first I thought the service was lacking - but they've gradually improved in the past three years.  The entire menu is enticing - and so far I haven't ordered anything I didn't like!  The steamed egg custard and chicken or seafood porridges are especially good.  Definitely worth a try.
author: Kristen S.

description:
This place was alright.  It was just your average Japantown restaurant.

The sushi was fresh though, which was much appreciated.

it was also a little bit expensive, but I guess all of the restaurants in that little complex are on the more pricier side because they cater to the tourist crowd.
author: Alison L.

description: I only wish I could remember all of the dishes and Japanese names for them.  I have to believe that this is as authentic and original as it gets--even in J-town.  We had some Japanese sweet potato dishes with tuna and a quail egg that you blend up and slurp--awesome.  We had sake soup with baby clams--fantastic.  We had abalone liver and abalone sashimi--wild.  Spinach with bonito flakes, spinach with a white miso sauce, and roasted baby eggplant--delicious.  Probably the best yellowtail and fatty tuna of all times--sublime.  Plus we had the squid marinated its own juices, the sweet shrimp (sushi tail and tempura head), sea urchin, salmon roe, and some dorsal fin erector--a symphony of different tastes, textures, and sensations.  I would not have guessed from the outside what they produce on the inside, but this was really extraordinary in the rue sense of the word.
author: Joseph J.

description:
I love this place. I've been here a number of times and I would have to say that it is one of my favorite Japanese restaurants in the Bay Area. 

I usually come here with my fiance and his sister's family (2 young children) and the restaurant is extremely accommodating. Upon arrival, they remember the items that the kids like to eat and the food comes out fairly quickly. 

We generally order a few orders of the sukiyaki and a variety of various sashimi, nigiri, and rolls and the food is always extremely fresh. The sukiyaki is great for a cold day. The broth is extremely flavorful (almost too flavorful at times) and it is served with a plate of sliced meat and plentiful vegetables (napa cabbage, carrots, onions, mushrooms (different varieties) and yam noodles. It also comes with a good amount of tofu, which I always love. 

This past weekend, I had salmon and yellowtail nigiri, all of which was fresh and delightful. I also had the steaming egg custard which was very light, and the broth was extremely tasty. The kids had shrimp and vegetable tempura, salmon and beef teriyaki - everything was excellent. 

All in all, I've only had good experiences at this restaurant. I always look forward to coming back. 

P.S. I never order dessert here because there's an amazing crepe place on the other side which is the perfect compliment to this meal.
author: Oanh N.

description: Wanted to find a solid sushi bar for lunch after a meeting near Japantown. Chose takara based on yelp reviews and the fact that many of the other sushi bars in the area are closed for lunch. I had the tuna, yellowtail and halibut shashimi along with a rainbow roll and the nigori unfiltered sake. The sashimi melted in my mouth and the roll was equally as delicious. I don't typically drink cold sake but it was quite good as well. Price wasn't too bad coming in at just under $50. Only negative I can site is the service, almost felt like I was bothering them. Would eat her again based on food quality but would probably try one of the 30 other sushi bars in the area based on service.
author: Bryan G.

description: Really.... don't bother. I don't care what a great review it got from Frommer's 2013, it was not good japanese food. The fish in the seafood soup was way over done, tasteless and a terrible texture. It was not a good representation of what good Japanese food should be. Nice atmosphere though.
author: Susanna S.

description: i travel to Tokyo regularly and I have to give this place a 5 stars.  If you compare the food and price, it's a bargain, lunch bentos are great, I tried them all, especially like the Pork Tonkatsu and Chicken dish.
author: Mason C.

description:
Came by with the boyfriend at in the midst of the Cherry Blossom Festival.  I had the blackened mackerel lunch box. Rice was awesome texture and well cooked; the fish was salty and buttery. Not a fan of miso or Japanese pickles (sacrilege, I'm sure). It was pretty stuffy but cleared out as we ate.

I'd probably go again if I were in the area.
author: Milena C.

description:
I like Japanese cuisine. The noodles... the sushi... the tempura... the food presentation. I especially like the decor. I would really be impressed if someone were to just "Disney" the crap out of a Japanese restaurant. You know what I mean... Samurais... Kimonos... some Geisha playing 'Sakura' on a stringed instrument.

Well... this isn't the place, but it's OK. Atmosphere is unmistakably Japanese, and that's good enough for me. Sh!t... It's freaking J-Town, dude! Service is friendly, but not totally subservient asian stereo typical. The ladies are smart and cool. I  like that.

OK... Beef Teriyaki is off the hook! Cooked the way you want it, thick, juicy and tender, with just a bit of fat. EXCELLENT! The Tempura is text book perfect. Could be a bit more generous though.  The sushi is only average. The Rock n Roll - Eel & Avocado, was their best of what I ordered, but I've had better in many other places. However, they will validate your garage ticket if your bill is over $30. That shouldn't be a problem because this joint is DAMN pricey! $26 for a 3 item combination dinner. $5 for a Sapporro brew. Commercial rent in Japantown ain't cheap. The garage parking, IS cheap. Spend $30 to save $5...

Here's my helpful hint for the day. If you want to bypass all the touristy shops and all the other sight seeing bullsh!t in the big Pagoda, park in the garage, lower level near the Kabuki Hotel. The garage elevator there will take you to the 2nd floor, a couple of rights and you're at Takara.

Check it out!
author: Rick V.

description:
visited this place FEB 4.. 2012
Saturday Lunch
got Miso Ramen
Male servers - satisfied
1 Female Worker.. blond hair, tattoo on arm...  - not so great, almost like i want to avoid this group but i know i shouldn't.. so im going to put my head down and pretend i didn't hear them... 

 my noodle sucked... 
service sucked,.. wouldn't of been ok if the female was absent..
author: Scottster C.

description:
Takara was recommend to my wife and I by a person on the street while we were looking for a sushi place for lunch.

We ordered a sashimi platter with pretty much one of every kind of fish they offer and an option that had beef teriyaki, oysters, and maybe something else.  The food was excellent and had great flavor to it.  We had a great server and overall great experience here, and will go there again.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Japanese owned restaurant which serves somewhat
authentic Japanese food for the price.

It is a great place to go drinking with co workers after
work, and you can head on over to Mogura or Ikkyu bar 
afterwards.

Conveniently located right next to Hotel Kabuki.
author: Michael W.

description:
Ate here on a Monday night and was disappointed by their service. When we entered the place, the guy rushed us to the closest table and threw down the menus before hurriedly speeding away, like we were inconveniencing him. 

We ordered a Ramen bowl and 3 item combo with Sashimi, Teriyaki  Salmon and tempura. The ramen bowl was decent but lacked a lot of flavor. Same to be said for the sashimi, which was really fresh but too cold to have any good flavor in it. Maybe if it was a little more room temperature, the fish would've been more flavorful but I could hardly taste the difference between the fish which was a disappointment.  The salmon was overcooked and had little teriyaki sauce on it to make up for it. The tempura was good, though. 

The combo meal came with some sort of seaweed salad (I think that's what it was... the seaweed was chopped into little rice-like pieces and tasted like beef jerky, which reminds me of dog-food flavor). I've never had anything like it at other Japanese restaurants and don't know if it's traditional or not but I would pass on it next time. 

A nice surprise was the fact that my combo came with vanilla or green tea ice cream at the end. I chose the green tea and asked for it to-go, since we were staying at the hotel next door and wanted to wrap up our dinner and head back after a long day. The same guy acted like that was unheard of, saying that it was really small and I could eat it there. He ended up bringing it out to me in a to-go carton anyways and I enjoyed it in the luxury of my jet tub, although it tasted funky and made me wish I had gotten the vanilla instead. Meh.
author: Megan F.

description:
We came here for dinner one night and had some sushi and ramen. So my review is just for this type of food we ate. 

We had these items and found them to be quite good in comparison to other sushi place we have gone to.

Nabeyaki udon
Dragon roll
Rock and roll
Soy sauce ramen
Miso ramen
Green tea

Everything tasted fresh. The soup for the udon and ramen was very hot and tasty( did not taste like msg) as they way it should be. Being a family of picky eaters, we were all satisfied.
