Only compliant I have is they do not provide to go container for ramen soup. My kids could not finish it so they had to let it go to waste.  So make sure to bring your appetite for the udon soup. 

We will be back.

Happy dining.
author: Adventure S.

description:
We saw a movie at the Kabuki Theatre and afterward, we were craving sushi. Japantown seemed like the logical place to find it. So, we decided to try Takara.

The fatty tuna and spicy tuna were excellent. The fish was very fresh. We also ordered Sake Onigiri  (rice ball) and it was good too. However, the menu was a bit overwhelming, there was a lot in it. What I was really looking for was a firecracker roll, but I was disappointed by their lack of variety when it came to the specialty rolls. 

They were pretty busy, but we got our food in a reasonable amount of time.

My biggest complaint? The glass my Sapporo came in smelled like fish! Ewwwww!
author: Staci B.

description:
This was the best-rated restaurant in all of Miyako Mall, but honestly, I wish we went somewhere else to eat. The service was ok. They were attentive but definitely forgot a few things here and there. That could be blamed on the restaurant being busy. 

We ordered the Vegetable Tempura Udon Soup which was a good idea at first, but then the crispy tempura crust quickly dissolved into a mush. Not a great idea as far a soup goes. The udon itself was good.

I ordered the Tofu Steak, which I assumed would be some type of saucy and fried tofu. When it came, it turned out the tofu was barely fried. It was just jiggly, soft, and tasteless. The worst part was the mushroom sauce that the tofu was drenched in. While it didn't taste bad (or good, really), the smell was just atrocious. I've never ordered anything at a restaurant that I literally had to scoot away from me because of the smell. That made me lose my appetite pretty quickly. I will be trying other restaurants next time I come to this mall. Not Takara.
author: Christina L.

description:
I've been going to this restaurant for years during the Japanese Cherry Blossom Festival in Japantown for lunch. Was here just yesterday for lunch and was not disappointed with the food. Ordered their lunch Bento Box at $7.95, which includes, miso soup, 4 pieces of California roll, tempura (1 shrimp with veggies), salad , rice, and whichever you pick..I think it was tonkatsu, chicken terriyaki, beef terriyaki. I know there were a couple more but I can't remember at the top of my head.. I picked the tonkatsu. The tonkatsu was crispy, juicy and not one bit oily. 

My only disappointment for the last couple of  years is the service. They are a bit slow getting to the tables..Took quite some time to get a refill for water or to even get our bills. We sat waiting...and it seemed like forever when there wasn't many people at the time. At times we thought they may have forgotten about us. Takara, I like your food..you just need to improve on your service.

Also if you've parked in the garage below, they will validate your ticket if you spend $30 or more.
author: Cindy R.

description:
Food: 3.5 stars
Service: 3.25 stars
Value: 2.75 stars


Honestly, this restaurant is just okay for me. Since it is in San Francisco Japantown, so the pricing is a little high. The sashimi on the Regular Chirashi ($14.75) was fresh, but not as good as the one I had in other Japanese restaurants, and the portion is small even I paid a little more to get a better one. One time experience is good enough!
author: F T.

description: Asked twice to make an order. Waited at the table for 10min and left. Without our order's having been taken. The obvious problem of this place is that they do not have enough waiters. Cannot say anything about the quality of their food.
author: Victor A.

description: I came with a party of 5 and have been waiting here for over half an hour to be seated. While I was waiting, the waiter seated 7 other parties who signed up after me. I asked for an estimate of how much longer the wait would be and if it was possible to be separated and be seated at different tables (if it would be easier on them), but the waiter was rude and said "Table of 5 will take a long time" and then walked off to bring in a separate party. Anyways, besides the rude customer service from one waiter, the food was OK. The only thing noticeable was the Teriyaki chicken lunch special, which has a very smokey flavor. The miso soup and the udon soup base were both overly salty for my taste. I don't think I'll be coming here again.  And if it matters, you don't get water until you specifically ask for it.
author: Shewa C.

description:
Our first time at Takara is also our last. Came here on a Tuesday night around 8:30PM. Discovered Takara whilst searching for reasonably priced sushi restaurants in Japantown on Yelp. Noticed the star ratings ran hot and cold, so we figured it was going to be a toss up. Uhhh yeeeah. Try throw up. 

Ordered the agedashi mochi to start. It didn't just look wrong, it tasted wrong. The mochi was drenched in sauce (versus a light drizzling), piping hot on the outside but cold in the center. Took one bite and set it aside. Next came our rolls. The fish was definitely not fresh. The nori was way too chewy. After sampling a piece -- one piece! -- from each of the rolls we ordered (4 total), we concluded that it was just not palatable. So, we got up, explained to the gentleman at the register that we were not pleased with the food, told him we'd pay for the alcohol we drank, but that the sushi was just flat-out awful. He insisted the chefs use only the freshest fish. And while that may be the case any other day or night, it wasn't the night we visited. After about five minutes of back and forth protestations, we paid for the entire meal (sans tip). It was approaching 9:30PM, we were starving, and our Japantown options were closing up one by one. So it was either continue to bicker with this guy or pay the check and get the eff on our way. Needless to say, we'll be disputing the charge with the credit card company come sun-up.  

Lemme tell ya, no amount of O-positive blood and electricity could've saved that meal. There are plenty of decent sushi/Japanese food options in Peace Plaza. I'd recommend you try any one of them in lieu of Takara.
author: Monster M.

description: Chicken Teriyaki-YUM. Warm hand towels-YAY!
author: DJ C.

description:
My colleague was in town doing a gig in Walnut Creek.  We already tried the Japanese fare there so I asked him to meet me in SF instead.  I planned to try out Okina Sushi, then realized at their doorstep that they are closed on Tuesdays.  Darn, yet again I had to pick a new place off the top of my head... and if you know me, there aint much on the top of my head.  No fancy mobile Yelp so I used my car's GPS to help me find a place.  The Takara name rang a bell, but I couldn't remember why.  I'm having this memory problem recently.

Looking at Takara from the outside, my bad food warning light was flashing.  It doesn't look good.  But looking at the menu, it was filled with mispelled Engrish words... hmmmm, must be good then.  We went in.

Typically I'll order a couple of items, get a sense of the food and what everyone likes, then continue ordering throughout the meal.  We ordered the chawan-mushi, the nabeyaki udon, tonkatsu, and yamakake for starters. 

Surprisingly the chawan-mushi came out first, in about 5 minutes.  I looked at my buddy, he looked at me.  There is no way chawan-mushi can be made in 5 minutes... yep, it was lukewarm like they reheated it.  Nasty.

The yamakake and tonkatsu came out next.  My friend loves yamaimo.  The maguro looked old and tasted kinda fishy.  My friend asked, "How can they screw this up?"  Yuck.  The tonkatsu was decent, not great, but the best thing we ordered.

The nabeyaki udon came out last.  This is a standard order for my friend, so I wasn't surprised he ordered it again, even with it being rather warm outside.  The udon was clearly the frozen variety.  We didn't bother finishing it.  Pffftt.

I told him, don't waste your belly space eating this stuff.  So we closed out our bill and went out wandering Japantown aimlessly, looking for someplace else to eat.  What a shame, 900+ Yelp bookmarks and I'm playing Russian Roulette with my stomach's happiness.

We ended up at New Korea House just to play it safe and not risk two bad dinners in one night... how sad is that, settling for Korean food in Japantown?
author: Bryan K.

description: My wife and I ate lunch here on 02/17/13. We had a craving for sushi.  She ordered the regular nigiri sushi and I had the regular chirashi. The fish was fresh . The slices were a little thin except for the maguro. My wife commented that the slices of fish was a little thin and the rice was a little too much for the slices of fish. She said that the salmon was very tasty. Salmon sashimi is her favorite. One of my checks on the sushi chef is to look at the tamago, egg omelet, If the chef is trained the omelet  has a consistent yellow color and is a solid piece with no joints. The tamago in my chirashi met all the qualities I look for. Raw fish was delicious, presentation was nice to look at. The rice was firm a texture that a good sushi chef prepares. All the signs of a knowledgeable sushi chef. The menu has extensive Japanese dishes. Will have to try some next time I'm back.
author: Taco Y.

description:
Came to Japantown on a beautiful day. We asked a store clerk from the boutique store for a restaurant reco and she directed us here with no hesitation. 

We got in around 11:35, only 5 minutes after they've opened for lunch, but already the place is filled with regular customers.

The waiter took our order and placed all the plates and utensils on our table, along with tea for me and my husband and iced water for our 2 girls. 

Here's what we ordered:

Chirachi lunch special set: the portion was small, only 3 pieces of sashimi (salmon, tuna and ???), but the fish are very fresh. The sushi rice is really good, just enough stickiness to it.  Tmiso soup is also superb, not too salty.

Lunch combo - Saba & Sashimi: I have to comment on the cucumber... it's so sweet and fresh! The sashimi (tuna and hamachi) were fresh and the saba was so thick and juicy! 

Udon with white yam: The udon was chewy but not slimy. My daughter finished the whole bowl in less than 10 minutes.

Soba with bean curd: The soup base was a tad too sweet, but the soba was very good, so are the bean curd.

Kappa-maki: again, the cucumber was very sweet... I'd like to buy some of these cucumber.

It took a while for the noodles to come, but the rest of the food came very quickly. In short, great food, great service. Will definitely come back again!
author: mei c.

description:
Takara has been my family's go-to restaurant for Japanese food in J-town for some number of years now, and I don't see that changing anytime soon. Every time I'm back in SF, I wind up here.

Its incredibly large menu has something for everyone -- from the obligatory teriyaki to the less commonly found kamameshi. This can be a drawback since I think generally you'll fare better at specialized restaurants for certain things ... like ramen. For ramen I like Tanpopo across the street. 

But to me, Takara is all about comfort food and it does it well. It is a little pricey, but in my opinion it's a bargain for the good quality and good portions. My favorite is ordering the "Takara Chirashi" which is sashimi over sushi rice. Something that can't be missed is their chawan mushi (savory egg custard), which comes with most of their set meals. I'd also add kamameshi (rice pots) and chazuke (tea over rice) are both comfort foods that I think are relatively rare finds in restaurants here.

The service ... has character. It definitely can drag at times, but my favorite is walking in to see the grey-haired old Japanese man with the beaming smile who hustles faster than I can. It somehow adds to the feeling of being home -- a feeling that I'll be taken care of here.
author: natalie n.

description:
An excellent hideaway of Japanese restaurants in the Japan town. You would never find it unless you were given good directions. 

It's directly outside of the Kabuki Hotel head out left from their lobby and you'll find a gem of a restaurant. 

Lunch was a little wait, but worth it. Try the Lunch Bento special, affordable and great combo choices. Throw in an extra sushi special and your all set. Great food, cozy setting and of course service was efficient. 

I'll be back...
author: Edgar M.

description:
Alright, so i'm a little behind on my reviews. I went to Takara during the Cherry Blossom Festival for lunch earlier this year. There wasn't much wait, and we were seated almost immediately. I bet if this place was in a higher foot traffic area it would have more business. 

The food was pretty good and it came out rather quickly. Not too bad in terms of service either. However the place wasn't that clean. The price for the food was reasonable, and won't mind going back if I am ever in the area. This was an overall ok place, so i'll give it an ok rating. 3 stars.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Food: 3/10 The toro was off, still half frozen. the other sashimi didn't impress either, i'm afraid. the rolls are mediocre at best. presentation of dishes needs to be more detail oriented and creative. 

Sake: 3/10 very limited sake list. no great stuff. what they have is overpriced.

Service: 2/10 slow service. nonetheless friendly staff. should have offered to replace the bad toro right away though, and should have apologised instead of claiming that it was good! 

Atmosphere: 1/10 boring decoration. not enough buzz for my liking. it's a low-key venue.

We didn't feel like staying longer after our mains, so we didn't even want to look at the desserts - and those are usually my favourites!

Very underwhelmed on the whole as I had high expectations. One of the worst japanese restaurants we've been to.

un abrazo ;)
author: Sebastian C.

description: The best thing anyone got in our group was thai curry soup with beef. It was really great. The other noodle broths were eh, and my gf actually got a beef ramen soup that tasted like they took out a top ramen pack and made some noodles and just slapped on some sliced beef.
author: Brandon R.

description:
You know that feeling you get when you're certain that you've found your one true love? Hell, I still haven't found that, but I'm pretty sure if Takara was a man he'd be my one true love... 

I believe my search for the closest authentic Japanese food, service, and experience in San Francisco has been completed! This is near the real deal people. None of that dragon dog fire creamy blabbity blah rolls, crappy teriyaki meats, or large american portions. 

I ordered the Chirashi sushi (roughly $17). It was a fairly good amount, with a variety of very fresh fish. I also ordered the negi toro rolls (8 rolls for roughly $7). They're small, but hey toro is expensive! The rolls just melted in my mouth. Just heavenly! 

Even before the meal, they caught me off guard by bringing Chawanmushi (a steamed savory egg custard). OH MY! Just the way my mom makes it! You can't find this in a lot of places!  They even brought out miso soup and a side dish of cooked carrots & konnyaku (a yam jelly). 

For once I actually ate slow to savor the flavors and tastes of my meal. Pairing my meal with a cold glass of plum wine really topped it off! 

The service was great here! Everyone was SOOO nice, and they even brought out a complimentary ice cream! As most people have complained about the service here, I'll have to let you in on something. In Japan, servers don't wait you every minute of your dining experience as they do here in America. And I think they've sort of carried on that cultural aspect here. They want you to enjoy the meal, so don't feel bad flagging someone down. In fact, I like not being bothered. Having little service here and there IS the Japanese way. 

There was plenty of seating all around. And the atmosphere was relaxing, and quiet. The prices aren't the cheapest, but they're not overly priced. It's Japanese food, so don't expect gigantic portions! And best of it, if you parked in the garage, they validate! 

Oh Takara, "Chou Oishikatta desu!!" You left my heart filled with warmth, and my belly full of delicious food! You're lucky because usually only my mom leaves me feeling that way. 

P.S. "Chou Oishikatta desu" is pretty much equivalent to "Hella delicious!" :)
author: Catherine O.

description: I've been coming here for years for fresh sushi. The food quality is high. Most of the customers are Japanese elderly folks. I've recently started bringing my baby/toddler with me and she loves it too. The miso soup is tasty and so is everything I've ever had -- bento boxes, sushi, sashimi, etc. The sushi is made with such small amounts of thinly laid rice that I feel like I'm getting the best deal. For those who do not know this, the best sushi is made with as little rice as possible and a very thick slice of filling or topping. Helps people who are on low-carb diets too! The service is OK, but the lady who comes and refills the tea should be faster. Many times I have to wave her over to give me a refill.
author: J B.

description: Adequate sushi but service for Tuesday lunch execrable. We waited at least 30 min after seating for waitress, who then kept forgetting parts of our order. Again and again. It was embarrassing, as we were entertaining friends from out of town who especially wanted Japanese food. Do not recommend.
author: Mary a.

description: I ate there for the first time on 11/01/2014. I had unagi (eel). It was fantastic. The chawanmushi was equally good. Very authentic.
author: Richard B.

description: Let's put it this way: I've never in my life spit  out a salmon skin roll, but it was that bad. This is one of those places where the owners are too cheap to pay for good ingredients and expect 2 servers to take care of the entire restaurant. Won't come here again.
author: JJ M.

description:
My never ending quest to find a good restaurant for dinner before show at the Fillmore brought me to Takara. The fish was fresh and pretty tasty but the overall experience lacked in a few areas. 

We didn't run into the service delays that plagued so many other Yelpers but did encounter some god awful stench coming out of the kitchen. Seriously, this smell was so rank I wasn't sure if we'd be able to get past it and enjoy our food. I kept holding my tea up to my nose to distract me and it did the trick.

Our waitress also seemed less than patient with us when we asked for a few minutes with our menus. So sorry but sometimes old friends chat when dining out! 

All in all, Takara isn't a horrible spot but with so many options in the neighborhood I doubt I'll be back. For now, my quest continues...
author: phil h.

description:
I've had lunch at Takara four times and all four times I thought the food was delicious.  I was lured by friends to this restaurant tucked away near the iconic Kabuki hotel with promises of good food at a decent price.  They were spot on.  The first time I sample several of their sashimi offerings and they were fresh and delicious.  The second time I went on my own and tried their cold buckwheat soba and an order of the barbecue squid.  It was so good I went back the 3rd time for the same meal and it was spot on again.  The soba was fresh and cooked perfectly.  The squid was barbecued just right to add that flavor you look for yet it was still tender with that snappy texture.  I knocked back a large Sapporo and life was good.  The forth time, today, I decided to try their Saba Shioyaki lunch and I was impressed yet again.  The Mackerel was perfectly grilled; it was flavorful; it was moist; it was delicious!  Add to that some silky Hamachi on the side and I was a happy man.

This place is now my goto place for a great lunch.  I have yet to have dinner here because I rarely eat out for dinner but I'm going to make an exception soon.

Needless to say I have been recommending Takara to all my friends as a hidden Gem in Japantown; for Japanese food, of all things.  Compare this with my experience at another Japanese restaurant on Judah and 39th in the Sunset (name not worth mentioning) and there's no comparison.  I wanted to see if their cold Soba and grilled squid could even touch Takara's same meal and it wasn't even close.  Takara's food took their food to task!  This isn't a review of the other place's food but honestly their squid was burnt and in some parts to a crunch, and their Soba was undercooked.

Go to Takara's in Japantown.  You can't go wrong when the locals treat their mom and grandma to lunch there.
author: Alan S.

description:
Your average sushi place.  Liked that they were open late on a Sunday night, but a lot of other places in J-town are as well.

Decent sushi and reasonable prices (about $1 a piece, depending on which kind of sushi you order).  Had the spicy tuna roll and the tempura shrimp, cucumber, and avocado roll.  The spicy tuna was just ok (I've had better) but the tempura shrimp was quite yummy.  

My favorite part was actually when I sampled my husband's red bean ice cream, which was sweet but mild and a great way to cleanse the palate.
author: Nina B.

description:
Health department score - 74.

I was about to be seated, nice man asked for how many in party, and I told him.

I glanced at the green card and it said 74.  I said, excuse us, we are going. 

He said "oh you don't like that?"

I said, "No one with sense would"
author: Cinnamon Z.

description:
my 2nd time coming here was definitely better than my first. we came here last minute and ordered a bunch of stuff to share.  Here's what we ordered: 

- chawa mushi (steam egg)
- grill hamachi kama (hamachi collar)
- grill squid legs
- soba (cold)
- soba (hot)
- chasu miso ramen
- salmon and salmon roe zousui (japanese porridge)
- ume rice with tea

the chawa mushi was the first thing that came out.  usually, chawa mushi is made when you order it and takes around 10 minutes. this came out within 3 minutes after we order. the taste was good but it was not pipping hot, which i m used to.

the salmon and salmon roe zousui was good. very very flavorful. the amount of rice and egg was just right.  this dish was very good. the rice is not mushy at all, everything was just right. 

the grill squid legs are also very good. it was grilled just right, not overcooked and not undercooked. each squid leg was around the same size. 

the grill hamachi kama was also very good. grilled to perfection. the meat was flaky and oily from the fish itself.  it came with 2 pieces. the hamachi kama is not always available, it depends when they cut the fish for the sashimi/sushi. 

the ume with rice and tea is ok. compare to the zousui, it's less flavorful but it's good if you're looking for something small and simple.  try it with the wasabi and it'll bring out different flavors of the dish. 

i will definitely come back for more dishes to try.  i see a pattern that their grill dishes are excellent here.
author: Kapo T.

description: This place was okay. The ramen does not taste very authentic here, and the beef ramen soup that I got only had one piece of beef in it, which was really disappointing. The thai curry soup with beef was actually the only saving grace at this place, because the flavors of that soup was really good. I would definitely recommend trying to find another japanese restaurant for ramen though!
author: Rachel T.

description:
I am not very happy to have to write this review, as an avid supporter of the Japantown community.  Being half-Japanese and having been raised by a Japanese mom, I know what good Japanese food is.  I also understand the importance of service and presentation in Japanese culture.  This restaurant could not be further from that standard.

In that arena, I have given this place the benefit of the doubt SEVERAL times.  The service is absolutely and astonishingly bad.  Someone else's review said service was "atrocious".  I have to agree.  And no, the quality of food is not so stellar as to make up for the service.  I will write here, my last experience there...

I went there with a friend who is not only new to Japantown, and new to good Japanese food, but also is not from this country (no Asian in him).  So, in a way, I was trying to introduce him to a great Japanese experience in the wonderful Japantown community.  In my opinion, he got neither.

We got there around 8:30pm, so I thought, oh good, we will be seated and served pretty quickly because dinner is winding down, the restaurant was barely half full (lots of empty tables).  We were two, standing behind another party of two.  As we waited unacknowledged for about 5 minutes, I started to think "uh oh, maybe not the best first place for my friend here", but again, I was trying to be optimistic.

Then finally, seated, we looked at the VERY extensive menu, which is why I liked this place.  They have all the choices.  I love my authentic Japanese food.  We had so much time to look through the menu, we changed our minds about 3 different times.  Remember, my friend is very new to this type of food, so we could have had questions.  Anyway, we waited and waited and waited.  The whole time, I kept looking up for a server to take our order.  I could have sworn, the servers (two females) were avoiding eye contact.  But finally, one came over to take our order.

At the end of the ordering, I realized, I had not been asked what I wanted to drink.  I always have hot green tea when I eat Japanese food.  The response was "look over there, we have no cups right now, it's been busy tonight, you will have to wait for your tea."  Uhm ... okay ... look over where?  Err ... what am I supposed to say, "No"?

Not only did our food come out very slowly from the kitchen and in a very strange order, but it was just so-so in quality/authentic presentation.  After about a half hour, and half way through my meal, I was getting really thirsty.  I flagged down one of the servers and asked for my tea.  Again, I was asked to look over "there" and know that there were no tea cups and that I would need to wait.  Okay, where is "there"?!  And why do I need to wait?  Couldn't they find something else to use?  The water glass that I hadn't touched was sufficiently thick enough to hold that damn tea!

Close to the end of the meal, after I had finally gotten my lukewarm tea after an hour of sitting there parched, I guess one of the servers had left our bill on the table.  We were deep in conversation and did not notice it.  We were trying to enjoy the meal despite the bad, slow, rude service and so-so food.  But as we were talking, one of the servers interrupted our conversation, "we are closing the register, so would you PLEASE pay your bill now" ... to which my friend turned to me and said "wow, she's kinda bitchy".  He's a sweet guy, so for him to say that, pretty much confirmed it.  She was really being a bitch.

After all that.  I remember thinking, I keep giving you servers the benefit of the doubt tonight, but this is ridiculous.  I have been nothing but "please" and "thank you" and smiles all through dinner.  I was pretty upset, but instead of making her wait, we paid the bill.  Instead of not tipping, we tipped.  I walked out first.  Servers did not say thank you to me, but did so to my friend, which I fully expected.

My friend said that in his country, service is expected and they get paid to deliver it.  A tip would only be given on the rare occasion that a server went above and beyond expectation with exceptional service.  He would have left nothing, no tip.  I left them more than nothing, which in retrospect, was the wrong message.  So, instead, Takara servers, here is my message.  I will never eat at your establishment again.  Thank you.  =)
author: Nancy S.

description:
I like this place for it's authenticiy and atmosphere. Not impressed by the service though. The waitress took the order quickly and I guess she mistaken my order of Tanin-Don to Ten-Don since she didn't bother to look at where my finger pointed So when the order came I told her it was wrong. She didn't look apologetic or whatnot, just look at me and waited for me to say something. I didn't care, I took the Ten-Don. Lucky I wasn't craving for anything. 

Other things, my friends ordered chirashi and ton-katsu. They gave her extra bowl of rice for the chirashi, which was weird.  And brought  fried oyster for the ton-kansu order which she finally switched with other table.

Overall I would still come back to try other items in the menu.
author: Di J.

description: I went here today just as it opened at 11:30. Our party consist of 5 people, two of those babies so we need to put them on car seats. We asked for a table for 5 so that we could put the car seat on the chair. We were told by the manager (a guy) to either take a booth tight enough for 4 people or a table for 4. The place was empty so I asked what's the problem about giving us a bigger table. The manager keeps on talking to the waitress and not addressing us directly. When I ask the waitress if the manager speaks English, she says he speaks perfect English. Then why the hell would he not address us directly? So disrespectful. And the waitress snobbishly says it is a very busy restaurant as if to justify why it could not accommodate a request for a bigger table. This is the worst customer service I have experienced for a long time. My advise to potential customers, go find some other Japanese place to eat. This place has decent food, but the customer service has sunk so low you are better off spending your money elsewhere.
author: San B.

description: I ordered fried oyster, chicken teriyaki, and pork cutlet, a 3 item combo for 26.50,  However they screwed up my ordered and acted as though it was my fault.  Chicken teriyaki and the pork cutlet are dry.  I can not comment on the fried oyster since they never served it but instead they gave me tempura.  The tempura was OK.  However the highlight of my experience is when the old waiter chased us down the hall because we did not leave a tip.
author: Eter W.

description: this is where i usually eat when i am at Japantown. They have good oyako don!
author: Yann M.

description:
Well, since my boyfriend and I never actually ate inside, I can't comment on the actual quality of the food, but here's the reason why we didn't try the food...

 We walked inside, ready to order some take-out, when we happened to glance over to our left and see the comments the health inspector had left in a report for this place. The third thing Takara was to do was to "clean up the rodent excrement in the kitchen." Note that that it didn't even look like they were suppose to exterminate the rodents, just clean up the excrement.

 Suffice to say, it lowered our appetites and made us a wee bit nervous, so we turned around and walked out.
author: Inga G.

description: Nice wide selection of both veggie rolls and set menus. I had the tofu steak dinner which came with salad, soup, rice and green tea ice cream for a very reasonable price. This complex has plentiful parking downstairs that doesn't charge outrageous fees like everywhere else in the city.
author: Carolyn A.

description: I finally had a chance to dine in with my friend a couple weeks ago . I had the ika mentai which tasted pretty interesting ... kinda like dried squid with spicy cod roe . It was not bad ... only thing is that they give you a very small proportion . The grilled oysters were pretty good ... they were very smooth but they tasted the same as regular fresh oysters . The wafu steak was alright ... the sauce and topping that came with was good & tasted interesting . I asked for medium rare but I felt like the steak was too well done . They gave us a green tea ice cream to share at the end . The green tea ice cream tasted alright ... there wasn't any strong green tea flavor to it though . I was really full at the end of the meal . This restaurant is not bad , but fails to impress me . And for that , Takara deserves a solid 3 stars .
author: Eileen L.

description:
Their lunch bento special $7.50! was what caught my eye. in the same floor there is another place that has lunch special with better choices (not just bento box but curry, udon, donburi, etc) I forgot the name of the restaurant though. 

I believe this place is great for lunch if you want to save a few bucks. I prefer the $10 lunch Bento special @ Benihana though and if you want to pay 5$ more you get the teppanyaki!
author: Lucy L.

description:
For about 3 years I worked very close to Japantown (lucky me!), so I would frequent it several times a week for lunch or dinner. Takara was usually my destination. I have been to probably 70% of the Japanese restaurants in SF and Takara is undoubtedly my favorite. It reminds me of so many restaurants I've been to in Japan.  If you want authentic and tasty Japanese fare and excellent service, then come here. The bento boxes are perfect for lunch and the shabu-shabu, sushi, sashimi, and sukiyaki are all delicious.  I've never had to wait more than a few minutes for a table, either for lunch or dinner. This place is kind of hidden away, which helps! They have a regular dining room as well as a sushi bar and tatami room for groups.  

Takara is the (sake)bomb!  

Sorry...I couldn't resist.
author: Aimee G.

description:
Japanese food like my grandma makes!  We're not talking fancy schmancy sushi rolls.  We're not talking platters of exotic sashimi. No.  That's not what grandma makes when we come over for dinner.  

We're talking yummy freshly made yosenabe heated at your table.  And the traditional combo dinner that includes rice, miso soup (lots of miso!), and dessert.  Their green tea was the real stuff, thick and bright green.  They even have ochazuke on the menu which is something I associate with mom making whenever we weren't feeling well.   That's a bowl of rice with green tea poured over it, and leftover meats, veggies, and pickled things thrown in.  We tried the sashimi and it was good and came with a giant pile of freshly shredded daikon which is totally essential.  Thanks Mom for forcing me to eat the daikon for years until I finally learned to love it.

Ah.  Japanese comfort food made the way I know it.  The best part that tipped the stars from 4 to 5?  They have ANKIMO!!   And they serve a deliciously huge portion too.

Oishii for reals, y'all.
author: Courtney Y.

description:
I'm spoiled, I admit, I don't usually like ordering sushi outside of Japan. But if I'm going to get sushi outside of Japan, I'm going to Takara. They're consistent, the owner is kind, and it's great ambiance. 

Their  chawanmushi egg custard is really good too. You can't go wrong here!
author: Drew Y.

description:
This is a generous 3-star review that is dedicated to the fish...  a 5-star freshness factor!!  The sake was wonderful, hamachi, like butt'a, the toro, awesome, smooth texture! A downside was the uni... not so firm, but not exactly bad tasting, either. Same for the albacore, which had the texture of being partially cooked. Still, it tasted pretty good.

As for the rest of the experience? 2-stars. Here's why:

Less than good Service: 
1. Slower than molasses in winter. (waiter) 
2. The sushi chef, unpleasant. (Just 'cuz I don't speak Japanese doesn't mean I don't know when you're belittling a staff member in front of everyone) -- plus, dude, we're customers. Would it kill ya to be a little nice to us? We were only asking you for help 'cause we didn't want to share the soy sauce dish. : \
3. The check. Took for freakin' ever to arrive. But that was better than... 
4. The hamachi collar -- it NEVER made it to us. Guess the waiter was still shaken from the stern talking to by the chef and forgot to order it. 

Yes, the fish was fresh and yummy. Yes, it was a holiday week, but we were really surprised they were out of ama ebi (a big favorite!). Yes, the little amuse bouche of the gelatin mushroom thing was really tasty. We were both really surprised! Also, while to some this may be somewhat of a no-brainer, the miso soup was really good.

Yet...
No. It's never okay to berate staff in front of customers. 
Nor is it okay in my book to be rude to paying customers.
No, it's not cool that we didn't get a key part of our order (at least we weren't charged for it). Plus, we wouldn't have ordered extra rice if we'd known the hamachi collar was gonna be a no-show.

So, based on this experience...
No. I don't think I'll be back.
author: Tiffinie T.

description:
This used to be my brother's favorite sushi restaurant - one of those hidden gems.  And my brother KNOWS fish.  Fishing, fish eating, fish cooking, fish filleting.  We took him there for his birthday last night and pretty much walked out disappointed.  

Turns out, the sushi chef that used to own the restaurant recently sold it in January.  He stayed on for 2 months after to transition, but is now off to find a new place - in Hawaii or Japan.  San Francisco just suffered a great loss because Takara really isn't the same.  Most of the fish was a little bland.  Not gone bad, but just bland.  And hamachi kama was tough - hey, I can make better hamachi kama - so that's just sad.

However, the raw clams on the half shell were amazing.  And their toro was indulgently fatty-fat.  The Uni was generously proportioned and extremely fresh - and I don't even eat uni.  The menu is also fairly extensive including some great post-sushi rice porridges and multiple different varieties of miso soup.  There was no wait on a Wednesday night, and street parking is somewhat decent that far up the Japantown strip.  Also, my family can drive anyone nuts, and even though we were in full force last night, the waitress still took it all with a smile, kept up a constant flow of hot tea, and made everyone feel comfortable and at home.  It went with the whole ambianceless, hole-in-the-wall feel.
author: Audrey T.

description: i went here for the first time while doing a weekend vacation in San Francisco, and I was happy with it.  My family and I ordered a variety of things, including some nigiri sushi, appetizers, and main dishes.  Some of the highlights were the pickle dish, grilled beef tongue, and halibut.  Overall it was a great experience, but for the pricing and the hype of the articles hanging outside, I was expecting a little more.  There was nothing wrong by any means, but just was not my favorite place ever.  I would definitely go back; the food was extremely tasty.  Just cannot say that it is the best ever.
author: Mike C.

description:
I will kill you all if this place disappears*

Simply authentic and amazing. 

Expect a wait here, but only because there's only three Japanese hosts that run this family owned place in Miyako Mall of Japantown. When we went with my uncle,  we had to hint subtly to him to stay and wait as he's usually the impatient one when it comes to restaurants. There was a young French couple waiting just after us and after 20 minutes of waiting, the girl was growing restless and left. Unfortunately for them, they missed on out this food and several parties were leaving at the same time this Sunday evening. 

When we were seated, we were presented with menus and matcha green tea. We had the young Japanese waitress and after running back and forth trying to serve everyone, we finally ordered the iron pot rice set meal that consisted of steam crab, bamboo and mushroom rice (very much like the one I had in Asakusa, Tokyo) with a side of egg custard and sashimi, chirashi sushi, and tempura set meal. Okay, seriously the best Japanese I've had in the Bay Area (and yes, I have been to Japan from Tokyo to Osaka). 

For our long wait, we got a complimentary ice cream (choice of either green tea, red bean, or vanilla) in addition to the two ice cream already included in the set meals. 

My aunt was tearing up a bit afters from the tasty meal. Damn, it was good. And that's why Takara means "treasure" in Japanese. 

*With sunshine and unicorns :)
author: Kenny L.

description:
Takara is a great sushi place that has authentic dishes and a nice atmosphere. Situated inside of the peace plaza, you have to search around past many other sushi restaurants to find it. My pal Tiffany L. and I were seated right away on a Friday night and were quickly served.

The place is very casual and the prices are reasonable. We ordered a sashimi plate that came with rice, an egg dish, and miso soup for under $20. We ordered some small rolls on the side. I would recommend the soft shell crab tempura roll. It was very good. I also loved the little green tea ice cream that we shared at the end. It always tastes so good and cleans the palette.
author: Natalie N.

description:
Good sushi requires not just the freshest fish but the highest quality seaweed and rice.  Takara's seaweed and rice is top notch.  

By the way, the best way to judge a sushi place is by the tamago.  If they don't care enough to make the tamago fresh and tasty, they are just second class.
author: Wakako U.

description: Great authentic food, good portion, love the chawanmushi.  Staff could be friendlier with a little smile.
author: Melvin T.

description:
Solid Japanese comfort food located next to the Kabuki Hotel in the mall behind IchibanKan. Others indicated that service could be slow, but I found that they were well staffed, inviting and generally attentive, especially with all our add-on requests to keep our kiddies occupied.

They have various sushi and sashimi offerings but we focused on their teishoku or set menus of grilled fish, tonkatsu and tempura which came with egg custard (chawan mushi), miso soup and a small portion of ice cream. They also had a number of small plates, all old stand-bys.

Japanese owned and frequented by locals, warm and inviting comfort food: what else do you need to cap off an afternoon poking around Japantown?
author: David P.

description:
Small, fresh, a bit pricey, tasty portions of perfection.  We were hoping to catch another restaurant but of course, it was closed by the time we arrived. Staff was chill, fast, effin' efficient! Little wait time to serve, with appetizers arriving after the main feast... whatever. It's all good here.

 Crazy tasty tobiko ;')
author: Holly B.

description:
This restaurant is surprisingly delicious considering it is located in a mall. I come here when I am craving some "interesting" cuisine that I haven't been able to find at any other restaurant. I usually just order from the large appetizer menu during dinnertime. I call it my Japanese version of tapas. I typically get the hamachi kama, grilled squid, squid with spicy cod roe, some amaebi nigiri (I really only order this so I can eat the deep fried head!) and braised pork belly. 

It's kind of hard to find someone who will come here and join me for dinner because I eat things that freak people out, but I guarantee you that just like how the butcher usually saves the best cuts of meat for himself, people who know food secretly laugh at all you folks who squirm at the parts of animals that are actually the most amazing parts. fear factor, my ass.
author: Jade L.

description:
The dining experience I had here became one of those "which shall not be named." The kind that you never want to remember or talk about again. I feel like everyone's had a few of those - those meals where the slightest remembrance evokes stong feelings of disgust.....The tuna I had was so chewy, almost like there was gristle in the center. REally gross, I don't think I'm overstating. Then, they totally scammed us on the shabu shabu. I asked the lady if one order was enough for 2 people and she told me that we needed 2 orders, which was so enormous, it ended up being the largest waste of food that I've ever participated in in my life. And service was awful.
I am completely disgusted by all of it...felt compelled to write and hopefully purge the experience from my mind forever.
author: Steph K.

description: I'd say a 3.5, but sadly that doesn't exist, and Takara just doesn't cut it for a 4. The restaurant is good, but there is so much good sushi in SF that it can't compete. Some of the cooked dishes are pretty good - I liked the softshell crab and the makarel plate. The sashimi is good, but not amazing or really inventive. I thought the staff though was really friendly and the service was pretty fast. I wouldn't not go back (I don't care if this is a double negative), but I wouldn't rush there again either.
author: Ashley H.

description: I ordered the lunch box ($7.50) that includes tonkatsu, california roll, tempura, salad, rice, and miso soup. Everything tasted yummy, crispy, and fresh. The only complaint I had was that the servers pretended to pour more tea into your cup. Half the time they just added a tablespoon of tea which bothered me immensely because I like to drink massive amounts of green tea during my meals. I found myself trying to justify their actions, but I really just think they're a bunch of frugal fish.
author: Natasha P.

description:
If you are in Japantown it is one of the better spots, hence the three stars. If anywhere else, 2 stars. 

Very standard taste, better than average service. I found the menu to be confusing with weird combinations. Limited sushi menu.

Miso Soup was not so good.  

Decor was on the okay side.
author: Dan W.

description:
Boyfriend and I visited Takara on a saturday evening around 7pm.  The place was about 80% full at the time so we didn't have to wait (nice compared to some of the other Japanese restaurants in the more crowded areas of the mall).

Pros:  The waiter and waitress which served us during the course of our evening were friendly, quick, and attentive.  We ordered two combo set dinners, and they came quickly.  I was surprised my meal came with an order of chawan-mushi, the japanese egg custard appetizer - after all, I just ordered a nigiri combination.  It was very good, the custard was light, the broth was savory, and the stuff inside was cooked to the right consistency that it didn't become textureless mush.

The food itself was fresh and good.  I thought it was awesome that it took less than 10 minutes from my initial ordering to have everything lain on the table.  Boyfriend's chicken teriyaki took the longest, but we had more than enough food to eat in the meanwhile.  

Also happy that with their nigiri special, it came with the salmon roe nigiri and squid.  Most places just serve the standard fare.

Finally, the price was right.  Both dinners were about $20 a piece, and I definitely felt like I wasn't ripped off.

Cons:  Their nigiri special was nothing uber spectacular.  I was slightly disappointed that it didn't come with tako.  

Bottom line:  I'd definitely go back, since I saw they had shabu shabu, nabe pots, and some really good looking sukiyakis.
author: Minnie L.

description:
As a Japanese man, this is my go-to place for Sushi in the City  What the other reviews say are, in fact, true.  Service could be on the slower side and sometimes the owner / sushi chef is mean to the wait staff.  However, these are the elements that make a good authentic Japanese restaurant. 

When I go with more than a party of 2, I usually sit at the tables and order non-sushi items.  My thought there is Sushi, especially Nigiri's (raw fish on top of rice) is only good when you get them one-by-one at the sushi bar.  When i feel like sushi, I sit at the sushi bar and order directly from the Sushi chef.  If you put in a reservation, they will know your name so I recommend that if you'd like the real sushi experience.  

They make their own soy sauce.  Their "gyoku" (egg) has a good flavor as well as their Anago sauce.  These are three items that you should know are staples at an authentic Sushi house.  

Finally, the sushi chef is personable and will interact with you.  For me, this is a critical piece.  Just 

While there may be other sushi places that are good in the city and outside, Takara rises above all others in value - relatively affordable, top quality fish and a personalized dining experience.  

Definitely recommended if you are Japanese and longing for the authentic cuisine in Japantown.
author: Ken Y.

description: I'm so disappointed. Sashimi is not fresh at all. Bad flavor and bad experience. Don't worth the money.
author: Melody Z.

description:
It's been 10 years since I was in SF but this place is still the real deal in Jtown. The patrons are mainly Japanese, which suggests authenticity. I come for the ochazuke (tea steeped rice) and the deep fried oysters. Yum! And the prices are a steal.
It's been 10 years since I was in SF but this place is still the real deal in Jtown. The patrons are mainly Japanese, which suggests authenticity. I come for the ochazuke (tea steeped rice) and the deep fried oysters. Yum! And the prices are a steal.
author: Steven W.

description:
This is a wonderful Japanese-owned Japanese-chefed Japanese-fooded Japan-towned place.  It's tucked away in one of the two buildings of the Peace Plaza and close to the hotel.  It has a rather unassuming exterior.  Its neighbor is a reflexology salon.  Once inside, however, the windows will look out to pedestrians and a Japanese-style garden that is settling to the mind and appetite.  

I've eaten here quite a bit and the food is impeccable.  The food is excellently prepared and it comes in plates conscientiously arranged.  Main dishes are accompanied by garnish or salad that seem to have been cut and chopped fresh immediately before it arrived on your plate.

There's wonderful variety.  And while an extensive menu is something that should make a fan of Japanese food wary, here, the menu is a generous offering of dishes you want to try on the current visit and future return trips.

The basics are prepared expertly.  I love the clams in sake on cold days.  My favorite is the chawanmushi.  No other place's approaches the taste and texture of Takara's.  It is egg with a texture akin to soft tofu.   Bits of chicken, shredded fishcake, mushroom, and a single gingko nut sits on the bottom of the cup.  It's marvelous in its simplicity.  The dinner sets include it along with a dollop of some preparation that is part tiny side-dish, part amuse-bouche.

One important note:  This Takara has no affiliation with the Takara in Oakland (at the old Isobune location).  The nerve of that place in Oakland.
author: jeffrey k.

description:
I think this place might have topped my list of "bad serviced restaurants" and I don't have too many on that list.

A group of us (3) were interested in this restaurant because it looked so busy and mostly Japanese ladies who were in line in front of us made us think it was more authentic than the other restaurants in the plaza.  We walked in, the restaurant was busy in the front end and only 1 out or 4 tables filled in the back end.  No one greeted.  No one looked at us.  No one acknowledged we existed next to the sign that read "Please wait here for hostess to be seated."  A group of about 5-6 followed after us and were complaining of the wait and we were probably waiting for 3-4 minutes before they decided to leave.  We probably should have done the same.

Sushi wasn't great.  Food was not very tasty.  Service sucked.  A very rude waitress (older, shoulder length hair lady) exclaimed "NO!" when one of our party asked for a glass of water and kept walking by.  At first we were shocked...maybe she said "I Know?"  Apparently not...since no water came.  The other waitress who took our order came back and finally brought us some water.  

We came and tried Takara but I will never come back.
author: judy l.

description:
I brought a few co-workers to this restaurant this passed weekend. Two of them have never ate Japanese food. I thought this place wouldn't scare them too much. 

From the feedback I received, they enjoyed the food and was a great student with learning how to use chopsticks for the first time. The really liked the veggie tempura and the chicken.

I, on the other hand, have had this before in other Japanese restaurant. The place was in a secluded location which was pretty nice since it was quiet. The server was friendly and we got out food in a decent amount of time.

When i went to go pay, I accidentally wrote the total amount in the tip line and the front person caught it. Thank goodness he was honest or else the server would have just loved me. Hahaha!

Overall, my party enjoyed themselves as well as I so I'm giving this restaurant two thumbs up.
author: Jay C.

description: I wanted to like this place but the service, though friendly, was completely unorganized.  We were seated and then employees kept running by us without taking our order.  After we did order the food came out sporadically (there were 4 of us).  The only reason I am giving it 2 stars is that the food was pretty good, but not good enough to go back.
author: Chris B.

description: I recently ate here twice based upon Yelp reviews and was pleased.  Am not 100% knowledgeable about Japanese food but knew enough to know it was fresh, well presented, etc.  However, I recently had lunch with friend I hadn't seen in 5 years and we were catching up.  It was 1:00, we had paid bill... and we sat down at 1l:30.  The waiter came to table and said we had to leave (because some obviously important people wanted our booth)!  There were plenty of tables in the back, however.  We did leave; I mentioned that we would not return after being "thrown out".  His only reply was "Sorry."  Strange...
author: Valerie B.

description:
Note: I am commenting on the sushi bar only -- I haven't eaten in the main restaurant nor have I ordered from its menu.

Abe-san and Shin-san are two of the best sushi chef's I've encountered in San Francisco.  Personable and accessible, they make hanging out at the sushi bar more laid back and less fussy than hanging out with the sushi chefs at, say, Blowfish.

Abe-san's cutting technique for sashimi guarantees that you feel like every bite is substantial  (he cuts in thicker, shorter chunks than other chefs, who rely in thinner, broader slices to make it appear as if you've received more food than you actually have).  The modest addition of clover sprouts and cuke slices to a sashimi plate makes the whole affair seem more well-rounded.

They also do a great job with nigiri sushi, particularly saba.  Their uni is always fresh and vibrant with flavor.  They also do a great job with unagi.

Another reason this restaurant is so terrific (from a sushi standpoint) is that you don't have to buy fixed slices of sashimi.  For instance, toro is priced at 7 pieces, but you don't always want that much toro (or other cuts).  It's nice to be able to say, I'd like 4 pieces of toro and 4 pieces of hamachi, without raising an eyebrow or getting that "we don't mix it up like that" look.

I highly recommend them for lunch, when you can get some personal attention (they close at 2PM for the afternoon, and won't seat you at the sushi bar after 1:30PM).
author: Andrew L.

description: Good food, terrible service. It was a busy Saturday night, however so I wouldn't rule out a return to this restaurant on a weeknight. I'd be able to rate it at least one star better.  I had a rice bowl with oysters which was quite de-lish. The tempura appetizer was light and lovely, too.
author: Paula H.

description:
First off i don't understand why this place is so HOT.  It's humid and warm.  Its like a sauna in there.  Get ready to take off your jacket.  No joke!  They ration ice and my ice water was melting from the heat.  The restaurant is small and service is horribly slow and bad!  I would have given this pace 2/5, but service was a -1!  Our party of 5 was smashed into a regular table...cramp  Large menu is nice, but my food was ok at best so idk if that large menu helps :/

Food was ok.  Got the SASHIMI DINNER.  I would not order again...Fish pieces were think and short.  The fish had nice texture, but lacked that delicious fattiness.  It tasted ok, nothing special.  App salad was oily and with no flavor.  Miso soup was weak/ok at best.  Picked veg was w.e.  Rice was regular rice.  Red bean ice cream was pretty good(best thing i ate all night).  Shiso leaf was a nice touch, but nothing stood out.  That steamed egg thing was brought out separately and very SLOW AND LATE that the time it arrived i thought it was dessert.  it was smooth but SALTY as ever!  Food there seems to be pricy ie 2.5 a coke...Toro isn't market price...i wonder what kind of grade their fish is...Rolls +3 dollars more than i am use to ie dragon roll is 15 and dinner plates kind of small...Service was crap!  person came by to take our order, drop off food, desert, and give us the check.  Water glass not not filled.  Couldn't flag down wait staff.  Asked for a refill that took several minutes.  I saw the ice pitcher and should have walked over there myself...
author: Stan L.

description:
I ate here a few months ago because I heard it made the list of SF's top 100 restaurants, and because I am constantly trying to recapture a hint of my absolute favorite sushi restaurant EVER, the Takara in Santa Cruz. Make no mistake: they are not the same. (If you have eaten at the one in SC and tasted their AMAZING creamy seasame dressing, and have managed to find a suitable counterpart here in SF, you MUST tell me.) 

The seaweed salad was delish, and the tuna was melt-in-your-mouth fresh, but the tempura shrimp roll was not made as specified on the menu. Instead of avocado and cucumber, it came with lettuce and mayonaise (ick ick ick!!) in it. I called the host over and said I didn't think it was made as stated, and he curtly told me "no, no, that's how it's made" and strode away. Well, I asked our waitress for a menu and sure enough, it stated avo and cucumber. When I pointed it out to the waitress, she was very nice about it and replaced our roll with one that had the proper ingredients. The food was good in the end, but the atmosphere is rather blah as it's inside the Japantown mall. All-in-all, I probably wouldn't choose to eat here again.
author: Jasmine F.

description:
Came here in quite a hurry as a friend was picking me up to go and see Chapelle at Punchline. Yeah!

Had their Hamachi which was good.
But they had  Oyako Ojiya (rice porridge with salmon roe and salmon thus 'Oyako' meaning 'family'). This was great as far a i was concerned because I had a mysterious stomach problem that was manifesting itself on random occasion for not apparent reason. The Ojiya was just what i was looking for and with a lot of meat and eggs; it was picture purrrfect.

It is a place you can go even if you are feeling under the weather and get a home cooked meal to nurse over your ills, whatever they maybe.

(BTW, About Chapelle, Did we wait 2 hours in line? Did we turn off our phones, get padded down by a big dude and check in my ipod? YES YES YES
Did we see Chapelle? NO. Did Ticketmaster screw me over again? YES YES YES - Curses Ticketmaster!!  I'll get you next time!!!.)
author: Tak H.

description:
I am hooked.  For raw fish - this is THE place to go if you don't care about slow service and the lack of ambiance.  A plain hole in the wall  with authentic excellent sushi, at a decent price.   And an "excellent" from me, on sushi, is a rarity.

I admit that I ended up here every time when I couldn't get a seat at Ino Sushi, the little sushi joint, next door.  But this place never disappointed me.  And no reservations required either.  After yet  another excellent experience at the sushi bar last night, I decided that it's worth a review. 

From sake, hamachi, maguro, hirame, amaebi to uni and toro, there was not a damn piece of sushi that I could complain about.  And even the hamachi kama was good, even though I don't usually get anything cooked here.  

Some basics to cover: 
- For a much faster service, sit at the bar.  
- If you sit a the bar, speak the very limited Japanese that you know -- order sushi in Japanese, and say thank you in Japanese ("arigato" - pronounced "a-li-ga-do")  when the sushi chefs hand you your sushi -- when the sushi chefs boss the wait staff around for you to get you what want, you know you are in good hands. 
- Know the difference between sake (the drink) and sake (salmon).  If you don't know the difference, you don't belong here.    
- Know the difference between nigri and sashimi.  Again, if you don't know the difference, go somewhere else.   
- If you ever see a big Japanese tourist group inside, go somewhere else and come back next time.
- Don't bother with the dessert here.  You are better off hopping to the ice cream place across J-town.  You'd need the exercise after all that good sushi....
author: Shirley F.

description:
It was such a surprise to see a menu that wasn't dedicated to sushi or bento boxes.  Instead, you can order full meal with great appetizers.  The best way to do this is go with a group of friends and split the appetizers and then dive into your main course.  Beware that the food dinner sets comes with lot of food.

I go the broiled fish dinner set, which came with this yummy egg custard, soup, and green tea ice cream.  We shared spinach with bonita flakes, chilled tofu with bonita flakes, clam soup cooked in sake.

One thing about this place is they seem busy regardless of what time you stop for dinner.  Service is horrible here, you basically wait and wait for a table, the reason being is that there's no one to bus.  Once you finally get seated, you wait and wait to order.  The food comes after a bit, then you never see your waiter again until to wave him down for the bill.  It honestly isn't his fault because the other 2 waitress don't do much, and he's running his ass off.  So yes, tip him well, the poor man is actually trying to do it all, so don't punish him.
author: Twist' D.

description:
I'm not from around here, but when I do go into the city, I always have to stop by Japan Town. So my family and I decided to give this place a try, so we got here right when dinner opened. I ordered the 2 entree dinner which came with tons of sides, some I didnt reconize. Teriyaki salmon was really good, and the fried oysters. The salad that it came with was good as well; I would like to know what that dressing was! Miso soup tasted like typical miso soup. Nothing special. Good stuff. These weird pickled vegetables came with my dinner also. The stringy one was okay, had a weird texture. But the yellow, whatever it was, was NASTY! First of all, how do you bite into this thing? And the flavor was yuuuuuuuck! I didn't care for the egg custard either. Took one bite and couldn't touch it again! It was like eating raw egg whites!

My father-in-law ordered what I ordered. Reactions were the same as mine.

My husband ordered, I think the sashimi deluxe. He liked it. He said there were fish in it that he's never had in a sashimi deluxe before. He was surprized yet impressed with this!

My kids and sister-in-law order the miso ramen. They seemed to like it. I had a little taste and it wasn't bad. The broth was good. 

I would probably eat here again. Saw somethings on the menu that I wanted to try. But I do want to try the other Japanese restaurants in the J-Town mall whenever I'm in town.

Another note: customer service was pretty good. People were nice. Tipping policy was weird though.
author: C C.

description:
Really good, solid sushi.  The atmosphere is nothing to write home about, and actually it was a bit gross... saw some flies hanging out on our table and the wall.  But, the food made up for that.

I shared the spicy tuna roll, california roll, a vegetarian roll, gyoza.... and I had the albacore nigiri.  The nigiri by far was my favorite item.  The fish was really fresh.  

Service was good, and our watiress was funny.  The best part about going to the J-town mall is the parking lot.  Really cheap rates.
author: Sarah F.

description: We had lunch box with Teriyaki and Tempura.  The price was just amazing at $6.95 and the service was very good.  But the Tempura was very greasy and Teriyaki sauce was too starchy.  If they could improve on these, I am happy to give them 5 stars.
author: Chris K.

description:
I almost didn't want to write this review....it's hard enough to get a table as it is... 

This place, hidden away in the shopping mall in Japan Town, looks like nothing when you pass it by - or at least it looks like thumpteen other sushi-cookie-cutting places around - but....this place has some of the best sushi in San Francisco and their prices are ridiculously low. 
Love the Tekka Don and the Saba is just great. Probably eaten here about ten times or more - but not in the past six months. Time to go back. Loved this place. Ok, now I'm hungry. Me need sushi.

Only reason this place doesn't get a five star rating from me is that the ambience is well...kinda lacking.
author: Rich S.

description:
This place being in a mall kind of lowered my expectations for this place, but I was pleasantly surprised. I had the salmon iron pot which came with a good-sized side of sashimi (tuna, salmon, yellowtail) and the savory custard, plus a ball of red bean ice cream. The chicken karage was pretty good. The sashimi was of excellent quality. Washed down with a big Sapporo.

Only thing, the booths are small, especially when two big guys are sitting next to each other (yes, I was one of them).
author: Maximillian M.

description:
This place is the hidden gem of Japantown. Reasonably priced, it serves more authentic food than can be found elsewhere ... where else can you order natto and konnyaku?

Brownie points for that one.

I love this place for two reasons:

One, the waiters/waitresses ACTUALLY speak Japanese and are incredibly friendly, offering to substitute any portions of meals upon inquiry. 

Two, it's much quieter and calmer, and the food is served hot, and presented well. Sure, they might not specialize in chicken teriyaki and the other items most tourists tend to order, but they excel in their noodles, soups and other non-sushi items -- which I have found other restaurants tend to butcher. Their sashimi has always been fresh with the tuna bright red, the salmon without a lot of white lines. 

I don't usually order their sushi, but the few times I have, it's always been nigiri and it's always been impeccably prepared, in the true Japanese style. It's the only restaurant I've found that serves things how I remember them at restaurants in Tokyo, and that alone makes it one of my favourites.
author: Amy S.

description:
Yeah, it was...okay.  Nothing spectacular, everything decent.  There were four of us: two ordered different types of udon, one of us had the sushi dinner set, and the other had several rolls and the gyoza appetizers.  I'd say it was a solid B / B+ for everything.  But I've had much better udon (plumper, crispier tempura for the udon) and the sushi looked kind of...okay, not noteworthy nor that excited to be there. 

Servers were all super-nice and -attentive. 

Not a destination spot but ok for a pre-movie dinner or if you're more concerned about finding a spot in Japantown.
author: enmi k.

description:
Where do you take 3 adults and 2 kids after Cherry Blossom Festival? Luckily we were early enough and found lots of seating available at Takara. And of course, they had kids' favorite - noodles.

We shared the following:
Dragon Roll ($14.75) - slightly spicy bbq sauce. adults approved. kids detested.
Futomaki ($6) - 4 massive cuts.
Hamachi Sashimi ($18.50 for 7 pcs) - nice fat cuts of fish.
Takara Sashimi Plate ($29 for 19 pcs) -Tuna, Yellowtail, Salmon, Striped Bass, Octopus, Albacore and White fish - wide assortment of popular fish. presented with shaved daikon and shiso leaves. i like that.
Ohitashi ($3.75) - boiled spinach with bonito on top. nice shoyu base at the bottom.
Chawan Mushi ($3.50) - steamed egg custard was nice and smooth. delicate flavors with a few slices of mushroom, a piece of chicken, a little fish cake. nicely done.
Miso Ramen ($8.50) - not a typical ramen because the noodles weren't the egg variety kind. these were thinner and tasted like white flour noodles. lots of seaweed, light on the bamboo. half a hard boiled egg. it was ok.
Nabeyaki Udon ($11.95) - we all loved the udon broth flavored with sweet mirin, cabbage, mushroom, bamboo, and topped with a carrot and shrimp tempura. udon noodles were nice and chewy too.

The place was a little understaffed as the restaurant filled up and no one came back to refill our tea or water. Understandable but not acceptable.

Overall not the cheapest option in J-town, but they satisfied our needs and had space for the under 6 yrs of age kids.
author: Cindy W.

description:
It's good, but not as good as they claim they should get with the prices and amount of food given.  

The portions are small.  The service is bad. The food, actually isn't horrible-just not much given to base it on.
author: Jac T.

description:
My favorite Japanese restaurant... I'm a fan of pretty much everything on their menu. The grilled steak, porridge, shabu shabu, rolls, noodles and so much more... I could eat here everyday and never get tired. 

I also like the fact that Takara is sort of hidden, on the other "not as busy" mall of J-Town... the one the tourists don't know about!

ps-they validate.
author: Monica C.

description: I have such a soft spot for this place, since I've been going here for years. lately, tho, fish quality has declined and service has been atrocious. stick to the rolls, and do anything to get your hands on a 2nd helping of chawanmushi.
author: Sasha R.

description:
This place is great!  Fresh, well prepared, and just delicious.

The sashimi was very good, my girlfriend's beef teriyaki was very tender, and the grilled mackerel was small but pretty good.  the steamed egg is great!  And ice cream at the end is an often overlooked pleasure =)

Don't come here for the atmosphere, and service is ok... somewhat chaotic at times.
author: shaun l.

description:
Japantown weirds me out and I don't know why. I'm not trying to be a hater but it boggles my mind that there can be so many freaking japanese restaurants crammed into one mall. They all look the same. They all offer the same. They're all priced the same. I can't think of another place where competitive advantage simply doesn't exist. Thoughts, HBS?

Picking Takara over all the other choices came down to who was open on a Monday evening and who had a slightly above average Yelp rating. I wasn't hungry so I only ordered gomae (spinach salad with sesame dressing) and hamachi nigiri. Gomae was fine but the portion was a third of the size of the seaweed salad. I felt cheated. The hamachi was barely average. Not the freshest nor the tastiest. My friend ordered the hot pot, which was impressive. I had a tiny sip of broth and thought it was flavorful. I'm not a hot pot person though so I have little to compare it with. 

Takara's saving grace was the service. The man and woman holding down the joint were funny and entertaining. They had a great spirit about them and I appreciate that. If they spiced up the place and got fresher fish, I would recommend them to anyone roaming around the mall.
author: Susan L.

description: I generally like this restaurant but I will likely quit eating there. The answer is simple. Each time I've eaten a box lunch there the sides and bottoms of the box is sticky because it has not been properly washed. It truly makes me wonder about the kitchen and its cleanliness.
author: Steven T.

description:
Service was very friendly and the food was pretty good but it just wasn't anything special.  We were here on a weekend evening and the place was pretty dead.  All of us ordered dinners which were very generously sized.  The appetizer custard that came with our meals was interesting.  I didn't like it but others I was with really enjoyed it.  My tempura was crispy and the prawns delicious and fresh.  The green tea ice cream was fantastic.

Overall quite good but nothing really made it stand out to me.
author: Hélène M.

description:
I like Takara because it has dishes that I never see at other Japanese restaurants...but maybe that's because i go to completely Americanized sushi places...and havent tried that hard to find otherwise in my area.

Anyways, I like that they have chawanmushi (savory custard cups), butakakuni (stewed pork belly in a sweet broth), grilled shisamo (pregnant capelin), and ochazuke (basically a rice bowl with a tea broth-- yeah it took a second helping for me to like it too....) To me, this is perfect Japanese comfort food in the winter time. Warm, saucy, and savory; ummmm, hits the spot.

And they do yosenabe and shabu shabu on a small scale which is nice when only one person wants it.  They also serve red bean ice cream as an alternative to the typical, ubiquitous green tea. 

One negative is that the bathrooms are outside in the strip mall, and it's not a big deal, except that I go to the bathroom every time I'm there because i drink way too much of their green tea just because it's the powdered kind and I trick myself into believing it's expensive matcha...
author: Momu T.

description: i really like their lunch special with udon and katsu don! it was very filling and authentic!
author: Louis O.

description:
I'm no japanese-food expert, but the food tasted great, and it was at a reasonable price! The two of us ended up ordering more than we could handle, for about $39. I'd definitely go here again...
... unless I was on a date, in which case this place seems a little run-down. The walls look old. And the restroom is outside, in the mall, and therefore not too clean.
author: Eyw d.

description:
First of the customers to order. On Valentine's Day, the 3 combo order for $25 dollars. As the combo, I got : Beef teriyaki (was okay that day), Tempura (really fresh and can actually taste the vege not like other japanese places), and sashimi (thickly sliced and fresh). 

I also order fatty tuna roll with onion in which I thought it was a handroll but came out to be tiny rolls. Was no complete satisfied. It was 7$ for 6 small diny pieces. The fatty tuna was actually thinly sliced. But I guess either than the 28.95$ combo that has fatty tuna rolls, you will not find fatty tuna in other foods that they have. 

My bf on the other hand got tempura soba, he said it was good (:

I strongly recommend :
-the 3 item combo-$25 (the appetizer,steamed egg with mushroom, etc is tasty.) And meal = totally worth it. Comes with ice cream of your choice in the end

the $28.95 sushi combo

Fatty tuna roll, although expensive for the proportion you get, there is not much of fatty tuna sushi listed in their menu :( Sadly. But their fatty tuna really melts when it reaches the mouth. Hahaha

Definitely needa do this again!
author: Vivian L.

description:
Takara is one of the better restaurants in japanTown. If you are looking for traditional, and cost effective fare... this place is a tie with Sapporo-Ya. For more creative/fusion, I prefer On The Bridge. 

Good consistent food & service.
author: Greg K.

description:
Today, the first day of eating as part of a conference began.  I had high hopes and lofty dreams.  The first plan was to make our way to Saigon Sandwiches to get the best banh mi on the planet and order enough to get us through lunch for the week (seeing as how hotel and conference related fare was expensive and not all that tasty).  Unfortunately, we got there 30 minutes late (they close at 6:00 p.m.).  So, we decide to just get something to eat instead and planned to visit 8 Immortals (Chinese Seafood place).  On the way, we stopped and looked around Japantown and stumbled onto Takara.  On the outside were reviews of the place and it had managed to become one of the 100 best in the Bay Area.  We were intrigued, but I still wanted to go with our original choice.  Well, we truck all the way over to 8 Immortals and they were CLOSED on Wednesdays.  Doh!  

So we make our way back to Takara.  Our waiter was super nice and we opted to go with more of a yakitori experience here.  We ordered everything that was available (e.g., chicken wings sold out) on the grilled menu.  And I have to say, everything was just okay.  

Sure there were a couple of stand outs.  The black cod neck (though it looked burnt) was exceptional.  The tofu and mushroom dish (not a grilled item, but I don't remember where it came from) was repeater.  It was really soft tofu that was fried then placed in a thickened mushroom broth.  

The eggplant with benito flakes had a unpleasant burnt taste to it.  Everything else was just okay.  On the good side, we did scare the waiter with how much we ordered.
author: Bob C.

description: Good deal on their bento lunch boxes. Can't complain about their food too much. Standard fare and taste. One minus, the teriyaki beef that my aunt got looked like shredded beef with bits of fat in it. I've eaten here about 5-6 times now and its always about the same. Not bad, not great but ---good. My elderly aunties like this place and they have that old lady jumpy stomach thing. And if they don't complain, then its worth going back.
author: Barb B.

description: Zero star. I ordered cold soba. And I got this hot water down Japanese soysause with soba. It's way too soft and it's disgusting. My friends ordered their shabu shabu.  The meat is way too thich for hot pot and the soggy veggies taste like it sat in the fridge for 4,5 days.  The waiter love serving hot plate and hot soup next to ur face. The environment is old, smell, and gives u a tire feeling. I am lazy to even write this review
author: Jeff H.

description:
This place would be five stars if the waitresses didn't completely forget us in the corner of the sushi bar area.  

"Excuse me, can we ord-"
"Um, we're ready to-"

Default to sushi chef with a little wave. He utters something in Japanese and in a few minutes the waitress comes over breathing heavily.  hee hoo hee hoo...and in a small voice takes our order and says thank you. 

Lickety Split and ten minutes later our sushi comes to the table.  Seriously rush service since they new we had been chillin' forevers at our table.  (Which, btw, had a hole in the ground to put our feet/legs in)  

The sushi was good, the sashimi was great, the ochazuke (rice w/ tea soup thingy) was good.  It was all good...

I love sushi and I really like this place.  The waitresses just need a shot of espresso.

Next time I'll sit in the main area and hopefully get served a little quicker.
author: Jay H.

description: The ramen is below the average. The service from the waiter is worst. If you have a stroller, they won't even let you in. Considering there are so many choices in Japan town, I would avoid this place.
author: cy c.

description:
Came here after for lunch as they were one of the few places that were open for New Years Day Lunch.

I realized I was in trouble when the Miso soup was overly salted, even more salted than those instant miso soup packages. However, I am thinking maybe an inexperienced kitchen staffer prepared this and perhaps the rest of the meal would be ok. 

I got the combo of beef terayaki, saba shioyaki, and tempura and she got udon and katsudon.

Her dish came first and the udon broth was basically soy sauce, some dashi, and green onions. Again, overly salty with no flavor.. the had no clue how to make soups or broth. The Katsudon was not bad, so for a dish its 1/2.
