My combo of beef terayaki, saba shioyaki, and tempura came out. Beet was grilled but not flavored. It was just covered in terayaki sauce and had large amounts of fat and gristle. The Tempura was good ( you have to try to mess up tempura) and the saba was not bad as well.

I give ti 3 stars as it has some value, you get a lot for your money. I am prob not coming here again but I didnt feel my money was completely wasted. 

service was slow.
author: B H.

description:
Well, this will be a review for the Japanese cuisine primarily since surprisingly, I wasn't in the mood for sushi (WTF?!).  Anyhow, I had a few things such as the seaweed salad, udon and donburi and they all were really good.    Service was a bit mixed up but probably b/c my Nihongo is crap.  They thought I said two when I thought I said "hitori"

Anyhow, once I got my order placed and the food started coming, I was definitely happy!  The lunch combo I had was only $10 and it was plenty to make you stuffed.  The tea is good too and all in all it's a nice spot that's a bit more low key since it's not in the main Japantown restaurant area towards the back/hotel. 

Good for groups too and most of the clientele were true Nihonjins!
author: Gene X.

description:
Who is the round-eye that has convinced the sushi bars in this city that the rest of us don't like real sushi?  It's like I have to order natto (texture is similar to mucus) to prove to the sushi chef that it's ok to give me the good stuff.   I can see that the chef has two types of Uni at the bar.   One from Santa Barbara and the other from Hokaido, and I always get the one from Santa Barbara first until I order the booger roll.  Then, the chef feels bad and gives me something decent.  I never have to put up with this in NYC.  

Pretty solid sushi here, nothing stellar...except for the live ama-ebi (sweet shrimp) which they keep in a tank out front.  I'd compare it to very good, fresh spiny lobster.  Service is horrendous - it takes an act of Allah to get a refill on water.  It's not necessarily worth the trip, but I'd stop in if Ino Sushi next door was closed.
author: Will H.

description:
I went to Takara for sushi, and I have to say, they were pretty good at that. We got a spicy tuna roll and several different nigiri combinations, as well as edamame, and it was all fantastic. The rest, however, wasn't so great.

The restaurant smelled a bit funny and was very drab looking. It took a long time to place our order, get our food, and a ridiculous amount of time to get the bill. We wanted to reorder sushi but I feared it would take so long we opted just to leave. They also were quite slow to refill tea -- another waitress other than our own actually did.

If you don't mind the lax atmosphere, however, come grab sushi here. the maguro was to die for.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
I had dinner with my friend.

I had their OMAKASE nigiri which was the best deal I had compared to few other places I had been this summer. And their price is much more reasonable than Sushi Ran where I had Omakase nigiri lunch.
Since TAKARA's omakase was dinner, I even got CHAWAN-MUSHI in addition. And, Takara's dinner price was $29.95.

Takara's Omakase had UNI, TORO, and AMAEBI.

The only negative thing about TAKARA is the service. The service was very poor. I should deduct 1-star from my rating.
author: Yu T.

description:
This might be my favorite Japanese restaurant in the city. Located in the mall in J-town, it is a little hard to find, but well worth looking. The people who work here are very attentive and extremely nice. Because this place is always so crowded, the employees really have their work cut out for them, but as they are running around they do everything with a smile. 

I love the tempura udon here. The portion is so big so I never leave here hungry. My friend loves the cold soba too. Prices are very reasonable and the location is great if you want to catch a movie at Sundance Kabuki afterwards.
author: Dana H.

description:
We had a great trip to Japantown yesterday and it was topped off by a nice lunch at Takara. We had 2 bento boxes, one with teryaki chicken (recomended for our daughter instead of a bowl of rice with tempura)That saved us 2 dollars. Nice move on the waiter. Mine was with white tuna which was very nice. My husband had a square bowl with mixed sushi,, He liked it,but did not like the pickled stuff. I ate that and gave him some of my sashimi. The one thing I really noticed was lots of locals. Probably because its cheap/good. But the place is run down and a bit dirty for my liking. There were wrappers on the floor and that just seems lazy/sloppy to me. 
The food was over all good. Service very nice/fast and accurate... prices good/cheap for decent quality.  This is not a fancy place, but definately a very good value. 3 of us got out of there for 31 dollars plus tip. 
I might go again. But there are other places for a few bucks more that I am also interested in trying.

***On a side note,,,, Japantown has much improved. I used to live there 25 years ago or so... then it was getting very run down and by the early 90s it was ucky... The atmosphere of the area was clean and well kept.. Nice going to the powers that take care of the place. Thanks.
author: Ann L.

description:
D. and I were starving and almost desperate for a decent sushi place that wasn't tainted by the 1970's Disneyish Mall feel of the rest of Japantown.  We had read about Takara on Yelp, but in our famished state is was difficult to locate it.  We almost had to settle for less.....and I'm glad we kept looking.

The fish and rolls were well prepared.  Fresh and well portioned.  We had our usual springtime (warm weather regardless of season) cold soba and veg tempura-everything arrived from the kitchen so quickly our heads spun.

I'm nicking off a star because it simply wasn't "stellar".  Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed myself, but it's got a ways to go before I feel that 5th star is really warranted.

What most impressed us were the prices, however.  The service was warm and not at all wanting for more.  We ate well for less than $50, and since we're both students this made the soba-sushi-tempura satisfaction all the more complete.  We'll go again when we're in town.
author: E G.

description:
Only giving it two stars because the waitress was polite. Friend and I had the Nabeyaki udon and it truthfully was pretty bad. The broth kinda tasted a bit bitter and foul. The shitake mushrooms were not thoroughly soaked in water before service, therefore it was bitter and very hard to chew. I admit that I did have high expectations because the people were actually Japanese. I've had udon that were made by Chinese people who ran Japanese restaurants so I though this would be a great opportunity to try more authentic cuisine (not saying other people can't do it). We also ordered a spicy tuna roll. It was VERY disappointing. It had a rotten, tongue lingering (not in a good way) taste. I'm tempted to give it one star instead.

EDIT- Sorry, this is truly a one star. Nothing justifies for it to deserve more than that.
author: Nikki Y.

description: I love their dinner sets. I ordered the Yakizakana dinner when I was here which consisted of grilled salted mackerel, egg custard, miso soup, and a dessert. The egg custard is so soft and delicious here, and the grilled mackerel was crispy and delicious as well. The only thing that I have to complain about was the miso soup, which was so very salty, and the prices which are pretty high for this kind of food...16 dollars for a dinner!
author: Linda N.

description:
A great place to come to when you have a bunch of you and you can get the most for your buck.  I really like the custard stuff they give you in the beginning after you order a dinner, I LOVE IT. 

The service is great, and they seem authentic japanese which is always a plus because then you at least have the idea that you're going to get somewhat good food. But Takara is solid, great japanese food. I suggest it for anyone who has a craving for good japanese food, an empty stomach, and want's the most for their buck. 

[APPROVED]
author: Eric T.

description: This place reminds me of the casual places I went to in Japan.  The local business crowd go there and drink and relax after work,,,(in Japan that is).  To be honest the food was not fantastic.  However, my expectations were not high.  I like the casual atmosphere and will go again.  Really felt like a cheap Japanese place in Japan.
author: Christopher F.

description:
Just recently had dinner here with one of my gfs and we love love sushi. we're both raw fish eaters and damn proud of it!  I had asked her to come to JTown with me to explore it a bit & grab some yummy food..we yelped cheap good eats round JTown and Takara came up..it's in the same plaza that I get my hair done, so we decided to check it out.

They give you a wrapped hot towel to clean your hands with, nice touch.  I had the green tea. 

We decided on the Sashimi Moriawase $16.95 as that seemed like the best deal, plus an additional Shrimp Tempura Roll $5.95

When the food arrived, my very first thought was, "wow...those portions are TINY" and they really were.  The cuts of sashimi were teeny tiny. so sad looking, they sat on a TON of stringy white radishes...probably in an effort to make the dish look bigger than it was.  The sashimi itself was ok.  I've had sashimi before where it just melts in your mouth, but this was just..ho-hum. passable. 

The roll was only 4 pieces and they too were small, if you put the 4 pieces together, they were only about 2 1/2 inches long (IF that). 

That's too bad that in JTown a sushi restaurant would skimp so badly on their portions...maybe that's why people think it's a deal...but your getting very little fish for a little amount. 

not impressed
author: Lulu C.

description:
I went here based on reviews and would go back again in the future.

Sushi Freshness: 8 (1-Won't eat; 5 - what you would find at Safeway; 10 - to die for). The sushi was fresh; much better than typical Japanese resturants. 

Sushi Creativity: 5 (1- Typical nigri rolls; 5 - typical nigri rolls plus some unique ones; 10 - Many different rolls). If you are looking for exotic rolls, they dont offer much variety. More the standard offerings.

Service: 8 & 5 - Attentive and friendly service in the beginning. When it got crowded, they seemed to forget us and had to ask twice for the bill.

Cleanliness: 7

Overall: 8 

Would recommend Takara. One advantage is that its not located in the J-Town food court, nor by some of the busier sections of the mall. I usually dont travel to that side by the hotel. Being located there they probably get a lot less foot traffic than other resturants on the other side. We also ordered some of their small dishes. Chicken kara-age, salmon and crab salad were also very good.
author: Mark K.

description: My Japanese friend really wanted to take me there for dinner. I ordered the large nigiri sushi combo. Meal was preceded with many nice touches (thick, fresh, pickled daikon; chawan mushi; tasty miso soup) that were very fresh and well-prepared. The head of the (amaebi) shrimp came a little after my entree arrived which was a nice touch. My friend's entree didn't come for almost 15 mins after mine did, which was unfortunate. But, when it did, it was worth waiting for: THICK, juicy, tender Hamachi Kama (the jaws of the hamachi.) The sushi was very fresh, nicely presented, unusual choices from the chef, and I was very pleased.  The atmosphere is lively, not fancy. I recommend this place. As Japanese food goes in this town, it's right up there.
author: C. S.

description:
Takara means "treasure" in Japanese, so it's no surprise that it's tucked into a little corner of the Miyako Mall in Japantown Center.  My family and I go there quite often and we can all agree that you can't beat the quality for the price you're paying.  The lunch special is such a good deal - I like to order the tuna bento box.  Yummy.  

Also, they do have pretty good nigiri sushi (not the best), as my sister had ordered the special of the day (I can't remember exactly what it was).  The special item changes every day, I think...Well, if you're looking a inexpensive place to order a bento box, I would recommend Takara.  

-1 for service: it can be tough to get the waitress' attention b/c there are only two waitresses, I think.  Otherwise, they are very polite and explain the menu well.
author: Stephen H.

description:
Takara is always so crowded for both lunch and dinner.
Their lunch is decent, and anything you order tastes right. 
Even the "Beef/Chicken Teriyaki" dish invented for American culture is irresistible.
I like how they have "Chawanmushi" and lot more real Japanese dishes. 
Dining is casual, prices and service are decent.
Takara is definitely one of my favorite Japanese restaurants.
author: Mai K.

description:
On a quiet night of January 2nd, irritated and stressed out by the end of the holidays, I decided on sushi as the ultimate upper for my tired body and low spirit.

My first choice was Ino.  I heard many great things and was eager to try it.  But Ino was, inevitably, closed like many other shops in J-Town for the most celebrated holiday among Japanese, also known as the first 3 days of the year.  

Takara stayed open.  The tank of abalone was quite encouraging.  Live seafood is always a good sign.  Sitting down at the sushi bar, I was greeted warmly with 2 small complimentary appetizers (dry seaweed salad, only so-so; and meatballs, which were quite tasty).  I ordered the following items:

2 pcs of Kanpachi
3 pcs of cockle---  absolutely delicious.  With the flavor of giant clam yet the interesting texture of octopus, every bite was delightfully yummy.  This was apparently a UK favorite as well, recalling that Andrew Zimmern ate a bunch in Wales (anyway).  Oh, and it did NOT come with the price of giant clam.
2 pcs of Hirami--- wonderfully drizzled in ponzu...  heavenly...
1 pc of Hamachi belly
1 pc of Saba--- the best Saba I've ever had.  The meat was so tender and tangy.  I love them on the more vinegar-y side.
1 pc of Uni--- as my dessert
1 order of Matsutake (Pine) mushroom soup in a small teapot--- When I was little, every time we had Japanese food we had to order the teapot soup.  For nostalgic reason I asked for it.  Also I have this thing for mushrooms in general.  The soup was fragrant and light.  The perfect ending to my meal.
1 small hot sake

As delicious and piggy-portion as my meal was, the best part has yet to be revealed....  (drum roll please):

The bill came to be $45.80.  What!!  

Takara, I am soooooo coming back!!
author: Jiajia C.

description:
This is my fave place for melt in your UNAGI.  I immediately ordered 2 orders, and a chawanmushi. The chawanmushi was to warm my belly up from all that vino. 

In pops the unagi in my mouth. Mmm....so yummy. Just melting in my mouth. The chawanmushi was warm, a perfect consistency of smooth custard, with slices of mushroom and chicken. 
We ordered totally fresh amaebi, which are still swimming in the tank outside the restaurant. Very sweet. The fried amaebi heads came after. Mymm Mymm....so good, no dipping sauce needed.
salmon nigiri- fresh

We also had the ankimo (monkfish liver with ponzu sauce) -good, and the Shiokara (squid with traditional japanese salted marinade). They definitely did not forget the salt.

Conclusion:
Kinda expensive but definitely worth it.
Good, consistent, fresh fish.
Tons of appetizer plates to choose from.
UNAGI. you've gotta try it. you won't regret.
author: Heidi L.

description:
Takara used to be a decent place for Japanese food but upon the most and LAST visit, it is the worst service and food place!  The sashimi was not up to par.  There is a live shrimp tank outside but the amaebi was disappointedly, previously FROZEN!  Plus the server was rude!  He got made when togo containers were requested.  He said that there's additional fee for the containers.  I said that's fine.  When I asked for soy sauce packets, he became more frustrated and angry because he would have to charge for it too.  I could not believe his attitude.  

I hope the service and food quality improves.  But in the meantime, it needs much improvement.
author: L T.

description: I came here for the first time with Audrey last night for dinner  .  The food was flavorful, but the dirty dishes are another story. She ordered the combo tonkatsu & teriyaki meal while I had the rock & roll and agedashi tofu.  Our waitress brought out the agedashi tofu with two small share bowls and spoons.  When I lifted the top bowl I noticed that the bottom bowl still had left over soy sauce in it.  I sent the dishes back and the waitress brought new bowls & spoons out.  I glanced over the dishes again and saw that there was a food particle on the new spoon so I sent it back again. Needless to say, I kept inspecting everything all night as I was scared I'd find a hair in my food next.  I don't think I'll be returning. Prices are much higher than other restaurants in the plaza.
author: Stacey L.

description:
I just had dinner there with my family.  I think the food was OK but I thought the service was abominable. 

My grilled salmon was well prepared but I felt it was not very hot, just warm.   The churashizushi was good and seemed well prepared.   Average price before taxes and tips was $20 per person.  

  But,  I thought it was not respectful the way the waiter interacted with me.   I felt rushed, not by just the server who came to our table the most but by several staff who wanted to know whether we were ready to order.  I don't like parts of my service being picked up as the waiter goes by without so much as asking if he can remove items.   I just don't like it and found it disrespectful.   Not a single moment of pleasantness came from the waitstaff -- and they just don't seem to understand that or the tradition of service one expects from a Japanese restaurant.     I felt it odd that when we came in we did not get an "Irrashaymase!" but some sort of greeting that just seemed mistimed and not welcoming at all.        But, nonetheless, I tipped 15%.    What was so odd was the waiter later came to remind me that I hadn't been served my ice cream just before we were leaving.   You would think I would be grateful but I felt that it was a purposeful slight to hand me the bill without being served my dessert and only coming back to serve it only because he felt he got a decent tip.  
Meh, I've experienced better so I'll go elsewhere next time.

I just felt there was somthing off with this restaurant, though the food was certainly good enough.   The service was just lacking.
author: Oak L.

description:
You gotta be kidding???
They dont seem to know how to run their business.
Gross!
Their carpet was sticky- stained...nasty. 
There was Wasabi residue on the bottom of my plate, and lip stick stain on my tea cup. They must have NOT been washed completely.
Chicken was over cooked.
Their service was unbelievably terrible!- order taking slow and forgetful...And DON'T put your finger in my plate! 
But they like talking about tipping...FUNNY!

Hello !??  Has the SF Health Department checked this place before??
author: N M.

description:
Good Food!

Certainly not the best I've had but very good. We had a Nabe that consisted of seafood, vegetables based with a very tasty broth. I should have asked questions because I thought there was meat in the Nabe which would have been great. Will definitely keep this on the list for the future so I can try other things.
author: Alan N.

description:
The first time my BF and I went, we were very impressed with the quality of the sushi.  We also enjoyed our agedashi tofu, fried oysters, and complimentary egg custard appetizer and ice cream.  However, follow up visits have not been so enjoyable.  It seems like service gets worse every time we go.  Last Friday, we went and it took forever to order and get our food.  

It will probably be a while before we go back again, which is too bad because they probably have the best sushi in the city.
author: C L.

description:
I know the rule is to avoid sushi on Sundays and Mondays, but I just got back from vacation and want some raw fish.

Good thing this place was open Monday night.  J-town is so empty Mon nights, but that's also a plus, given easy parking and lots of seats at the Kabuki theater.

The food was good, but the service was too attentive!  Maybe it was just so empty that the wait staff kept coming over.  We thought we were rude for lingering.

Still, if that's the only bad thing I can think of and was so happy after my sushi and green tea ice cream, then it's all right.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Now this is authentic. They are often short staffed, so be patient. Prices are very reasonable for lunch, especially the udon + donburi combos (I can only eat half of it). 
I usually go for the tempura because they do it right. The donburis are good and I love sansai udon. Oh, and their chawanmushi are pretty tasty too.
author: lisa m.

description:
I love the food but the service sucks. For Lunch time, there is a tanned skinny young waitress is so bitch to take my order and for Dinner time, there is a young skinny gotee with shoulder lengthed guy is very rude after we spoke Japanese to another waitress. If you are giving that fat ass attitude to your own people then go to Castro and serve the tables. 

I keep coming back because of the food but I had enough, 
NOT coming back
author: June P.

description: I've walked by this place so many times and I've never been interested. I'd given up on J-town sushi and never knew this place served anything else. To my surprise I've now found a new favorite winter dish. The salmon and salmon roe zousui (japanese porridge) is really comforting and the broth is delicious. It's a combination of big salmon pieces, roe, rice, egg, green onions and dashi stock baked in a claypot. I also ordered a free side of ume boshi (pickled plums). Don't be fooled by the choice of ochazuke. While it's probably good, choose the zousui. It's unlikely that anything could be better. Eat your heart out East Village.
author: Dana O.

description:
Their sushi is good.  All others are so so.

We were one of the very first customers when Takara opened many years ago.  I still remember that all the staffs and the owner nervously staring at us for our reaction, and we were uncomfortable because we were the only customer in the evening.  The food was fantastic, however.  It was just like the ones I had in Japan.  It was definitely the best in Japan Town, and I became a big fan of this restaurant since then.  They served the best authentic katei ryori (home style dishes).  I usually went there for dinner sets and nabe ryori (hot pots) that you cook yourself on your table, and it was such a joy to see my guests and friends enjoy it.  About $30-40 per person is not cheap but is money well spent.  I would give full 5 stars if things are still the same.

Sadly, the good old days are gone.  The menu is still the same but the food is now mediocre.  The food is less tasty,  nabe is much smaller and the ingredients lack variety.  I don't see a particular reason to go there.  I really really miss the good old days.  I wish the owner gets the old recipe back and serve the food just the way it used to be.  The food is not the only one that was changed.  The staffs used to be extremely courteous, but now they are noticeably less courteous and attentive.  I will check it out again some time later to see if things changed.

ps. By the way, their sushi is still good.  Especially, Chirashi such lunchbox is my all time favorite.  The sushi is fresh and house sauce is very good.
author: Chris M.

description:
4.5 STARS::
   [How you give it 5??]

Dozo Irrashaimase!

Yes, the main staff is really Japanese, is Y they really speak Japanese (all you below whom were oso amaze that they talk dat talk).

Yes, everything we've ever ordered (and eat 10) was/is supremely authentic and tasty, but for the few times they got frazz from been biz-E, some dishes came to the table lukewarm:  also, do not go near closing time, mainly b coz they will refuse to make NEthing that takes time (past closing).   .   .   It's the law!

N JOY!!!
author: Clifford L.

description:
I LOVE J-town! I wish I could live there!
Backed by my adorable Japanese landlady, I took her advice and coerced my pal into driving across town (in the opposite direction of my dr. appt. she was also chaufferrng me to). 
Takara delivered a well rounded Japanese meal in a very effiicient manner (considering they were booked solid with the 
SF music tech summitt next door). 
We shared a lunch set with mackerel, rice, all the trimmings, the veggie tempura, and soba ramen; followed by some organic sake (deligntful).  Would've made my Sachi-san proud!
author: Sandrita R.

description: This place is one of my all-time favorite Japanese restaurants. I have tried many dishes on their menu, but my favorite is the teriyaki chicken! I love how traditional this place is, yet casual. It's perfect for people that have little to no experience at Japanese restaurants. I wish I lived closer, I would get it everyday!!
author: Kayla M.

description:
Great food, but building is in desperate need of a remodel.  The staff is actually Japanese which is nice.  The food is really fresh, especially the sashimi.  

I love the combo dishes, and usually get the salted mackrel, Tuna Sashimi, and Tempura.  The pitchers of beer are reasonable, but it's sort of hard to find.  

Nothing fancy, but just good straight up Japanese food.
author: Mark K.

description:
This place is good, if you're reading this you should give it a try.  Here's why:

1.  The sushi was fresh and delicious and the sushi chefs were legit.  No offense, but I want a grumpy old Japanese guy making my sushi that occasionally glares at me like I'm not worthy to eat his food.  Otherwise, it's like I'm getting McSushi and I feel cheated.
2.  The non-sushi dishes were equally delicious and delicate... for instance, the Taramiso... reflecting the fact that their flavors aren't super Americanized.  The portions aren't Americanized either.  And let's face it, Americans are fatties (including me) and it does us good to eat smaller portions of food that aren't loaded with salt and fat.
3.  The prices were reasonable.
4.  The place looks and feels like something you'd find in Japan.
5.  The other reviews with scores below 3 stars are either based on incorrect/outdated information (I can confirm the rating is 90 as of 12/23/09) or are from retarded reviewers (you know, the ppl that take a star away becaue their copy of the receipt had a wrinkle in it... the food costs more than a Mcdonald's value meal... the waitress didn't give them a lap dance, etc.).  I didn't have any problem with the service... yeah they were busy, and we had to wait sometimes, but we made it in and out for dinner within an hour which seems normal for the city... and nothing seemed particularly microwaved or reconstituted like some of the other reviews have claimed.  I didn't try the Chawanmushi.
6.  They have rice balls and they're tasty.  Tasty rice balls makes my wife happy.  If you've never had a tasty rice ball, you need to try one here (onigiri, try the salmon one).  If I could choose to be reincarnated as something, it would be the warm center of a tasty rice ball.
7.  You're spending time on Yelp reading reviews.  The whole point of Yelp is to try places for yourself and tell people what you think.  So give it a try and write a review.
author: Chris P.

description:
Actually, my family and I wanted to go to Ino Sushi (we have been there before and it is excellent) but it was closed when we visited Japantown so we gave this place a try.  

We weren't sure if this place was any good but to our surprise, it was really good.  We ordered mostly nigiri's and they were all good.  They used quality fish and the rice was perfect.  I recommend this place if you want good sushi.
author: toddy h.

description:
Hands down, the food was good. Quality sushi. I wasn't that jazzed about what they did with the Agedashi tofu but it was still good. 

Service was mediocre at best. Other tables around us were also feeling ignored.
author: lori p.

description: This is 1 of the 2 Japanese restaurants I've tried on this side of the mall, both super-authentic.  We ordered 2 of the 3 traditional apetizers available : the grilled fish & eggplant dishes.  Of course the egg custard soup was some of the best I've ever tasted, heaven!  Sushi was so good!!!
author: Linda L.

description:
it's been over 2 years since i've eating here but the quality of food has remained GOOD. the price of the lunch bento box has gone up to $7.95 but still worth it. it was packed when my husband, our little guy and i went there the wait staff never walked they RAN in there.
 i ordered my bento box=DELISH!! chicken teriyaki, tempura, california roll, salad, miso soup and rice=YUM!! my husband had the broiled mackeral though it took about 15 minutes it was tender and lightly salted=GOOD.
author: Jo K.

description:
Fabulous!
* Fresh sushi/sashimi
* Smooth, classic chawan-mushi included in your dinner set
* Traditional Japanese dishes 
* Good value for $$
author: susan f.

description:
Traditional & fantastic.

Now THIS is where we should have gone that night we decided to go to Ozumo's instead...  The menu at Takara is so extensive, offering opportunity after opportunity to try and taste things you've never heard of before.  And they made me fall in love with a new dish I had previously never eaten - Chawan Mushi - a Japanese egg custard that came as part of our meal; a savory custard that I loved so much I went home and learned how to make it for myself.

You can get anything your heart never knew it could dream of at this place, and the prices are great.

One bad thing was that they discouraged us from sitting at the sushi bar (which we love to do because you get to know the sushi chefs that way).  Also, we ordered a TON because we wanted to sample everything that caught our eye, and they unfortunately brought it all out at once instead of course by course, so we ran out of room at our tiny table - which is the only reason I'm deducting stars.

Try it, you'll like it.
author: D. L.

description: We eat here fairly regularly, I find the food excellent and fresh, what needs addressing by the owner is the interior, it is looking old and sad.  The nice thing about this place is that is owned by Japanese and employs Japanese, it is the real deal.  While I agree with lots of others that the service is slow, I think it is more because there just aren't enough staff scheduled. I commend the staff for their friendliness especially Gaku, he is knowledgeable, sweet and very very helpful.
author: Michael C.

description:
People here keep complaining about the health inspector score of 74, let me tell you a little background why this score is so low, they used to score around 92 in Takara but one time they had a pipe burst (not theirs but the building's) and flooded the place. This was just a few months ago. This affected their score and made it pretty low. I do not contest the other things that might have lowered their score but the place is not a 74, if you are really nit picky maybe its an 86. Take these health ratings with a grain of salt, our local Chinese restaurant 1 block from my apartment gets a score of 100, and believe me they do not deserve it. 

Anyway the Japanese food in Takara is generally the best in Japan town, that might be a bold statement but in my opinion this is true, and I have eaten at all of them. I used to take Japanese classes near JTown and pretty much went to all of the restaurants in the area. Mind you the food in Maki is generally better and the sushi at Kiss Sushi is definitely at a different level, but mind you these two that I mentioned are significantly more expensive than Takara. If you compare Takara with the other places in JTown like Mifune, Iroha, Sapporo, Kitsune, those others who serve the "usual" Japanese American fare, then Takara is safely the better of the lot. 

I suggest going for lunch since the Bento Box lunch is one of the best deals in town. They have really good tenpura, miso soup that taste authentic, the sushi is good (not the best) but as a general restaurant it is pretty good compared to the rest. 

If you want really good sushi, go to a specialized sushi place, or if your thing is ramen go to a restaurant that specializes in ramen. It is pretty unfair to rate a restaurant with an extensive menu such as theirs and compare a specialized dish to a restaurant that specializes in that dish. But all in all, Takara is still the place to go in JTown if you want good Japanese everyday fare. 

Don't believe me? I dare you to go to each of the "general" Japanese restaurants in Japan town and listen to the people speaking and figure out who is speaking Japanese. I will bet you that aside from maybe Tanpopo, Takara has the highest percentage of Japanese locals eating at a restaurant in JTown (Benihana being the lowest). This fact alone shows you something about a restaurant.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Most of the people I went with agreed the food was decent but not stellar, and it was a bit more expensive than places with similar quality food.  (15-20% or so)  If there were half stars my spicy scallop roll would have bumped it up to 3.5 stars, if I go back I will highly consider just getting some miso and a couple of those.

I am not a terrible stickler for service, but one entree didn't come out until almost everyone else was mostly done eating, and getting the check was  a slow process.
author: Zac K.

description: Takara is one of the better Sushi place in SF.  Though they don't have a large range of fish as Sushi Ran in Sausalito it does a better job at the sushi basics.  Ken at the Sushi  bar is fantastic and a true profesional and will take care of you!  The rice Temp spot on.  Give it a try.
author: David C.

description:
first off, the carpet is disgusting.  not surprising a previous reviewer said their score was low.  

what's up with the seaweed salad having no flavor whatsoever?

and for the vegetarians out there, this place isn't for you unless you're satisfied with veggie tempura.  and any sushi/japanese restaurant who gives you a strange look for asking if they'd make tamago maki (since they already do tamago nigiri) is pretty lame.

the one nice thing is the free ice cream.
author: Karen O.

description:
Dear consumers, 
  if you enjoy annoying, loud, sloppy service from 8 waiters all too busy to think, less than mediocre sushi, really loud, annoying but slightly snobbish babies, inflated and misleading menus, loud busboys, waiting 30 minutes for the check, Chinese rice at a Japanese restaurant, lip stick on your glass, and large parties waiting in line and breathing down your neck hoping that you will leave, then Takara Japanese Restaurant is the place for you.com
author: Frank S.

description:
getting here a little early allowed us to sit down and take in some of the feel and atmosphere of this old nook in nihon machi.  i have found myself more and more on this side of the peace plaza with ino, oizakaya, ikkyu and of course the cute tellers at union bank ;P

okay, so nobu entered...
looked at the four of us and said WTF??!! with his eyes telling us to pick up our FXXX'N beers from the table and go over to the counter area in the smaller back room.

we went along with everything nobu ordered, which was perfect.

6-7 waves of incredible omakase with the highlights being the kohada, aji and of course the fried up bones and atama of three of the selections we ate.  never got that service when i came here with my pops as a youth!!!

the servers were friendly but quite busy last nite as they seemed to forget about the beers we ordered and one time came back with two rounds of sapporo rather than just the one.  of course we didn't send it back!

the view of six friends all grubbing and double-fisting their nama (draft not naked!!) biiru was a sight and holy shit!!  since when did this place become soo busy??  a monday and a packed house at 8.  awesome!

we all ended up paying like 55 bucks each which covered the omakase (very generous cuts but not overwhelming) and like 4 beers ea.  not bad at all!  

walking out practically crying from laughter on roasting eachother and one nameless bud attempting to pee on me from the other side of the stall in the bathroom..one of the sweet waiters remarked on how i resemble a drunken sarariman...GUILTY! 

great place for a group of 6 to 7 pals, not a date spot.  will try the extended izakaya menu next time ;P

gochisou sama!!!! (you can't say itadikimasu mr.roundeye!!  unless you are about to start another meal...)
author: omar b.

description:
I'd recommend anyone who is looking for excellent Japanese sushi in Japan Town. 

I went sushi bar for dinner. 
I feel comfortable when I see the Japanese sushi chef.
I had Ika, Hamachi, Anago, Awabi and uni.
Everything was fresh and so good.
And the sushi chef recommended Aji.
I never had Aji before but I tried. It was sooooo good! 
There are green onion, ginger on top.
I didn't know Aji was so good.
I want to eat Aji every time when I go back.
Finally I had my favorite Salmon skin roll.
It was the best Salmon skin roll I never had.
I tried so many different sushi bar but Takara is the best.
Everybody should try it!

I want to try different dinner menu too. 
Because there are so many to chose from. 
Combination dinner, Iron rice pot, Shabu shabu, 
Hamachi Kama, Taramiso,etc......

I can't wait to come back!!

The restaurant was clean. And I like the Orchid. 
They put some Orchid between the table. 
It looks so nice!!
author: Ken N.

description:
I love this place.  Yes, the service can be a little slow, but the sushi/sashimi makes up for it.  I always seem to be telling people to go here and try it...my bad.  I need to be more selective in who I tell. :P  I've had the best toro and uni here, as well as the freshest amaebi (right out of the tank in front).  MMmmm.  I try not to cloud my palate with all the tempura-teriyaki offerings; I stick with the fresh sashimi and nigiri.  Straight to the sushi bar is the way to go...always the best experience there with the chefs.  Have a sapporo or sake with them.

People have often told me to go nextdoor to Ino and honestly, that place is all hype...but that's another review.

Edit 12/28/07
It's been awhile since I've been back.  My last time was pre-Yelp days.  And at that time, the sushi was fresh and ok.  It still is, although not as top-grade as I once remember.  They changed owners a few years ago, so that may have something to do with it.  

Last night might be the last time I go here...ok, maybe just for 2007.  We took a seat at the sushi bar, and asked the waitress to see the menu.  We weren't planning to order from the dinner menu, just the appetizer.  The sushi chef pretty much flipped out and told us we couldn't order dinner at the sushi bar.  We were ok with not ordering, but that didn't stop him from practically ripping the waitresses head off for bringing a menu to us.  From that point on, the service was pretty slow and forgetful.  I had ordered a hamachi kama which never showed up.  I think the waitress mistook my ordering of gyutataki (which sucked badly...it was some sort of low grade beef that they were using) as a substitute. It took her awhile to bring me a coke.  And then when we were asking for the bill, it took like a good 15 min for them to bring the correct bill to us.  To top it off, no fresh amaebi in the tank sitting out front, which should've been the sign for us to not eat there that night.
author: JeFF T.

description:
many japanese locals, even japanese and sushi chefs will tell you takara is 'honest' japanese food. if you are a honky reviewing this place based on your experiences in tokoyo or else where in japan, as if you know anything (you probably know just as little about the rest of the united states, the very country you are from) just stfu.

my experience was wonderful, the food was not ultimately excellent by any means, but they offer many normal japanese people food items, the place smells asian, and the ladies are not entirely friendly or unfriendly. this place is by no means a sushi restaurant.

me: ika no shiokara (which is surprisingly on the permanent menu)
waitress: are you sure?
me: yes
waitress: are you sure?
me: yes
waitress: are you sure?
me: yes
waitress: *shakes head* mumbles something

A+++.
author: christopher a.

description: Sushi was so-so but the rest of the food was fine.  Nothing remarkable but nothing bad. Felt really rushed though. Food came out Instantly (not a good sign with sushi) and all at once- entrees before we even ate the soup.
author: J M.

description:
now this is real japanese sushi! tsunami, sushi groove, tokyo go go, kiji, deep sushi, etc. you're all guilty of taking a sacred food and americanizing it to the mass. how dare they! hehe. so if you're looking for authentic sushi, go to takara in japantown. this is sushi for those who truly appreciate japanese sushi. sushi aficionado, i suppose. anyway, unlike the american sushi which can be too sweet or too spicy, the takara sushi is subtle, complex and, dare i say, somewhat bland but in a pleasant way. it's quite difficult to explain it in words. you just have to experience it yourself. then you can decide if you prefer the american version or the japanese version. moi? i like both versions. i'm easy to please.

the staff is nice but sometimes painfully slow. so i'm taking away one star. thus, three stars.
author: frisco j.

description: Went to Takara particularly for the Sukiyaki. We looked forward to having Sukiyaki where you can cook at the table yourself. The food was good but it was not as good as the Sukiyaki that we had in San Diego. The pot came already with stuff in it (raw though) and the meat came separately. They just put the put on the stove, cook it there and put the meat in when we want to eat it. I wish they would have more vegie and more variety in the pot. The meat was a bit thinker than I am used to in Sukiyaki. Otherwise, the taste was good. We also ordered some rolls and other appetizer. It's good. But not the best we had ever had.
author: J V.

description: I love that you can get a mini noodle and mini donburi combo.  One friend had the sashimi and beef teriyaki combo.  The rest of us had the zaru soba combo one with oyako don and one with tanin don.  Zaru soba was very good.  Oyako don and tanin don were good but a little sweet for my taste.  I preferred the tanin don over the oyako don.  I did not try the sashimi or beef teriyaki but my friend enjoyed it very much.  This will be my go to spot when in Japantown.
author: H Y.

description: For what it is, it's very solid, and one of the best places in the J-Town center.  Great bento box deals at lunch.  Excellent dinner menu has combo dinners which come with chawan mushi, pickled veggies, soup, rice, and some kind of salad-y thing served with whatever main you get:  fish, chicken, pork, etc, and dessert (ice cream or anmitsu).  This is our go-to place for a very filling dinner.  The sushi is also decent for J-Town.  Takara is one of the few places in the center that is always busy, every day, lunch and dinner.  As with everything else, they do close a bit on the early side.  (For a full-on treat, get a massage at Sain Saine next door and a quick stop to Ichiban Kan or Harajuku down the hall before you actually eat.)
author: Isabel M.

description: If you can find Takara, you won't be disappointed.  Hidden in a hallway between the mall and the Kibuki Hotel, Takara provides authentic Japanese cuisine at reasonable prices.  The sushi selection is fantastic and raw fish is all excellent.  Service was fast and quick.  Everything was very good, definitely a place I would come back too.
author: Eric M.

description: I'm unsure if the change in ownership has affected the kitchen staff at this place as it has at the sushi counter, but if it hasn't, Takara has my recommendations for outstanding Japanese cooking in nihonmachi.  Why?  Their tonkatsu teishoku, the unofficial litmus test of a Japanese restaurant's kitchen, is spot on.  They use good dashi too.  Nice and well hidden - if you're like me and can appreciate Japanese food in SF that's NOT sushi, then this place is worth seeking out (I haven't been since they changed hands though).
author: Mori Y.

description:
i like the food, they have a pretty big menu, and different enough from what the other japanese restaurants in the area offer.  this review, though, is really to tell you that:

1. the waitlist is inside, right by the front door.  whoever's standing at the hostess desk is not a hostess and will not be pointing you to the waitlist unless you ask.  whenever you can get this person's attention.  and then you will feel like they don't care whether or not you put your name down.

2. WAIT by THE WAITLIST.  THIS MEANS INSIDE.  you will fall under the mistaken assumption that since there's about 6 sq feet of waiting space in there (and wall-to-wall carpeting makes it feel even smaller), you can wait outside in the hallway where all the other parties are.  you Will lose your table this way.  these two girls who came in after me (but tried to sign their names in before me!) got seated because they know how takara works.  and i heard 2 other parties complain about having missed their tables as well.

3. you have to flag them down for more tea. not quite as big a point about the waiting, but i like tea and since it's an asian restaurant where tea is the western world's glass of water, i shouldn't have to bug you for more.  keep it coming!
author: Janice C.

description: This place has the best soft shell crab appetizer. Tasty, light, and crispy. My friend has high praises for the toro served here. I wouldn't know since the mushy texture of sashimi grosses me out. However, if one day I get over it and want to chow down on some raw fish, this will be the place!
author: Lubs Y.

description: This is a good no-frills place if you appreciate authentic Japanese sushi. They have fresh nigiri that oozes onto my tongue, plus lots of lunch specials to choose from. My favorite lunch special is the nigiri plate with 6 pieces of nigiri (3 are chosen by the chef) and 3 pieces of sushi rolls (chosen by the chef) for about $11. Not bad. I never had raw squid before, but it was part of the chef's special and turns out to be oh so delicious.
author: Victoria N.

description: Unassuming restaurant with decent prices and fresh fish. The yakitori is good as well and they serve egg custard along with it...
author: Nicolas H.

description: They have chawanmushi here which I feel like is rare for Japanese restaurants around here (so + 1 for that).  I love the light texture of egg.  The sushi is decent, and prices are average.  I've seen people get hot pot here, but we just had sushi and a random smattering of cooked things.  Overall i'd come back if I were in Japantown for dinner.
author: Joann C.

description: My husband and I attended an afternoon double bill of 2 Japanese classic movies across the street at New People Cinema. We thought we'd round out the day with a good Japanese dinner. If Takara represents the best Japanese food in Japantown, that is unfortunate. Maybe we just don't like Japanese food as much as other Asian cuisine. We didn't enjoy any of the little soups and appetizers that arrived first. The sashimi on my combination dinner was good but the tempura was almost all soft vegetables rather than shrimp. My husband thought his fried oysters were O.K.  The Karatanba sake was good. The service was adequate. All in all, we would not return.
author: Lorinda S.

description: This is an authentic Japanese restaurant with very good fresh food.  They are reasonably priced and you get plenty to eat. The staff is very nice and helpful. I've eaten here several times over the years and never had a bad meal or experience. The sushi is delicious and fresh, the dinners are tasty and fillng and the Bento  lunch is one of the best deals in the city. Always plenty of parking on the street or in the garage.  Check it out if you want some real Japanese comfort food.
author: Sabrina L.

description: I stepped into the restaurant, waiting to be seat by a hostess or host but all I got was two girls walking back and forth without saying It'll be just a moment or even hi. I could understand that there were too many tables for to servers that were also hostess to work on but you shouldn't be rude to your customers. The tea was too hot, so I asked a server/hostess with short hair if I can get a cup of ice water. SHE SAID "NO" AND CONTINUED WALKING OFF. I Thought the food will make up for the customer service but in my perspective, it was bland and not good at all.
author: Sylvia C.

description: Solid Japanese cuisine. The waiter spoke to me in Japanese by default--how did he know I'm a weeaboo? Perhaps this is the difference between Seattle and SF Japanese restaurants.
author: Manuel W.

description: I used to LOVE this place.  I used to go to Takara for dinner at least 2-3 times a month.  Don't know what happened, but the past couple of times when I went there...I was disappointed big time.  The quality of the food has definitely deteriorated.  It's not like I ordered anything crazy, just the 3 items, but the terriyaki steak was horrible.  The fried oysters had way too much batter.  The chawanmushi was the only thing that I still enjoyed there.  The service was non-existent.  There was this server guy (hope it was his first day there) that was running around stressing everyone out.  It took forever for the food to come too.  I was glad that my friends from out of town didn't complain though.    Seems like everyone here really had a good time there though -- maybe I went on a bad night?
author: Winnie L.

description:
sushi bars with formally trained japanese chefs are rare these days. ryoko, maki and takara are the few that come to mind. most japanese restaurants are owned or have employees comprised of various asian bloodlines and skills, and most of the time, the attention to details are rather nonexistent. being ethnic chinese, born in taiwan and raised in the pacific, i suspect my palate has become a little more discerning over the years when it comes to asian food. 

at takara, the key is to sit at the sushi bar and let the chefs drive. alls one has to do as a passenger is sit back, slug the green tea, asahi or sake and enjoy the ride. 

i ate a few times in the formal dining room, but even though their dinner combos are fairly traditional and filling, they were nothing special. the fried kaki were decent. nice, fresh, plump and briny with just enough batter. the egg custard was standard as was everything else.
author: May T.

description:
yo

i really want to like this place a lot. takara is great to go to for lunch, as you can get a good amount of food for around 10 bucks per person. this is a good thing. i love getting the "mini set", which gives you your choice of donburi with either udon or soba for about 10 dollars. and portions aren't bad at all. the bento boxes are also worth it, though the mini set, however ironically named, fills me up more. the sushi i have tried so far, which isn't a lot, is not bad at all. i was actually quite surprised.

it isn't the food that i have a problem with here, cause that shit is all lovely. i just feel like the people working here need to attend a customer service seminar or something, cause i've experienced some bad bad service here. now, i understand that this isn't bushi-tei or any other high end restaurant, so i don't expect the service to be exceptional. however, there are some things you can't let slide. the second time i came here, most of us got our food (which took a long time already) except for my sister. after much more waiting, we asked about it and it turned out that our waiter had forgotten to put in her order. okay. i work in a restaurant. this happens sometimes, whatever right? but the dude forgot to put in the order AGAIN. 

really now? come on, homes. i'm watching you and the rest of your coworkers. you're not THAT busy. 

there are numerous other service-related things i could write about, but most of them are less of a big deal, like the waiters being unintentionally rude and rushing us out of the restaurant (there is an art to this; they need to learn it), taking forever to bring us our food, taking forever to bring us our check. 

again, the food is good. i'm giving takara a very, very, very marginally earned 3, just cause it's one of the few japanese-owned restaurants in j town that i really enjoy going to, despite the lousy service.
author: Edmund C.

description: Great traditional Japanese fare. Had the 'Kaki Fry' last night, and I got about 6 huge oysters. My favorite thing you get with the dinners is the Chawanmushi (egg custard). It comes in a little covered cup and like a cracker jack box, you find little surprises as you make your way to the bottom...fish cake, mushrooms, bamboo shoots. You also get your choice of Green Tea, Vanilla or Red Bean ice cream for dessert, which makes it a good deal. My friend Mark had the Buckwheat Soba noodles and the grilled oysters which he wasn't able to finish. I will have to get the Ochazuke next time...Rice, tea and different meats and veggies...reminds me of college days when we used to have it for a midnight snack! Try it, you won't be disappointed.
author: Arlene C.

description: This was a wonderful place for lunch. The prices are reasonable too for the amount of food! My bento consisted of 3 piece California Roll, 6 piece tempura (with a prawn) albacore sashimi (creamy and fresh) rice, miso soup and salad. All for 7.95. Service was very quick and friendly and the place was very clean. I'm ready to return!
author: renee k.
Alan P.

description:
Opened my eyes to the glory of J Town.
I was headed with my lady to a night of groove at the Fillmore, and (as usual), hit Yelp on the way in to catch a place to eat nearby in advance.
We scored the goods with about 5 options in the Miyako mall in J Town - just a couple of blocks away from the show and with ample cheap underground parking...
We first tried Ino, but the place was inevitably packed and the wait would prove to be too long.  We sashayed to Takara and were warmly greeted by the wait staff.  Plenty of seating available, and they were quick to take our drink orders and let us look over the longdong menu.
Big props on a menu that has plenty to choose from: sushi, sashimi, tempura, yosenabe, udon...you name it, they got it.
We ordered some staples: edamame and a standard roll, plus a couple of the tasty-looking combo dinners.  Food came out fast and furious, which was exactly what we needed in order to get to the show on time.  We loved all but the savory custard, which seemed a bit too creamy before a jump-up-and-down-hollar-and-scream concert.
Tempura was excellent - crispy and uncoagulated, with a great variety of veggies to choose from.  Miso soup was nice and thick.  The chicken terriaki was tasty and had a great sauce, and the side salad had a zippy dressing.  Only problem with the meal was the fact that my sashimi order never arrived.  It looked close to arriving on 2 occasions, but then was whisked away elsewhere.
Lucky I was stuffed and didn't need the fish (but I secretly yearned for it, since I would've easily thrown the tempura out as a sacrifice to scrumptious sashimi), and the wait staff was very apologetic and gave us a hell of a deal on the bill.
Still, I have to knock them a star for the miss... I'll be back again to re-rate and update soon.
author: Brett L.

description: This place is real find.  The fish quality is excellent.  There is zero atmosphere, and the service is friendly, but kind of spacey.. but the food is very very good.  There's not much in the way of the Hawaii/HK style wacky rolls, but the sashimi is amazing.  The specialty here is the green tea porridge, which was a great discovery.  It's nice to finish off your sushi meal with a little bit of something warm.  Plus, I've never needed a reservation.
author: Liz C.

description:
UPDATE for 4/13/08: Went to Takara for dinner last night and boy did the service suck!  My waitress ignored me for the entire night: not once did she check in to see how I was doing, not once did she refill my tea, she didn't even bring me my chawan mushi and miso soup!  I had to ask the poor bus boy for everything, which he did with impeccable manners.  But still, that's unacceptable to have such an incompetent waitress, right?!  Worst of all, I saw her serving all her other tables all night.  Boy, that burns me up.  I gotta knock 1 star off for that crap; however, I won't take more off since the bus boy and other waitress were very nice even though I wasn't their responsibility.  

If you've all ready read my review, I guess you can expect me to give that star back after my temper settles and my "lifetime boycott of this crap hole" ends sometime next season. ;)

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

Takara's like the girl that you've dated on and off over the last decade or so.

The food's always been pretty good (she's always been quite pretty), but I've ended boycotting Takara on and off over the past decade because of their sometimes super-crappy service (she has a bitchy streak).  They'll do things like argue with you over stupid things, sometimes botch your order, take a long time getting things to you, and they'll even do super killjoy things like carding you when it's obvious that you're over 21 (she argues with me over mundane things, nags me, and always does things to make me look stupid in front of my friends).  But what brings me back?  Well, the food of course (yeah, she's pretty good looking)!  And when I do break the boycott, I get really good service at that time (she's nice to me again).  So what happens?  I go back again a few more times, and invariably the service sucks again (she starts bitching me out again).  So I leave again (so I leave again).  But I always just end up coming back.  This has been happening for the past decade or so.

Yes, I have issues, thank you for asking.

Highlights: really great sushi -- super fresh, good cuts, great selection on omakase (real rarities that you rarely see anywhere else), but cut a little on the small side (damn, perfect opportunity for an Asian joke here but I won't go there); nice full-sized oysters on the kaki fry (although they no longer have that delicious miso-based dipping sauce but instead just give katsu sauce now); uber fresh yakizakana; and the lunch bento and lunch chirashi are steals.

Overall, a very solid authentic Japanese restaurant that is better than most others in the city, but expect to develop a looooong love-hate relationship with them.

Here's to another decade, babe!
author: Ryan D.

description: So I went here the other day and wasn't entirely impressed with the food.  Granted I was with a group of 15 people and the staff was really trying hard to get all of our orders right, but things kept getting mixed up:( I got a bottle of unfiltered sake with no glasses to drink it from, now I know that I can drink, but how do theeeyyy know that??? For what seemed 30 minutes (more like 15 minutes) my glasses arrived, whew! For a second I thought they could read my miiinnnddd... I got the seaweed salad, Unagi, and Spicy Tuna Roll. They tasted good, and for the price it was about right, I spent about twenty bucks... But for some reason the rolls kept falling apart on me, and no it wasn't my white girl ways with the chopsticks, or the bottle of sake, I saw other people having problems too!
author: Cassie L.

description: This is one of my favorite japanese joints - it's nothin' like my mama's and i don't come here for sushi - but what i love is that they have some authentic japanese dishes that you usually don't find anywhere else - chawanmushi, ochazuke.... and some red bean ice cream to finish it off. Gochisoosama!
author: N K.

description:
Looking for some good sushi, my business associates and I found Takara right in the heart of japantown. 

Service wasn't the greatest as our waitress couldn't really offer any recommendations. In addition she only came to our table when we were calling her with hands up. Empty cups and tea the whole time didn't help either.

We tried a couple Japanese hot dishes including the grilled squid and the agadashi tofu. The tofu was good but the squid was bland... Basically grilled unmarinated squid. 

What actually really stuck out here was the fish quality. The nigiri sushi had that 'soaked' look of defrosting fish and our shared plate had water build up by the time we were done! Our spider roll had a bunch of hard greens and a carrot which ruined the taste.

We left full but our sushi cravings unsatisfied...
author: Jeff H.

description: I was disappointed by this restaurant.  The food itself is 4 stars, the service is 2 stars, and the entire experience was an average 3 stars.  Usually I don't let slow service bother me when it's busy but waiting 30 minutes for the bill just got irritating and was a bad lasting impression.  I'm always up for trying new things and there was plenty of opportunity for that on the menu which is a huge plus.  But this time, it was a miss for me with the ochazuke(porridge with green tea, nori)...it didn't do it for me and I wish I went for the familiar sushi or tempura.  Also, I thought the dinner was overpriced.  Yes, it sounds like I'm moaning and groaning but it is not a bad restaurant at all, i just wanted more out of it.
author: Debbie Y.

description:
Yummm shabuu shabuuuuuu!

for 4 people (realllllyy hungrey people)
1 shabu shabu dinner
1 salmon teriyaki dinner 
1 tempura dinner

= AMAZINGNESSSSS

Like everyone else has said, the people who work here are nihongin. So don't be weried out if they start speaking to you in japanese. 

Also, for lunch Takara has some really good and cheap combination options. However, I would not recommend the sushi- go to Kushi Tsuru if you plan on having a sushi dinner.
author: elyssa w.

description: I really enjoyed eating here.  Service was a bit slow at first but the lady who was serving us was very kind and made sure that the hungry boys I was with had plenty to eat.  The chawanmushi that came with my nigiri plate was a nice treat and the nigiri was fresh and delicious, albeit a bit pricey.  It's a pretty quiet scene, but get there early or else you'll be waiting around a while for a table.
author: Krystle S.

description: Pretty authentic Japanese food. The tempura was well above average, as was the chawanmushi (warm Japanese custard) that accompanied the dinners. This is not a cutting edge hot spot serving locally sourced organic Euro-Japanese cuisine. This is a simple, traditional Japanese restaurant circa 1975. The menu is broad, and prices reasonable for the area.
author: C K.

description: Their Donburi was just fantastic.  I had the mini udon and donburi and it came in these little bowls.  I felt like i was eating at home.  The udon was not bad.  The udon noodles had just the right feel as i was biting into it.  the soup was not bad.  Just enough sodium to give it a kick.  I also tried their negitoro (toro roll w/ green onions) and that was okay.  i thought the fish taste was a little too pronounced.  overall, not a bad place to have lunch.
author: AhLin C.

description:
three words: bland and limp.

i dont know if  it was an off day, but this was the worst sushi i have ever had in my entire life. seriously. 

presentation was poor, which is okay if the food tastes good - which it did not. i always get ikura nigiri and it was completely AWFUL here. good god. the seaweed around the rice was all soft, the rice was dry, and worst of all the ikura was not nice and round looking, and tasted completely BLAND. i did not know such a thing was possible. UGH. this is worse than those pre-packaged type of sushi.

much of the sushi in the boats looked like they had been floating around for quite awhile... they did not look fresh. i dont know how else to describe it, but everything just looks limp. sake nigiri tasted awful too, very thin slices of salmon with lots of rice and tasted bland. i also had the amaebi, which was OK. 

i could not bring myself to eat much more and wanted to leave immediately. i also really wished i had eaten at the noodle place in the mall like Takashi at the Japan Center Beauty Clinic had recommended. all in all, i will never ever ever want to eat here again.
author: Sharon G.

description: This place has gone down hill over the years. still not as bad as the others in the mall, but that doesn't mean much.
author: mark l.

description:
my favorite place for japanese appetizers!

i go for their TARA MISO.  it's sooooo yummy.
author: J D.

description: not close to exceptional but price to quality ratio is solid.  chirashi for about 20 bucks.  make sure you to get your ticket validated if you use the underground parking lot.  validation available for lunch, fyi.
author: Young P.

description: Mm...it's a no-frills Japanese restaurant complete with sushi, chawanmushi, and seaweed salad.  Their simple dishes are good and the yellowtail collar was flavorful.
author: Nina L.

description: This goes against everything I stand for, but the world needs to know where the best Sushi in the US exists.  Never before have I hi-five'd a sushi chef after eating the best Toro and Uni ever.  Nobu?  Noshit... this place kills it as far as quality, but don't look for atmosphere, it's all business.  No real cold sake menu, but you can bring in your own bottle that you bought in nearby Japantown.
author: Josh F.

description: I think this is the best sushi restaurant in Japan-town.  Super fresh and  very generous portions.  The other food is great too. Try the Chirashi-sushi as well. It can get busy, but you know its good when you see all the Japanese Nationals in the restaurant.
author: X Y.

description: My absolute favorite sushi bar in San Francisco. Small, but friendly and you know the seafood is fresh when you see the tank of live shrimp outside the door in the hallway of the Japan Center (right by the Miyako Hotel entrance). I've seen someone order shrimp and get it, cut in half, with the antennae still wriggling! That's a little too fresh for me, but you get my drift. Prices... well, this is San Francisco, and I've seen worse. (I go to the Sushi Boat place near Union Square when I want cheap sushi.)
author: Denny A.

description: Got the Chirashi to go, in town for conference and this place seemed to have good reviews, though some seemed disappointed. I'm here to say don't pass it up based on some iffy posts; looks like they got a new chef or just had some off days before. My Chirashi came with ample rice, three large ieces of tuna, and two very generous  each of mackerel, salmon, squid wrapped around cucumber, snapper, egg, and pickels. Doesn't sound like much, but they are most generous sashimi slices I've come across in many years of sushi. Mackerel i usually don't care for, but these were great, melt in your mouth. Tuna, salmon, and snapper also terrific as well. Even the egg, pickle, and squid were excellent. Pleasantly full, comes with choice of salad or soup. I got the salad, good dressing, but disappointed it was all lettuce except for tiny slice of tomato and normal cucumber slice (probably take 1/2 a star off, then rounded up). Sushi though was well worth the $16.95!
author: Allen H.

description:
This is pretty good Japanese food. I come here with my dad and obaachan sometimes for lunch. The servers are kind, the food is delicious, the bentos are enough to make you stuffed.
As far as cleanliness:
Also, perhaps it's just because I'm biased, but since I think Japanese people are generally clean and cleanliness-obsessed, I think that the restaurant must be as well. I suppose it could have rat excrement. But I choose to go with the former.
author: Sora O.

description:
my friends and i happened to be in japan town and happened to be hungry - we happened to be walking past takara and decided to duck in and just hope for the best.  this quiet little restaurant amazed us with the quality of food they had to offer.

because we didn't know what to expect everyone ordered something "safe."  this included three types of dinners: ton katsu, ton katsu & sashimi and sashimi & tempura.  the food was great and the portions were generous.  the ton katsu dinner came on a plate that held two freakishly large cuts of breaded-fried pork chops.  the sashimi was cut amazingly thick and was the among the freshest i have ever tasted.  the tempura was perfectly light and crisp.

what i thought made this restaurant great were the little add ons.  before our dinner arrived they served us individual cups of chawanmushi (steamed egg) w/ pork and mushrooms.  after dinner we were treated with the unexpected, "just-right," serving of green tea ice cream (they also had vanilla, strawberry and red bean - but how can you not love green tea ice cream!?).

i have a feeling this restaurant deserves five stars from me but i need to go back and try out more of their menu.

bottom line:  this place is simply great. no fancy gimmicks. and i would definitely recommend a visit.  i know i'm going back.
author: alex c.

description: Fresh nigiri, good rolls, very casual environment, always consistent.  I don't live in the area but make the trek out there on occasion since it is reliable sushi.  The toro and mackeral taste very fresh.  I also like the toro + scallion roll.  Just the right balance of flavor from each ingredient.  It's not a tourist trap and you feel like you are getting your money's worth.
author: Butters S.

description:
I was disappointed.  I know one shouldn't expect much going to a sushi place in the mall in japantown, I mean, how tourist can you get?

But it was close to my friends new flat and we decided to give it a try.

The service was terribly slow, and it was not busy in the least.  I had the futomaki roll and the shrimp tempura roll.  futomaki was miserable, and something in the tempura roll made it taste more like a spa treatment than something i should be ingesting.    one of my companions got gyoza which looked really cool and webbed, but were unimpressive flavorwise.

we spent a good 20 minutes trying to get the attention of anyone who worked there to get our bill without being rude.

and for the love of god and all things holy, i hope they hire a new interior decorator when they decide to update their circa 1987 decor/carpeting/wallpaper.

there are like 8 million sushi places in the city, im sure you can find better, if only across the hall in the same japantown mall.
author: Christophe B.

description:
This is a hidden gem.
Takara is in the corner of the mall, near the Miyako hotel.
This is where we go when we want japanese food. Excellent quality, authentic. The only place i know that offers chawan mushi!!
Excellent value for the combination dinners. The shabu shabu offers tender beef to be dipped in the broth. The soft shell crab with the ponzu sauce is outstanding!
Service is very attentive.
author: lovetoeat a.

description: LOVE this place.  Love the Chawanmushi (the egg custard that they serve with the set dinners).  It's got a sublime, smoky flavor that I can't get enough of.  I order it even when I'm not getting a set ... everything is delicious  - they take something as basic as Nabeyaki Udon to a higher level ... the sushi always tastes super fresh...  I love the friendly skinny maitre d and the gruff waitress who'll tell you if you're ordering too much ... don't get here as much anymore, since the place is always crowded ... and it's not easy to get the kid's stroller in there...
author: June S.

description: The sashimi was amazing - excellent quality fish. The service was not very attentive and the atmosphere lacked a bit coziness, but that can all be forgiven due to the excellent food. They have a huge menu with lots of choices that you don't generally see in other Japanese restaurants. We had a claypot dish with crab that was unusual and delicious. We definitely recommend going out of your way to find this place.
author: Stephanie R.

description: We came here for dinner last week for dinner. Food was ok, acceptable but nothing exciting. Service was not very good.
author: M B.

description: Had steamed egg and tempura and it was so good.  I have to say the sashimi was fresh.
author: Mary L.

description: So the parentals rolled in for their semi annual visit, and one of the places my Dad always has to go is Soko Hardware. And being from Texas, they are always complaining about the Japanese food and can't wait to come to SF for "real" Japanese food. So being the smart cookie I am, I decided to kill the proverbial two birds with one stone and try a Japanese restaurant in Jtown. First, I have to say that I was kind of surprised by the lack of 5 stars for the food in the area - I mean, how hard is it to have decent Japanese food in a place called Japantown? Second, and this is probably because I was raised on Texas Japanese food, I thought this place was really good! Ambiance is dive-ish (which I ADORE) and when we went for lunch just before the lunch rush, it was filled with these cute older Japanese people who reminded me of my grandmas and grandpas. For starters, I thought the miso was good - not too salty and kind of gritty but not overly so. I had the udon lunch combo with katsu don (as did Dad) and I thought they got the donburi sauce/ rice mixture down nicely. My mom had the chirashi lunch special and said it was one of the best she's ever had (though, again, she has lived in Texas for more than 40 years). She said that the vinegar flavor to the rice was practically perfect and the fish was incredibly fresh. And for the 3 of us, the bill only came out to 35 bucks. I think I'm going to add this on to the list of parent approved restaurants for their next visit.
author: Elena N.

description: Food was ok.  Service was great until after the meal.  Went with my in-laws, who tipped not so much. I was going to make ammends (i.e. sneak a $10 bill when they were on their way out, thinking for a $40 lunch it would be sufficient.  However the server came across the restaurant and, in front of my mother-in-law, counted the money and asked if the service was okay as we didn't leave much of a tip.  WOW. I was still seated!!!  The server waited until i opened my purse and walked away.  I left $5 more after her comment.  You lost $5 and a customer.
author: Erin F.

description: Great, homey, simple, authentic Japanese food. Nothing fancy here, no fusion cuisine or anything. As I'm half Japanese and lived in Japan for several years, I feel right at home here (feel like I'm back in Japan). The entire staff is Japanese and quite efficient and friendly. I love the lunch time o-bento box. You get miso soup, salad, 3 pc. California roll, tempura and then get to pick one item from a list of 4-5 things (tonkatsu, chicken teriyaki, etc.). All that for $6.95! I heard that the sushi isn't as good as it once was since the chef Yuki-san left, but it's not bad. If you want great sushi, go next door to Ino-sushi. This is a great place if you have a group and want to drink sake and order a bunch of "tsumami" (small plates to drink with, like Japanese tapas). Also, it doesn't get super noisy like Oyaji, so it's great if you want to catch up with old friends (you won't have to yell at each other across the table).
author: lani P.

description: Just went there last night about 7pm with the 4 of us.  I will start with the positive: the food was wonderful. Everything from the chawan mushi to the nicely grilled beef teriyaki was very tasty. My family ordered the sushi/sashimi combo which was beautifully prepared and all pieces were very fresh and tender. For that, I give the total 2 stars. I give NO stars for the service...just awful!! We waited and waited for our order to be taken...it was busy but not overwhelming with three waitresses. Tables around us were getting their orders taken before us. Once we finally ordered, the dishes came out very quickly and all at once. NO one checked on us nor did they refill our teas...when we all ordered water, only 2 glasses came. When we finally got the bill, the waitress grabbed the credit card without a single thank you. It was when she brought the card back she noticed we still had all the finished dishes in front of us with no dessert...we refused! Just terrible service!! First in awhile...could have been just that moment but we will NOT be going back. Unfortunate because the food was very good.
author: Naomi N.

description: this place is not a bad place to grab a quick bite in jtown.  i came here w/ the fam on saturday for lunch, and service was swift.  they have a lunchtime bento that is only $6.95 which comes w/ CA rolls, salad, miso soup, rice, and a choice of a couple items.  i got the lunchtime chirashi, and the portion was just right.  the fish was pretty good and fresh, and the sushi rice was delish.
author: Helen T.

description: I had dinner here with some friends on a week night. The service was good and we received our orders timely. This restaurant is located in the back of the mall next to the Kabuki Hotel, an area I usually never visit. Upon ordering, I was expecting to the find the usual bento boxes with 2/3 items combination dinner. Instead, I was pleasantly surprised with a full meal. They started out with shredded bamboo shoots, 2 pickles, miso soup, my combo choice (teriyaki chicken and tempura), a porcelain cup with steamed egg custard with mushrooms, and ice cream. The portion size and quality of the food was decent. My favorite part was the smooth steamed egg custard. They also had a shabu shabu option and plenty of sushi rolls to choose from. My friend ordered the sushi with the fish on top of the rice. It was proportioned well, the rice wasn't overwhelming. If you want an old school traditional Japanese meal, this is the place to be.
author: Candace F.

description: We've only come here for lunch, but we've come many times and oh what a lunch!  My wife is from Japan and she says that the food here reminds her of Mom's Home cooking in Japan,   We always order the Lunch Combo with Tonkatsu and Tempura.  The Tonkatsu is cooked just right and also comes with a nice clump of karashi (Japanese Hot Mustard).  The Tempura is fried nice and fresh with not an overload of batter, the way it's supposed to be.  When your Shrimp Tempura looks like a "Billy Club" and you find that there is only regular sized shrimp inside, that is NOT authentic Japanese.  The Tempura also comes with some grated Daikon to mix in your Tempura sauce, another authentic touch from Japan.  Lastly, you get a small plate with Oshinko, pickled vegetable, very authentic.  They have Comdo Lunch Specials for about $6.95 but we found that the Regular Lunch Combo - 2 Items is perfect and is about $11.00, good deal good meal!  The only problem we have with them is that if you come in right when they open the restaurant has a peculiar smell like the carpet may be moldy or the mops or towels that they use to wipe the place needs to be thoroughly washed and deodorized.
author: Doug L.
