description: my dad took me here the last time i was in the city.  admittedly, i was super skeptical.  i grew up in jtown and had never eaten here before.  this place is great.  i had the lunch set for $7.  it came with salad, miso soup, tempura and a choice of 4 different things (i chose the white ahi sashimi.)  everything was perfect and the sashimi melted in my mouth.  kinda shetty that they're tucked away into the side of the mall that no one really goes to, but its great none the less.  great bang for your buck.   good choice, pops.
author: Karina U.

description:
so i read/heard about this place thru yelp.  and boy...was i interested.  and what better way to try takara out than on my girlfriend's bday before the dredg show @ the fillmore.  so it took a bit of searching & sleuthing to find the place.  its INSIDE the mall, not outside along the street or anything.  find 22 peace plaza (next to the big ol' japanese tower thingie) and go upstairs...

outside you'll see a tank of live shrimp....read on and you'll see why.....

so i took the suggestion and asked for us to be seated at the sushi bar.  we got there around 6'ish on a thursday nite.  there was only a couple finishing up their meal there. 

did i mention that EVERYONE at takara was supremely nice/polite/helpful?  they even showed me how to eat this fried tofu soup.   they speak fluent japanese (and their english ain't too bad either), but expect lots of japanese being spoken between the chefs.   great learning experience.  i wish i knew some basic japanese so i wouldn't feel like such an arse.

anyways....onto the food.....got seated promptly and was greeted enthusiastically by both sushi chefs.  lots of cool things in front of you:  2 kinds of plates, a chopstick holder, and they hand you a hot towel.  then your water/beverage and some odd black seaweed looking snacky thing that was really good.  then proceeded to order LOTS of sushi.  the girlfriend did the ordering because she knows alot more than i do.  but this is what i DO remember eating: salmon, unagi, uni, tako, scallop, some plum mint roll thing, spider roll, tamago, maguro, grilled beef tongue (for myself)...we might have ordered hamachi or some other things, but honestly, i don't remember.  but it was all SOOO good.  even better because our sushi chefs were catering to ONLY us since we were pretty much in the sushi bar alone, while everyone else was in the dinner room, til about 7:30pm when a large group of 6-7 came in (they even had their own bottle of sake with their respective names on em waiting for them).

now....remember the shrimp tank i mentioned?  well....we ordered ama-ebi....which is a raw shrimp nigirizushi.    they literally grab what live shrimp they need into a bucket and bring it over to the itamae-san (sushi chef) and they just kill it right in front of you and turn it into the most delectable thing ever.  EVER.   ahhhhh!!!..........but wait.......they don't waste anything.   they heads come back to you fried.....eyes, brain, whiskers thingies.  it may be scary to some, but just eat it...it hella good!

so yeah.........it was all delicious.   the bill came to $81 bucks (food & tea).  would've been $84, but they never brought us our miso soups that we ordered from the get go.  but its okay by me....i was effin stuffed by the end.  i dropped a $21 tip...so it came out to $102 altogether.  yeah, it got expensive...but it was worth it.  plus it was the lady's bday.

this place is legit.  i can see why the yelpers here want to keep this place a secret.   this place is number 1 on my sushi lists.  extra points because i think they freshly grate wasabi roots for you when you come in.  you can taste it.......and so will your nose canal and brain.

i'm coming back on saturday with 3 friends to have em try the ama-ebi.
on sat they are open from 5:30pm-9pm.  i have no idea if they are open earlier for lunch though....sorry guys.  thats all the info i have.

cheers!  -nick2k
author: Nick N.

description: i haven't been here since the change in ownership either, but when we ate here last november, it was really good. the dashi they use has that taste you can only get in japan (i'm still trying to unlock the secrets of duplicating this flavor).  i've had better tonkatsu in Japan, but theirs came pretty close.  the shioyaki saba was good.  the best part was that it was served with tsuri daikon, which kills the fishy taste a little and tastes so good with some shoyu over your fish. yum!  also great is their chawan mushi and kimpira side dishes.  their prices seem high, but you get a lot of sides (miso soup, salad & a scoop of ice cream for dessert) -- so it was all worth it in my book.  this was probably the tastiest authentic japanese meal i've had in the bay area so far.
author: Waynele Y.

description: I will never pass on an opportunity to eat udon or have an oyako-don.  And tonight, we thought we'd try somewhere new.  Takara is situated on the east side of the Japantown Shopping Center. The times we've walked by, it's always been busy... which would indicate good food.  Well, we were seated immediately and the menus were we given offered a wide variety of choices.  From sushi/sashimi to udon/soba, there was nearly every Japanese food items that you could imagine. The prices are a bit higher than the restaurants on the west side of the center, but the portions are bigger.  I had the Tonkatsu dinner (which game with an egg custard, miso soup, rice and side salad), wifey ordered the nabeyaki udon.  We also shared agedashi tofu appetizers.  The boiling udon came out quickly, even before the tofu made it out.  It looked real hearty but the flavor seemed to be a 'little' lacking.  My tonkatsu pieces were rather thick (dare I say meaty)... which made it a bit tougher to chew, and the panko crumbs seemed like they had been fried a longer time.  The agedashi tofu... a simple dish of slightly battered and fried tofu with radish shavings on top... was this blocks of tofu submerged in a syrupy sauce with the radish shavings and shiitake mushrooms.  The sauce overwhelms what is supposed to a rather delicate and simple dish.  We'd come here again to give it another try, but would have to go back to our usual staple a couple of times to satisfy our udon desire.
author: Dale K.

description: I am torn about this restaurant. I had made a reservation for when the place opened at 5:30pm (on a Sunday) and within 10 minutes the place was pretty much full...good sign, right? Well, the problem was the service was slow, really slow. The poor lady was in over her head. I was taking my boyfriend's parents from out of town and chose a place that I thought would be moderately priced (they usually like to front the bill). The sushi came and it was good, but when we wanted more we had to wait a good 20-25 minutes for her to come back (she forced us to be those annoying people who raise their finger when they need something..urgh! I hate those people!). Then, when we were done, we waited another 20-25 minutes for the bill (which in the end was not so moderate). I would think with so much competition in the area that they would try a little harder, but they are obviously on to something because there was a good wait when we left. Final word: if you don't mind waiting, give it a try, but its not so incredible that you have to go...a lot of help I am :)
author: Debbie L.

description: Yummy "Mom's In the Kitchen" sort of Japanese food...they have their usual suspects of tempura, chicken teriyaki and some sushi (which is surprisingly good for a non-sushi only designated restaurant)...but what I go for is the "ochazuke" (green tea over rice and other accoutrements) and super yummy chawan-mushi (sort of a savory custard with shrimp, fish cake and ginko nuts in the middle)...it's only served at night but man, oh man, I could eat it for every meal...
author: Hannah H.

description: Had the tempura udon. Just average, nothing memorable. Maybe I didn't order the right stuff? Service was so polite though, I feel bad giving only 3 stars.
author: M. W.

description:
Ok, this is officially the first bad restaurant in San Francisco when it comes to food.  The city is known for its amazingly fresh food and creative approaches to it. The quality of sushi in SF really stands out... apparently not in Takara. 
It is very touristic place that targets crowd who have no or a very little exposure to sushi. It was almost impossible to get an attention of a waiter, who was running between the tables and the cashier. 
The first warning that I saw on the menu was the "bundled dinner" that comes with soup, a couple of appetizers, sashimi etc. This was scary enough. Though I ordered "Special Sashimi" that wasn't anything close to special, the quality was still very mediocre. However, fish in spicy tuna roll was so old that I had to stay on Tums for rest of the night.
If you have never had sushi in your life and would like to try it for the first time - try some other place (Ino next door is pretty good). If you are sushi connoisseur - stay away!
author: Milena A.

description: We had dinner here last night.  Wow.  The two choice dinner for $21 is a great deal.  My gf had the beef steak which was very tender and I had the teriyaki beef and tempura dinner.  You get miso soup, rice, two entrees and dessert.  The service is always very good and the wait is never long.
author: Brian L.

description: Takara has great traditional Japanese cooking that you won't find in too many restaurants.  The food has been consistently good on every visit.  The service, however..... well, I'd easily rate it as among the WORST I've ever experienced at a restaurant.
author: Matt B.

description: Authentically Japanese from the cooks to the waitpeople, who all speak Japanese.  Takara is my favorite place in Japantown, and apparently a favorite of many Japanese Americans in the Bay Area who flock to it at lunch time.      The menu is extensive.    It t offers many different a la carte items and combination meals, including "bento boxes."   It has all of the familiar fare:  teriyaki, tempura, broiled fish, domburi (rice bowls), noodles, sushi, and sashimi.    The raw fish is impeccably fresh and all sushi, even in the bento boxes, is made to order.   My favorite is a combination lunch that allows you to choose 2 or 3 items and comes with  miso soup and pickles.  Service is quick and efficient despite only 3 wait people who  seat guests, take and serve orders, and refresh water glasses and tea cups.  There is also a sushi bar in a separate room from the main dining area.
author: Evelyn G.

description: I went here last week and the sushi was really good and fresh. We ordered the nigiri omikasa and some rolls. The uni was fresh. (Big uni fan). The Toro melted in your mouth. I felt that the price was a little above the average sushi place but well worth it.
author: S N.

description: The sushi / sashimi is the freshest and best quality around.  Service is prompt and courteous.  Only regret is that the cost of fresh fish is continually rising and the restaurant obviously has to pass the increases along.  Some of my favorites (Toro) have been priced out of reach.  Other dishes are good but the sushi sets this place apart from many others.
author: Dennis B.
